title: Fiesta in Florissant (Mo.). 2023.
BodyText: Catholic devotional art sold by vendors at the community event in the north St. Louis County suburb of Florissant. Florissant was an early French Catholic settlement in the 18th century, which included missions to local indigenous peoples. The Catholic population of the region, as elsewhere in the United States, has become considerably more Latine in recent generations.

title: Saint Louis CITY Soccer Club
BodyText: STL CITY SC matches are opportunities to reflect on the similarities of civic and cultural practices to those commonly classified as “religion”. At this May 20 match against "derby" rival Sporting Kansas City, the club and fans marked sacred space through performances such as a parade and chanting and through physical markers such as the installation of Damon Davis’s “Pillars of the Valley,” which memorializes and makes visible the erasure of a thriving black community to make way for “urban improvement” on the site the stadium now stands. Clothing, devotion-based subcultures, and fan-created iconographies of players are other ways that CITY SC can challenge and illuminate the ways we think about and understand religion.
creator: 8H86gZYSFIRHGy8q39OgBAfQFeC2

title: Epiphany Lanes
BodyText: Located on the campus of Epiphany of Our Lord Catholic Church, Epiphany Lanes is (as of 2022) a fully functional bowling alley. It is among the last remaining of a thriving mid-twentieth century culture of parish bowling alleys in the Archdiocese of St. Louis. Church recreation clubs and spaces have a long history in the US, dating at least as far back as the 19th-c. Bowling alleys like Epiphany Lanes in the 20th century seem to have been less motivated by the physical culture movement that produced the YMCA and other similar reform movements and more concerned with creating community spaces to bolster parish social ties and Catholic identities.
creator: 8H86gZYSFIRHGy8q39OgBAfQFeC2

title: Holy Family Catholic Church
BodyText: Holy Family Catholic Church in Cahokia, Illinois, is located just east of St. Louis across the Mississippi River. It was founded in the 17th-century and is the oldest continuous parish in the region.

title: Busch Stadium
BodyText:
Busch Stadium in St. Louis, Missouri, is the home of Major League Baseball's St. Louis Cardinals. The team dates to the late 19th century and has a robust, dedicated fan base in St. Louis and beyond. A statue of Stan Musial greets visitors and passersby in front of the main gate wherestadium tour ticket holders gather. On the day I visited with my graduate seminar, people from all over the country--and fans of other MLB teams--gathered to tour this cathedral of baseball. 


In addition to informing tourists of the team's history, the tour guide recited the names of legendary players (including Musial) and permitted tourists' entrance into areas of the stadium otherwise restricted to ticket holders, including owners boxes, media rooms, and trophy rooms. Throughout, the tour created a sense of sacred space that was embodied in tour goers' reverence for images and objects on display.
creator: 8H86gZYSFIRHGy8q39OgBAfQFeC2

A quote:

With some trial and error, Trudy can probably overwrite the return ad- dress with the address of the start of buffer. Then the program will try to "execute" the data stored in the buffer. Why might this be useful to Trudy? Recall that Trudy can choose the data that goes into the buffer. So, if Trudy can fill the buffer with "data" that is valid executable code, Trudy can exe- cute this code on the victim's machine. The bottom line is that Trudy gets to execute code of her choosing on the victim's computer. This has to be bad for security. This clever version of the stack smashing attack is illustrated in Figure 11.6.

Random quote from my Computer Security Textbook

title: Food Bazar Wall Ridgewood Queens 1
BodyText: This skull is on Food Bazaar's wall as part of the Making History mural in Ridgewood, Queens. Many of the residents and shoppers are Central American immigrants. This was paintied around the time of Dia de los Muertos, end of October, beginning of November. The other side of this building has Afro-Latin American experience theme, specifically of women.
creator: d2v7JCxLlFT9jkQlvayOD4Z3HAL2

title: Food Bazar Wall Ridgewood Queens 2
BodyText: This is the other side of the Food Bazar wall in Ridgewood Queens. Both of these show that the mural planners and artists are creating art work they think will be relatable to the local residents, here specifically, Afro-Caribbean or Afro-Latin. The mural makes a statement about feminism. Put together with the figure of a woman and a river flowing out of her, it can be interpreted as a goddess or "Mother Nature," and that nature is feminine. here the question, what is religion? does this count as a marker of religion on "a-religious space," a supermarket wall. The non profit organization Groundswell plan and paint murals for this grocery store chain.
creator: d2v7JCxLlFT9jkQlvayOD4Z3HAL2

title: St. Louis Pride Parade
BodyText:
When walking up to the Pride Parade in St. Louis, pedestrians can hear the roar of the crowd as floats pass by and the bright colors in the crowd. Rainbow flags fly high in the air and cars slowly pass by, looking for parking spots. Almost every parade goer wears rainbow attire and walks by with a smile on their face. Hardworking men push carts in the 90 degree heat and call out that they have ice cold beverages or pride gear for sale. The crowd cheers out louder when drag queens riding in convertibles wave in their direction or a float passes by that is throwing out rainbow beads and candy. While Pride celebrations are traditionally very loud and proud, this parade was actually a very calm environment. There were many families with small kids in attendance and corporations that are branded as “family-friendly” had giant floats decked out with rainbow colors, furthering the idea that pride is for all ages. All of the St. Louis community coming together to celebrate those that face discrimination every day simply for their sexuality shows the close-knit aspect of the St. Louis community. 


Do the corporations that had floats in the parade actually continue to have prideful values after the parade, or do they only use it as a way to make money from LGBTQIA communities?

Are the people that come to the parade still just as much advocates for the community once they leave?

Were the people in attendance mostly from the middle class? Is there a correlation between being an ally to the LGBTQIA community and class? Race? Gender?

  • Driving passed the parade location, I can see from a distance all the people that are lining up around the parade’s barriers and cars crowd the entire area

  • There is honking all over and traffic is incredibly slow moving as everyone tries to find a parking spot

  • Walking into the parade grounds on Market Street, cops direct traffic away from the route and make way for the crowds of people pouring in

  • There seems to be an excitement in the air to finally reach the parade action

  • At the less populated end of the parade, the crowd is still three people deep from the barriers

  • Many people sit in the shade behind the crowd because the weather is incredibly hot, 90 degrees today

  • One of the first things I see when looking towards the crowd is a man pushing a cart around, sweating through his shirt. The cart is full of rainbow colors and bright flags shoot up way above the top of the cart. As he pushes it, the flags fly back a little bit in the breeze. A young woman in knee-high rainbow socks flags the man down and he stops his cart. She walks up and walks around the entirety of the cart, looking at all the options. The man waits patiently until she makes a decision. He takes the cash and continues on the route, fanning himself in the process.

  • Everyone around me has some sort of pride gear or bright colors on them, not one person in sight’s clothing is bland

  • Sitting in the shade, the crowd is slightly quieter, you can see the beads and candy thrown by the floats flying into the crowd

  • People’s cheers get louder when a float comes by that is throwing free things, and much quieter as soon as it passes

  • Although I thought the crowd would be mostly young people, the crowd is very diverse: many families are here with young and older children, people are here with their friends or significant others, and many people (young or old) come in groups. While the crowd is mostly caucasian, it is not by a large margin.

  • People cheer and clap constantly, as the floats go by one after the other -- no breaks in between

  • Many of the cars in the parade are convertibles with drag queens sitting in the back of them, waving to the people and smiling. People seem to cheer much louder for the drag queens, especially when they look in their direction. Wearing long gowns, wigs, and a lot of makeup, it seems like it would be incredibly hot

  • Many people in attendance are wearing cardinals or blues gear, some of which has rainbow colors for the parade

  • Towards the end of the parade, the floats are all made to represent corporations like Schnuck’s, Boeing, Bud Light, and many more. The cheers were much softer for those floats. I think this is because the other organizations in the parade, like Pride STL, seem authentically there for the right reasons

  • Political candidates are also using the Pride Parade press, riding in the back of convertibles with their face, name, and office they are running for plastered on the side of the car

  • The barricades seem to get more crowded every few minutes as people get up from their break in the shade and come back to see the action

  • A lot of people have put out lawn chairs and blankets under the shade, missing out on most of the action to be in the shade. From their view, the crowd is blocking the floats so they can only see things that are above them, like flags and balloons

  • Men who seem to have been working all morning and afternoon in the heat are walking down the route with rolling coolers or carts, yelling out that they have ice cold beverages or water bottles

  • I expected there to be trash littered all over the ground like any other big parade I’ve been to, but there is not a single piece of trash in sight. People seem to be respectful of littering and the environment at this parade

  • I also expected there to be a lot of craziness and rude people in the crowd, as usually there are some negative experiences in giant crowds like that, but all the people seem to be friendly around me and respect my personal space. When I asked someone to take a picture of my boyfriend and I, they were more than willing to help

  • While Pride celebrations are traditionally very loud and proud, this parade was actually a very calm environment. There were many families with small kids in attendance and corporations that are branded as “family-friendly” had giant floats decked out with rainbow colors, furthering the idea that pride is for all ages. All of the St. Louis community coming together to celebrate those that face discrimination every day simply for their sexuality shows the close-knit aspect of the St. Louis community. 

Video 1

Video 2
creator: m5zMmy4slFNMTuX7a4kn6hIFumX2

title: St. Francis Xavier Church
BodyText:
There were only three sounds as I first walked into the St. Francis Xavier Church: the sound of the huge wooden door creaking open as I walked inside, my clap of my sandals against the smooth floors echoing throughout the vaulted ceilings, and water dripping into a huge cement pool of holy water. Once I sat down in the wicker seats in the back, the sound of distant traffic from Grand and the Church’s blasting air conditioner became more evident, but was still muted. The air around me smelled like an old book, as there were blue bibles next to every single chair or pew in the building. The walls were full of depictions of religious figures: huge cement sculptures hung on the walls that showed the story of Jesus and the cross consecutively and stained glass on three of the four walls poured in light and color that each showed a specific religious message. Even with groups coming in and out of the Chapel, the Church was the perfect destination for quiet reflection and escape from the busy atmosphere of the city outside.

Do people still do confessions here? Is it similar to the traditional Catholic confessions that is depicted in media?

How many people visit this site in one day? Where are the workers and clergy people?

When, if ever, is the church closed?

  • Sound of water dripping into pool of holy water

  • Distant sounds of traffic outside on Grand Blvd

  • Sounds of the air conditioner running, cold air runs throughout the whole church

  • Sunlight comes through stained glass on three of the four walls, giving off bright red, blue, yellow, and purple colors

  • A bright spotlight shines on the sculpture in the front, depicting holy figures

  • A good place for quiet reflection, as no one is in the Chapel and there are only light or distant sounds coming in

  • Blue bibles are in a cubby next to every seat or in front of the pews

  • Confessional booths are open all along the side walls, lights and curtains are only on half of them

  • The cool air conditioning feels like a wall as you step into the giant doors from the summer heat

  • The air smells like an old book

  • Any sound echoes up into the highly vaulted ceiling, especially the sound of my sandals walking on the smooth floors

  • The seats in the back are made of wicker, make a stretching sound as someone sits in it

  • Sounds of nearby traffic and construction become more evident

  • The walls, windows, and main altar-area are covered in sculptures and portraits of religious figures

  • One side’s sculptures depict Jesus being put up on the cross, the other continues the story of Jesus coming back down off the cross

  • Spotlights shine down from an area near the ceiling, that looks like the balcony-area of an opera show

  • The spotlights only shine on two areas: the main altar in the front and the pool of the holy water in the back

  • The rest of the church is illuminated by modern-looking chandeliers along the side walls

  • The nine giant columns that span from the back of the church to the front are made of a glossy stone material that reflects the light from the chandeliers

  • The noise from the holy water pool gets louder every few minutes, as a larger amount of water collects and spills from the fountain

  • A motorcycle speeds by on the street, giving off a loud engine noise that echoes throughout the church

  • The large wooden doors squeak open and the traffic noises sound much closer

  • Footsteps echo through the church as a large group walks in

  • “At least 800 students attend every Sunday night” says a tour guide to her tour group that just entered

  • The stained glass windows next to me show Jesus and his disciples and reads “Follow Me”

  • The one next to it shows people bowing to Jesus and says “Behold, the Heart that had Loved Men so Much”

  • As the tour group exits the church, the quiet, peaceful noises that I heard become more apparent

title: Crave Coffee House
BodyText:
When passing by on SLU’s Medical Campus, the Crave Coffeehouse building appears to be a traditional-looking church. Once inside, however, you are met with a blast of cool air from the ceiling fans on the vaulted ceilings and 2000’s music softly playing over the speakers. You notice the modern-looking brick covering all the walls and the tall stained glass windows that pour color into each side of the room. You see the altar at the front of the worship center, with a big wooden cross lit aglow by a warm light behind it. There is a huge curved counter where friendly workers make coffee out of machines that whir loudly. Customers of all different careers and ages drink coffee, converse, and laugh around the room. Crave Coffeehouse provides an atmosphere that defies traditional religious ideologies, starting with its exterior. Groups of all kinds gather at Crave to create a welcoming atmosphere -- whether it is with a Christian motivation or not.


Do customers typically frequent Crave because of the religious undertones, or just because of the coffee/location?

Do all the workers share Crave’s religious values?

What does Crave’s typical customer look like/what is their profession?

  • Soft 2000’s music plays over the speakers and echoes throughout the room

  • Barista laughs with customers who are placing their order

  • The air smells like coffee beans and pastries 

  • A blender whirs as a barista adds in ingredients to make a customer’s smoothie

  • The door creaks open and clicks shut as a new group of friends/students arrive

  • Three large fans are on the ceiling, making cool air flow throughout the whole shop

  • Students doing homework at a nearby table make clicking noises as they type on their laptops

  • Little snippets of each conversation is picked up from where I’m sitting every few seconds

  • Conversations of two different groups of girls blend together, drone out the music 

  • The sound of the refrigerator whirring is one of the three most prevalent sounds (fridge, music, conversation)

  • The layout of Crave is an exact replica of a church’s worship center, as they hold a Sunday mass here every week

  • Banners at the front of the shop read “loved by God, sent to the world” and “Crave Coffeehouse + Reliant Church”

  • A cross is the focal point of the room, is displayed in the middle of the altar-area with a backlight making it look like it’s glowing

  • Seven tall, pointed stained glass windows on both side walls pour blue, yellow, red, green, and pink into the room

  • Two of the female students in the room softly sing along to the music playing as they write in notebooks

  • A machine behind the coffee counter starts up with a loud electric noise

  • Silverware and a mug clink together in a woman’s hand as she begins to clear her table

  • The brick that covers all four walls seems old and imperfect, some areas of brick being more white than red

  • The room is long and narrow, with an altar at the front. The altar is a stage-like area of the front wall that contains the main lit-up cross, four candles and metal candle holders, and a wooden podium 

  • At the back right corner of the room is the coffee bar, a huge curved counter where two workers stand near the register, waiting for their next customer

  • At the very back of the room is the restrooms on either side wall, with huge wooden doors between them that lead out to the parking lot

  • Without seeing the “Crave Coffeehouse” sign out front, a passerby may believe that this building is just a traditional church

  • Once walking inside, you are met with a nice breeze from the ceiling fans on the high ceilings, friendly baristas that greet you, and a very modern-looking church with a coffee bar in the back that seems like it belongs there

  • There are stairs leading to a door on one side of the altar that leads to the backstage area

  • Above the restrooms and the back door, there is a balcony area like a typical church may have

  • The balcony area is made of dark wood, and looks like it’s the oldest and most traditional part of the building

  • All different kinds of people are inside: professionals in the middle of their work day, more casual workers with name badges, young students here to study, and groups of friends of all different ages that gather

  • Most groups in the room seem to gather in one corner of the room, the environment feels very friendly and welcoming

Video 1
creator: m5zMmy4slFNMTuX7a4kn6hIFumX2

title: St. Louis Science Center
BodyText:
Walking up to the St. Louis Science Center, it felt like walking up to an extravagant church. The outside is modern and white, with a huge brass dome on the top of it. Inside, children are running around everywhere while parents follow closely behind, trying to keep track of all their kids. Within sight, there are almost no groups there without children. 

The Science Center is a child-centered experience with differing and immersive exhibits that engage the visitors’ minds with a wide variety of ways. There were interactive, first hand, personal experiences that appealed to all ages in some way. The information presented was timeless and revealed something about our nature as a society and the world around us. It was served as a launching point for deeper inquiry, giving the audience an accessible image or concept and explaining how it affects them personally or how it has in the past. The children in attendance often lead the groups while the parents bring up the rear. The appearance of the building is similar to that of a basilica and the sense of community brought with it is not unlike that of the church. 

While children aren’t typically involved in traditional religious ceremonies, like being put in Sunday school during a Christian church service, the Science Center provides children a ritual-like activity that is completely centered around them. At the same time, the activities provided at the Center prompts the adults in attendance to play like children, too. In many psychological studies, it is proven that there are benefits of playing for adults -- although most have lost that sense of play with age. The St. Louis Science Center not only allows for children to have a sort of religious experience centered around themselves, but it also allows for adults to find that childish sense of play that is so beneficial to their health.

Do adults that bring their young children to the Center like to come for themselves, too? Or is it just for their children to have fun?

How often does the typical family come to the Science Center?

What is the age, race, sex, and class of the typical attendee?


  • From the outside, the building looks like a massive, white, modern church

  • The two main areas of the Center seem to be totally different from each other. One looks like a pop socket on the back of a phone with a very modern shape. The other looks like a beautiful church with a rounded, bronze top. They are connected by a glass bridge that goes over the highway, which seems to be a trademark of the Science Center

  • The glass bridge is something I see almost everyday driving past it. Before I knew what that building was, I just saw it as a signifier that I was getting closer to SLU when I saw it

  • After finding out it was the Science Center, I always knew it as “the building with the air quality sign” on it

  • My roommate and I used to joke that when the Science Center said the air quality was good, our days would be good

  • Now, walking up to the huge cement front walkway, it feels like I really am walking into a St. Louis monument

  • There was an outside exhibit called “Whisper Tunnel” where there are two large white dishes standing 40 feet from one another. When a person whispers into one, the sound shoots across and the person at the other dish can hear it. There were two older ladies standing at it when I walked past, each whispering into it and listening when the other said something, giggling like little kids

  • There are people funneling into the large entryway from the parking lot. People seem to be walking quickly to get into the air conditioned building because it’s so hot outside

  • Upon walking into the glass doors, a blast of cool air hits the visitors and they’re met with a line of people trying to pay their parking ticket

  • Suddenly, the air is filled with a ton of echoed chatter from the crowded room and the high ceilings

  • Your eyes are immediately drawn to the ceiling where there are all different types of pipes and wire paths where balls roll down and all kinds of crazy machinery whirs

  • The paths are all different colors and make the ceiling look hectic and chaotic, but very playful

  • Walking in further, you are met with all the pathways to the exhibits on the first floor

  • There are restaurants to the right as soon as you walk inside that have a retro vibe to them

  • Families stand in line at them seemingly after a few hours at the Center, children are crying and some have blue rings around their mouths from their slushees

  • So far, every single person within sight has a young child with them

  • Walking up the stairs in the main room, there’s like a totally different world on the upper floor

  • People are walking around everywhere and there are even more children on this floor. Kids are running around and parents are close behind them to keep track of them

  • There are three ways to go, all leading to different exhibits. We chose to walk up to the balcony and look out at the huge dinosaur replica exhibit with a crowd of people around it

  • Next to the dinosaur was a fake digging site for archaeological digs

  • The dinosaur was very realistic, the skin had so many details on it and the head would turn every few seconds. The eyes would look from left to right and its presence seemed to loom over the audience below it

  • One man reached up and tried to touch the fake t-rex’s mouth, jumping with his hand above his head

  • Kids stood in awe of the dinosaur, having to crane their necks all the way back to see it

  • On the bridge, natural light poured in through the green-yellow tinted windows, seeming really bright compared to the other areas with no windows

  • Cars zoomed past below us as people looked at them in the binoculars that were set up

  • There are all different shapes on the carpeted floor that are glass and see-through to the street below. Kids pushed their friends and siblings on them and yelled when they stepped on it in fear

  • I got to see the back of the sign I see everyday driving down the highway

  • Coming into the space center, there were cool lights coming out of all the doorways that made it feel more modern 

  • Technology whirs around us as there are exhibits all around that simulate actually being in a spacecraft 

  • At the end of the Center, there was a big circular room where a huge summer camp sat and waited for their bus, some of the kids sitting and watching a person try to land a spacecraft in one of the exhibits, others running into the space-themed gift shop

  • History of play (boy scouts - outdoors, YMCA - indoors) and how adults grow out of it and that religious background

  • How children are typically left out of religious services to go to Sunday school, and the Science Center gives them a child-centered ritual to take part in

  • Lance Armstrong’s mother recently said in an interview on Hulu that she hoped the landing gave greater glory to God

    • Do religious groups come to the Science Center?

    • Do they view the landings in this light?

    • Do they come to the Science Center and see the space section in this light?

title: Ellen Clark Sculpture Park
BodyText:
The sound of the creak as you walk through the wrought-iron gates of the Sculpture and Dog Park signifies an entire new environment. Although the loudest sound is still the constant traffic on the intersection between Grand and Lindell, the park has a completely different atmosphere than the bustling cityscape surrounding it. Covered in bright green grass and shady trees with birds chirping loudly overhead, the park acts as a resort from the hectic chaos that lies just beyond its gates. The natural landscape differs immensely from the brick buildings that surround the park. While the surrounding city has sounds of cars in traffic, the park has sounds of dogs’ collars jingling. 

The difference in landscape rings true in even the social aspect of the park: most conversations start with a simple “what is your dog’s name?” or “what breed is it?”. Because of the automatic shared interest of everyone that walks through those gates, social interaction comes incredibly natural to the park’s attendees. While the crowd ranges from young couples, students, families, and older individuals, conversations flow all over the park. The park’s dog population varies just the same: small dogs, big dogs, old dogs, and every different shade of fur imaginable. 

While the original purpose of the park was to be a display of colorful and vibrant sculptures made by Ellen Clark, the park’s attendance is almost entirely from dog owners coming to let their dogs play freely in the city. 

The most interesting aspect of the park lies in the religious undertones. While dogs are not typically allowed in religious buildings but they still remain a huge part of many peoples’ lives, the dog park is a place that has religious aspects that includes them. Dogs and their owners visit the park every week or multiple times a week at the same times, visitors quickly learn the names of the regulars, and everyone has a common interest once they arrive.

While Ellen Clark Sculpture and Dog Park resembles a religious location for its visitors and their beloved pets, Saint Francis Xavier, the church for some of the park’s attendants, stands just adjacent to the front gate. 


Does this site require further investigating? Yes.

Where do most of the attendees live?

How often do most of them come? What times of day are most popular?

What do they normally do at the park? Do they consider it a retreat for themselves, or just their dogs?

  • Sounds of traffic and honking are the loudest noises within the park

  • A crisp wind blows through and leaves rustle on all of the trees within the gates

  • Sounds of dogs running through the grass, the tags on their collars hitting together to make bell noises 

  • Breaks screech at the stoplight between Grand and Lindell

  • In one of the many lined up cars at the stoplight, a radio blasts music in the distance and grows further away as the car speeds off

  • As a pack of dogs running together grows closer, the sounds of their heavy breathing gets louder

  • The colorful statues in the park seem much brighter in the sunlight, with colors of red, blue, green, silver, and purple

  • When new groups arrive, the iron gate squeals open and slams shut behind them

  • Every dog runs up to the new dog to smell them every time the gate opens

  • An airplane cuts through the sky above, drowning out the traffic noises for a moment

  • The park is on the northeast side of SLU’s campus and is located in front of the Marvin and Harlene Wool Center 

  • Adjacent to the Park is Saint Francis Xavier Church, which looks photoshopped in because of the deep blue sky behind it

  • A bus pulls up to the stop on the side of the Park and shouts out the location for the bus’ passengers

  • In the distance, the people in the Park can hear the fountain’s streams splashing down into the pool below it (fountain behind the blue Saint Louis University sign on Grand Blvd)

  • As time goes on, the park becomes more shady as the sun disappears behind the Jesuit Hall building

  • The Park’s attendants are a wide variety of people: young couples, students, families, and older individuals

  • While the type of people vary, the Park’s dog population has a variety just the same: small dogs, big dogs, old dogs, and every different shade of fur imaginable

  • Every few moments, a couple dogs break off from the group and begin to wrestle on their own

  • There is a lot of greenery in the park for the very contrasting city-scape surrounding it

  • We are framed on three sides by brick buildings of all different shades

  • One side of the Park gives an open view to the University, the huge church being the first thing you see

  • Fox Theater is just within view

  • The Park is very colorful with the sculptures and the surrounding city palate -- both with the actual colors of the Park and the environment

  • The SLU Church bells ring every hour

  • The Park attendants seem to spread out because of the design of the seating -- benches are spread on different ends of the Park

  • Some attendants seem to hover over their dog, watching carefully to stop any problems their dog creates -- this creates conversation as people begin to talk to the wandering owners

  • Conversations usually begin with “What’s your dog’s name?” or “What is their breed?”

  • As it gets later and people begin to come home from work, more dogs arrive at the Park

  • Although it is firstly named a “Sculpture Park” it seems as though not one person arrives simply for the sculptures, but instead, with their dogs

  • Birds chirp loudly overhead

  • The Park is located at the periphery of Grand Center, creating a great view from the Park

  • While many people use the Park to sit on their phone while their dog plays, many others use it start up conversation with other dog owners, talk with the company they came with, or to simply sit in the sun and relax

  • Many of the Park’s attendants know other owners or other dogs’ names because they come to the Park every week/many times a week

creator: m5zMmy4slFNMTuX7a4kn6hIFumX2

title: Cathedral Basilica of Saint Louis
BodyText:
When walking into the huge wooden doors of the Cathedral Basilica of St. Louis, it feels like stepping into another world. You are greeted with a giant and incredibly immaculate marble worship center. Many of the visitors, including myself, have let out an audible “wow” that feels natural upon entering the room. Among the hundreds of wooden pews in the room, huge groups of tourists walk around in awe of the beauty that surrounds them -- even in the middle of a weekday. As people enter the room, their eyes are immediately drawn to the intricate portraits on the ceiling and the shimmering gold tile that surrounds them. After that, the room draws their eyes to the main altar at the front, where Jesus hangs on the cross inside of an immaculate gazebo as a single spotlight shines on Him. Among the tour groups, families, couples, and individuals that enter the tall arches of the Cathedral, there is an unspoken rule of silence. Everyone understands that the sense of peace that the Church maintains would be broken with any loud noises. Compared to the gloomy sky and busy city streets that surround it, the Basilica offers the community a sense of peace and beauty simply upon stepping inside. 


How many people come here in a day? Are tour groups available every day?

How many people attend service here regularly? 

Is it the location or the legacy of the church that draws them in?

  • Sounds of construction taking place at the back of the Church echo throughout the giant marble room eerily

  • Tourists pour in and their soft footsteps noisily enter the room

  • A tour group is wandering throughout the church, a man in a green shirt leading it. His voice fills the room as he describes each sculpture and ceiling painting in the room

  • A young woman stands in front of the main altar, taking pictures on her camera. There are sounds from the lens focusing and then snapping the picture 

  • As soon as people enter the room, the tend to gaze up towards the immaculate ceiling paintings

  • Next, their eyes are drawn towards the altar at the front

  • The sounds of a drill in the back of the room disrupt the peaceful quiet of the room

  • Everyone whispers, as if they don’t want to disrupt the atmosphere of the Church

  • The ceilings are covered in paintings of religious figures, and behind the figures is gold tiles that make it look like the paintings are shining

  • Every inch of the room is covered in immaculate artwork, even down to the wooden pews that have intricate engravings on every side

  • It seems as if every person is transported to a different place as they step inside the Cathedral. Their eyes fill with awe as soon as they look around

  • A man tells his son “Wow. This is amazing.” as all of the altar lights are turned off except for one spotlight on a statue of Jesus

  • One mother holds her daughter in her lap in one of the pews and describes the artwork that is above them

  • One family stands to the side of the cathedral, where there is a smaller altar with a portrait of Jesus. They silently light up the red candles in front of the portrait

  • Everywhere you look, there is something new and elaborate that you notice. It feels as if you could stay in here forever and never see all of the intricate art

  • A mom walks in with four daughters and the smallest among them shouts “WHOA!” as soon as she walks in the Church. The mother hurriedly tells her daughter that she must be quiet, as if not to disturb the sense of peace in the room

  • One woman sits three pews in front of me and bends down onto the kneeling bench to say her respects to the Jesus statue in front of us

  • One young couple sits a few pews behind me and sits silently next to each other, their eyes closed and heads back, seemingly praying

  • The audience of the Cathedral is mostly families with children under 10, but there are many outliers to that in the crowd

  • Some teen-aged boys walk into the main Church area and begin making odd noises that echo throughout the room, goofing around and calling each other stupid

  • A mother makes her daughter stand in front of the main altar as she snaps pictures of her by the main Jesus statue

  • The mother with four daughters whisper-yells at them as they aggressively pull down a kneeling bench that makes a loud thud as it drops to the floor

  • The tour guide man in the green shirt talks at the back of the room, his voice echoes all the way to the front, but it is indistinguishable

  • The Cathedral is one long room with two round areas jutting out from the sides, almost in the shape of a cross. There are entrances all around the front and back of the building, making it very accessible. Each of the circular side areas contain two confessional booths each, with deep green curtains in front of them. One side also has a marble holy water vat, while the other has the red candle vigil. The front altar has an immaculate gazebo-shaped structure, with different colored marble columns holding it up. There is a marble table at the front where the Priest speaks, a candle at each end of it and a table running spreading across it. Behind that is seven tall candles laid up against a marble structure that is used as a stage for the main sculpture. The entire focal point of the room stands on that marble structure in the gazebo, which is two disciples praising a giant crucified Jesus on an immaculate cross. Jesus has a halo surrounding his hanging head

  • The Cathedral’s bell rings, signifying it is 2 o’clock

  • The tour guide man speaks in between hammer noises from the construction, the hammer noises seem to completely affect the peaceful atmosphere

  • The tour guide man stands directly next to my pew with his groups and begins to explain the artwork at the front of the room, the group is an older crowd that seem to ask questions after every piece of dialogue that the man says

  • He starts to explain all the different arches in the room and the religious figures displayed upon them

  • The room feels cold, although there is no movement of air in the room

  • Celtic crosses with flor de lees inside are the engravings on each side of the pews

  • There are people buried in the crypt underneath the Church according to the tour guide

  • The echoing of the tour guide’s voice in the room reminds me of religion because it sounds like a Priest’s voice echoing throughout the worship center as he gives a sermon

  • This room feels incredibly hard to explain, as it has so many intricate things inside of it, from the noises to the artwork to the people

title: Mary Bruemmer Room (SLU)
BodyText:
Demonstrating the Where's Religion? apps to the ad hoc campus advisory committee for the brand new Center on Lived Religion! 


The Mary Bruemmer conference room is in DuBourg Hall on the campus of Saint Louis University. Bishop Louis William Valentine DuBourg was a French Catholic who emigrated to the United States after the French Revolution and was instrumental in the founding of what would become Saint Louis University. He was a documented enslaver and also spearheaded several Catholic boarding schools among local indigenous peoples. Both enslavement and settler colonialism are part of DuBourg's legacy. The Center on Lived Religion thus also benefits from these histories of enslavement and displacement. 


Mary Bruemmer was a SLU alumna (Class of 1942) who returned in 1956 to work as an administrator and volunteer until her death in 2021 at the age of 101. Among other efforts, she served as Dean of Women, Dean of Students, and founded the Women's Commission. 


We acknowledge both of these legacies in the life and work of SLU and in the Center on Lived Religion. 


https://www.pbs.org/newshour/amp/education/uncovering-the-traumatic-history-of-one-native-american-boarding-school-in-the-midwest


https://www.slu.edu/news/2021/december/mary-bruemmer-obituary.php
creator: 8H86gZYSFIRHGy8q39OgBAfQFeC2

title: Lafayette Park
BodyText:
When walking through the wrought-iron gates that surround the 30-acre park in the middle of Lafayette Square, it’s like transporting into another area of the world. Surrounding the park is classic St. Louis three-story homes and bustling traffic, but inside the park is a green oasis complete with a lake, statues, and a lot of history. The history of the park is exemplified in the statues of historical figures that regally stand on pedestals and in the aged structures scattered all around. The main building in the park is an old-looking brick building that used to be a police station for Lafayette Square but is used as a visitor’s center today. Next to the building is the Lafayette Park Lake, where even on a rainy day remains a hub for people and birds alike. Sitting on a mossy bench in front of the lake, I can hear the sounds of the fountain spewing straight into the air and splashing down into the water, the hum of the generator at the visitor center, and the sound of children laughing at the play area. All over the park, people walk their dogs on the concrete paths, a man plays catch with his two young sons, and a woman begins to feed the birds around the lake, seemingly a daily tradition for her. No matter the weather or the day, Lafayette Park attracts many different communities for its calming environment in the middle of the bustling city.


Are the park’s visitors mostly attracted to it because of the location or the environment of the park?

How many more visitors are there on a sunny weekend day?

Are there any events in the park that cause people to attend regularly, keeping up with traditions?

Is the lake the part of the park that is most attractive to visitors? Or is it a different portion of the park?

  • The sounds of the fountain spewing straight into the air and splashing into the lake below it are the loudest noises within hearing distance

  • Next is the hum of a generator on the building next to the lake

  • Every few moments, the geese in the grass surrounding the lake start to squawk

  • The rain has just lightened up, but it is still drizzling, so the rain creates tiny ripples all over the pond

  • The geese, ducks, and swans don’t seem to mind the rain -- all of them are out in the open, not hidden under trees

  • They seem to have taken over the pond area -- there are no humans near the pond, only the birds

  • The pond is in the middle of the park and surrounding it is the Park House, sculptures, and a play park

  • Surrounding those is many different areas of green space -- some fields, some secluded

  • According to their website, https://lafayettesquare.org/visit/lafayette-park/, the park was dedicated in 1851 as the first public park in the city of St. Louis

  • It is considered to be the oldest public park west of the Mississippi 

  • The Park House used to be used as a police station for Lafayette Square, but is now used as the Parks and Recreation office

  • The website also has a self-guided walking tour to print out and follow so that people can understand the history of each monument in the park

  • Surrounding the entire park is tall, three-story, classic St. Louis homes. They are all so colorful and exemplify the vivaciousness of the city that lies just outside the greenery of the Park

  • I’m sitting on a bench just beyond the sidewalk of the pond -- on the rainy day, the wooden bench is soggy and the green moss spreading all over it seems to be really bright against the gloomy colors of the day

  • The bench has a dedication on it with a metal plaque below it

  • Even with the rainy weather, the park still seems to be busy -- there is a father playing catch with his two young songs in a field nearby, people walk their dogs on the cement sidewalks, and people still sit on benches by the pond

  • This place seems to be a hub for people around it, even when the weather is bad

  • Immediately upon walking in the wrought-iron gates of the park, it felt like entering a calming natural environment in the middle of a bustling city

  • The trees covering the sky above the park and the sounds of birds and water rushing make it feel like an enclosed nature park, when it’s actually some greenery in the middle of St. Louis city

  • There are two statues within my view

  • One is a statue of George Washington erected in 1869

  • The other statue, which was the first one I saw upon walking into the park is of Thomas Hart Benton. His statue has around 10 concrete steps leading up to it. The base of the statue is surrounded by a concrete walkway and appears to stand on a pedestal to the rest of the Park

  • The statue was dedicated in 1868 by the first professional female sculptor, Harriet Goodhue Hosmer, according to https://www.stlouis-mo.gov/parks/parks/browse-parks/view-park.cfm?parkID=52&parkName=Lafayette%20Park&amenitySubTypeID=27 

  • A woman walked down the cement path by the Park House and walked right up to the birds on the grassy area around the pond

  • It’s like they recognize her, they all start crowding near the fence before she even makes it to them

  • When she reaches the fence, she starts to greet them with a baby voice like they’re her pets

  • She begins to pull out a bag of food from her purse and throw some all around the group of birds, making sure each gets some

  • Seeing that woman, obviously very happy to see her ducks and geese, along with the father playing catch with his sons in the field behind her just shows how Lafayette Park is a place for all different communities to gather, no matter the weather
creator: m5zMmy4slFNMTuX7a4kn6hIFumX2

title: More Than Coffee
BodyText:
The first sounds you hear at the More Than Coffee stand are the rushing cars down Manchester Avenue and the Christian music coming out from the stand’s speakers as the friendly workers wave at you as you’re walking up. While the stand resembles a traditional (yet miniaturized) coffee shop drive-thru, the experience is much more unique. One of the first things customers notice is a white sign next to the stand that reads “We train physically and/or mentally challenged adults for meaningful employment. TRAINING NOW.” 

It seems that the name “More Than Coffee” emphasizes a lot about their store’s message. Not only in the menu, as they try to stress that they have a food menu as well as coffee, but also in their purpose as a store. Their hope is to evangelize the Christian religion while also giving people, that traditionally struggle to find work, a meaningful job. 

Since the drive-thru window is actually a walk-up window, the workers are able to get more personal with the customers. After asking introductory questions, they take your order and asking you more about yourself as you wait. The managers begin talking about their workers’ accomplishments like they are proud parents. There is a donation box in front of the window that says “People helping people one cup at a time.” After giving you your order, they give you a loyalty card and ask that you come back soon so they can keep working the Christian mission.

While the busy sounds of traffic may not represent the devout peace that More Than Coffee is trying to bring St. Louis, they still somehow made it feel like a religious experience. The entire endeavor just solidifies the idea that there can be religion anywhere -- even in the middle of a strip mall parking lot. 

What is the hiring process like?

Who owns the stand? Why did they think this was an important mission to bring to St. Louis?

How many people normally work the stand? Are they always trained to make the experience personal for customers?


  • The first noises heard are the sounds of traffic rushing down Manchester Avenue and the Christian music playing from the shop’s speakers

  • Upon walking up, there were already workers waving to me and saying “Hi!”

  • The shop is in the middle of a strip mall with an Asian Market and a small clothing store

  • It more resembles a stand than a shop, because it is a tiny building in the middle of a parking lot 

  • Instead of a drive thru window like most chain coffee shops, it has a walk up window, making connection and conversation between the customer and the workers more likely

  • One of the first things you notice about the stand is the big “More Than Coffee” sign with a cross instead of a ‘T’ on the ‘Than’ 

  • Next, your eye is drawn to a big white sign standing next to the shop that reads “We train physically and/or mentally challenged adults. For meaningful employment. TRAINING NOW.”

  • When I first started ordering, I noticed there were more workers in the little stand than I expected -- around seven workers were inside. Three of which were at the window taking my order

  • The workers were incredibly nice and very eager to make conversation, they immediately asked my name

  • When I did place my order, another, older man with crutches walked over and started to ask my about myself -- where I went to school, what I was studying, what kind of journalism I hoped to write, etc.

  • One thing I picked up immediately is that the management is incredibly proud of their workers. The older man speaking to me talked about one of their mentally challenged workers, who used to be a cashier at the stand but started his own successful granola business and asked me to check out his website

  • Plastered all over the stand are small wooden crosses

  • Spray painted on the cement walkway is “We Cater” with a cross for the ‘t’ again

  • Their menu is displayed as a traditional drive thru menu, but smaller, just like their stand is

  • One older blonde woman was running around the inside, checking everything that the workers did. She seemed to be the manager

  • She rang up my order and gave me a loyalty card after giving me my receipt

  • It seems that the name “More Than Coffee” emphasizes a lot about their store’s message. Not only in the menu, as they try to stress that they have a food menu as well as coffee, but also in their purpose as a store. Their hope is to evangelize the Christian religion while also giving people that might struggle to find work, a meaningful job

  • In my view, this shop is truly working the Christian mission. While some stores might identify with religious morals, this shop is truly exemplifying them by giving those outcasted by society a place to work and live normal lives

  • Inside the shop, their was homemade artwork by some of the workers, it seemed, with crosses drawn with markers and papers that read “I love Jesus” in different forms

  • One of the workers even had a lanyard around his neck that said “I heart Jesus”

  • It seems that even the workers share this Christian belief that the store has

  • Upon leaving, all the workers had big smiles and said goodbye, some even remembered my name

  • The manager said goodbye as well, and told me to come back again soon 

  • The entire experience just solidified the idea in my mind that there can be religion anywhere -- even in the middle of a strip mall parking lot

Video 1
creator: m5zMmy4slFNMTuX7a4kn6hIFumX2

title: Saint Louis Zoo
BodyText:
At the front of the Zoo, most of the people walking in pass by the map stand, already knowing their way around the park. There is an excitement in the air as people decide which animals they want to see first. Different conversations fill the air, overlapping and becoming indistinguishable. People’s sandals slap on the pavement as they seek a shady spot for a rest from the hot summer day. Some of the children have blue mouths from the slushees they begged their parents for. Since many of the visitors are St. Louis residents, it isn’t their first trip to the Zoo, not even their first trip of the summer. Many of them wear St. Louis sports gear as they pass by a sea lion statue at the front of the Park that also rocks a Blues jersey. 

Standing near the elephant enclosure, one of the most popular attractions of the Zoo, I watch as families round the corner and see a giant elephant standing right in front of the fence. Each person says “wow!” or “look at that!”, staring in awe of the beautiful creature in front of them. The elephant seems to be putting on a show for them, wagging her ears back and forth and shooting water into the air with her trunk. The air smells like animal poop and bugs fly around all over the area, but no one seems to care. All different kinds of visitors walk up to the enclosure, different races, sizes, ages, groups, squeezing together along the fence to see the animal. 

The St. Louis Zoo is one iconic landmark that is an integral part of the city’s vibrant and rich culture. Whether bonding through the shared fascination in animals, the city’s sports gear that they are wearing, or even just the excitement that the Zoo is free, the visitors represent the tight-knit culture of St. Louis’ population. 

What is the traditional social landscape of the Zoo?


How many times a year does the typical St. Louis family come to the Zoo?

Do residents of St. Louis consider the Zoo to be an integral part of the city’s culture?


Near the elephant enclosure

  • The most prominent sound is the water rushing down from the waterfall and splashing into the pond below

  • The next sound you hear is the high-pitched sound of children in awe of the animal in front of them

  • As soon as people round the corner and see the giant elephant right in front of the enclosure’s gate, they usually say “wow!” And “look at that!”

  • One child tries to yell “I love you!” To the elephant

  • The elephant seems to be drinking water and trying to cool herself down by picking up water with her trunk and splashing it all over her head

  • Her ears are wagging back and forth like she is happy

  • She is gray and covered in wrinkles

  • People are constantly posing for pictures in front of her and taking videos on their phones

  • Men with strollers stand at the back of the group while moms and babies walk to the front to get the best view

  • Children all around have blue lips from the slushees they drank

  • Many of the people passing by are all wearing matching shirts that say a camp’s name on them, teenagers in charge of the children try to keep the group together

  • Children misbehave and hang on the fence of the Enclosure, causing moms to yell at their children and apologize to everyone around them

  • Many strollers and wheelchairs pass through the walkway

  • The walkway is cement with all different kinds of animal tracks imprinted in them

  • One summer camp group in yellow shirts finally gets their turn to step to the front of the fence

  • Children are being held up to the fence all over, by grandparents, parents, and siblings

  • All different kinds of people walk past the Enclosure, different races, sizes, ages, groups

  • The sound of the zoo train passes by in the distance, the wheels spinning and screeching on the tracks and the alarm going off on the railroad gates

  • The smell of animal poop, hay, and grass fills the air

  • One man gets up on the rocks near the fence to get a better view away from all the people

  • Bugs fly onto people every couple of seconds, randomly people will start swatting the air

  • The area is mostly shady, with a few areas of sun peeking through the trees overhead, people sit on the rocks near me to catch a breather from the hot day and from walking around

Near the North entrance 

  • Children walking past cry in their strollers and in their parents arms while walking towards the exit, obviously exhausted from their zoo experience 

  • One woman makes her boyfriend stop at a stand nearby so they can get pineapples with drinks in them

  • A woman with her family stops off to the side and fixes her shoe so that they can keep walking around the zoo

  • A group of teenagers sitting at a picnic table nearby talks about how exhausted the sun makes them

  • A child runs past to see the train rush by

  • A man walks up to the snack stand and looks up at the menu

  • All different conversations pass by my earshot, making them all indistinguishable

  • A family walks up and asks to join my table, in need of shade and a place to rest

  • Almost everyone here seems like they’ve been to this zoo before, knowing their way around. No one stops at the stand to grab a map

  • A camp counselor nearby struggles to rangle her group of children

  • The sound of a man speaking into a microphone echoes near the area, evidently in the Sea Lion arena, indicating that there is a show in progress

  • the sound of sandals on the pavement is loud everywhere I walk

  • As I approach a booth that sells hamburgers and hotdogs, the smell of a barbecue fills the air

  • A child in a stroller near me begs his mom for a snow cone. When the mom repeatedly tells him no, he defeatedly says “snow cone”

  • Only having been to the zoo a few times myself, I am lost on where I go to exit and have to stop and look at the signs

  • The conductor for the zoo’s train yells out “All aboard!” 

  • The bell on the train rings as it starts to go on the tracks

  • All the picnic tables in the shade are taken as people try to escape the sun for a moment

  • A child cries near me because her parents said no to a toy

  • People gather around the statue of an elephant spitting water from its trunk

  • There’s a line of children and parents at the face painting stand as the painter draws Batman on a young boy’s face

  • Hundreds of summer camp kids are gathered near the entrance, a school bus parked at the entrance, waiting for them, the engine humming

title: Astoria Toy Shop- religious statues or toy figures?
BodyText: Rudy's is a hobby/toy store in Astoria Queens. They also sell Catholic statues. in context, the statues have a toy-like aesthetic to them. it begs the question- how do we know the difference between a religious statue and a toy figure? When is an object a toy? when is an object a statue to worship?
creator: d2v7JCxLlFT9jkQlvayOD4Z3HAL2

title: World's Fair Pavilion
BodyText:
As I walked up to the World’s Fair Pavilion, I could still hear the sounds of cars buzzing by and the presence of all the traffic near Forest Park. But when I walked inside, it was like stepping into a different world. The Pavilion felt much larger than it looked from the outside, as trees block the view of how long it actually is. It seemed like all the hectic noises got drowned out and all I could see was the green space and nature waiting for me on the other side of the Pavilion. The only noises I could hear were the Kerth Fountain on the hill below me, birds chirping overhead, and a few people around the area talking in the distance. People at the bottom of the hill kayak peacefully in a small lake and teenagers mess around in the fountain, splashing water on each other. The ambience of the Pavilion feels like an oasis from the bustling streets around it and it has a relaxing effect on its visitors. Whether it inspires religious reflection, or simply a few moments of mindfulness, it is a perfect calming destination for St. Louis residents looking to escape the city’s hecticness. 

Why do people normally come to the World’s Fair Pavilion?

As lots of people showed up to swim and walk through the Kerth Fountain, are they actually allowed to do this?

What is the typical race, class, and gender of the everyday Pavilion visitor?

  • The two loudest sounds at the Kerth Fountain on the bottom of the hill and people in the Pavilion talking

  •  When they talk, their voices echo a little in the high ceilings of the Pavilion 

  • It’s a man and a woman in exercise clothes, I believe the woman is his trainer and is instructing him on what to do with the PVC pipe in his hands for their next workout

  • A couple walks around the perimeter of the Pavilion, holding hands and talking. They are both wearing nice clothes and look like they’re on a date

  • Leaving my car and walking up to the Pavilion, it seemed much smaller, as trees were blocking my view of how long it actually is

  • As I walked up to it, I could still hear cars buzzing by and feel the presence of all the traffic near Forest Park. But when I stepped inside of the Pavilion, it seemed like that all got drowned out

  • Seeing all the green space and nature waiting for me on the other side of the Pavilion was like stepping into a different universe

  •  All the sudden, there were no noises of traffic or many people within sight. All I could see was how beautiful the area looked

  •  Birds pass by overhead and chirp, the air smells like fresh-cut grass and flowers, and the sun beats down on the pavement I’m standing on

  • Inside the Pavilion, it’s nice and shady with a cool breeze passing through, as the building acts as a wind tunnel

  • As I viewed out onto the hill below me from the Pavilion’s balcony, I saw a little lake with kayakers in bright orange kayaks paddling around

  • Bugs buzz from different directions all around me

  • Bikers pass by and ride up through the Pavilion, passing by the people exercising

  •  Lavender and tall grain plants line the outside of the Pavilion

  •  In the Kerth Fountain, a group of four teenagers jump into the fountain, water going up to their knees

  • One girl takes pictures of them as the three boys jump around, splashing in the water

  • The exercising duo have finished up their session and parted ways, walking towards the exit

  •  There are two large archways underneath the Pavilion on the left side that are gated up, they seem to lead to an area for event-goes to meet

  •  On the other side of the Pavilion is three large archways that lead out onto a ramp that goes all the way down the hill

  • The teenagers in the Fountain have stopped playing in the water and having started to look at the pictures that were taken

  • A child who saw the teenagers jump in has followed suit, squealing with excitement when he hopped in

  •  Nearby, an old sounding train horn just blew

  •  The roof of the inside of the Pavilion is wood slats that are the same orange color as the outside roof

  • On the balcony that looks over the hill, there is “St. Louis World’s Fair Pavilion Plaza” written in the cement blocks on the ground

  • There is a plaque that reads “Kerth Fountain, Restored 2004, From the family, friends, and colleagues of Alfred H. Kerth III” that you notice right before you see the fountain below

  •  On either side of the Pavilion, there are two tall towers that almost look like watch towers that stand above the rest of the roof

  • An airplane seems to be close to the ground because it loudly flies by above

  • On both sides of the entire Plaza there are rows of tall trees that make the area feel more secluded from the rest of the park

  •  As a nice breeze blows by again, the tall plants blow back and forth

  • The environment is incredibly peaceful and a great place for reflection

  • A lot of St. Louis history happened in this place and the environment feels that way

  •  It feels like an oasis from the bustling streets around it and the environment has an effect that makes you want to relax and be mindful

title: Serpents and Jackals in the UWS
BodyText: There was an SUV decorated with emerald, yellow and dark red crystal beads parked on W. 104th street in the upper west side Manhattan. it had two serpents and two jackals on the hood, and two jackals on its roof. It also had flowers inside the car and on the license plate. In Hindu, Buddhist and Jainist framework, the serpent Naga is a semidivine being, half human half cobra. The name Shiva in Hinduism means jackal. In other south Asian tradition, it represent the goddess Kali.
creator: d2v7JCxLlFT9jkQlvayOD4Z3HAL2

title: The Jewel Box
BodyText:
Walking up to the grand entrance of the Jewel Box, I was completely enticed by the beauty of my surroundings. The cement sidewalk led to two koi ponds that have bright-colored water lilies floating on the top. Next to one of the ponds stands a statue of St. Francis of Assisi, who is known for his love of nature. He stands powerfully in front of some trees, with his arms raised above his dominion. I walked up the staircase that leads up to the glass doors, and pulled it open to a new world. Inside, a blast of cold air hit me as I looked up at all the plants almost reaching the high ceiling. I saw a huge wall of greenery as I paid my $1 admission fee to a security guard at the front. Beyond that, there was a large open space with a runway-looking area. A black carpet stretched across the floor with white chairs surrounding it, looking like the room was set up for a wedding. The plants were along the side walls and two shorter walls of plants were on either side of the room. Hanging planters were attached to the ceiling, connected by thick metal chains. The room was almost entirely green, except for a few spots of pink flowers that brightened the setting. The ceiling is all glass, so the bright blue sky with white puffy clouds were pouring through, looking like it was painted on. The only sounds that the visitors could hear were the air conditioner, the security guard’s phone quietly playing a video, and the occasional sound of a traffic driving by. If it weren’t for those occasional reminders that it is in the city, it would feel like a tropical paradise. Whether the visitors are there to plan their wedding or just to see some greenery, the Jewel Box is the perfect place for a quiet moment of reflection in a beautiful setting.

All of the visitors that I saw come into the Jewel Box were young couples. What were the visitors mostly there for, event planning or just for a visit?

What is the Jewel Box mostly known for?

Does it drive many visitors to Forest Park, or do people come for other things and end up at the Jewel Box?

  • The only sounds I can hear are the sound of the video playing on the security guard’s phone and the air conditioning blasting

  • There are some noises of trucks driving past in the distance

  • It’s freezing in here, which I didn’t expect – I thought it would need to stay humid for the plants

  • The layout is also set up differently than I expected, it seems like it is set up for an event today

  • There is a sort of runway in the middle of the floor with a long black rug, with potted plants along the sides of it

  • It smells like a tropical destination in here and looks like it with tall palm trees on both sides of the room

  • An older couple walks in and pays the $1 admission fee, then slowly walks around the length of the building, looking at all the plants

  • They point to a few of them and talk about it

  • Once they arrive closer to the entrance, they take a seat in two of the twelve white chairs spread out across the room

  • They sit next to each other and stare up at the blue-sky peeking through the ceiling’s * The ceiling has four terraces that are layered along the edges of the glass, so that workers can get up there and maintain the spotlights

  • There are many hanging planters that are held up by some of the terraces, they stand completely still on their metal chains

  • As another couple walks in to see the beauty, you can hear the processing of the security guard’s machine

  • They stand near the entrance and look all around them, they seem to be taken aback by the beauty as they walk into the main area

  • Since the ceiling is all glass, the sky is completely visible through it. The blue-sky with white fluffy clouds almost looks painted on to the glass

  • All of the plants still have water droplets on them, showing that they just recently had their daily watering

  • Outside, the trees that surround the building are swaying back and forth a bit in the breeze

  • Nearby there are people using a leaf blower, a lawn mower, and a weed whacker, filling the air with those mechanical noises

  • It feels like a different location than the area that I entered, a much more tropical place

  • The atmosphere is much calmer inside these walls than the city environment outside

  • There is a balcony above the security guard’s stand that has two winding staircases on either side of it. Visitors can walk up them and see the view of the place in its entirety

  • Since the woman in the couple that just walked in has a scooter for what looks like a broken foot, the man she is with climbs up it and explains what it looks like

  • Since the air conditioning is on so high, some of the plants shake from the wind it’s creating

  • The couple seems to be planning an event here, possibly a wedding, as they stand at the front and explain what they want to do with the space

  • A new couple walks in, holding hands, looking at the beauty together

  • Most of the plants in here seem tropical and have a palm-look to them

  • While there is a lot of green, there are also some spots of pink in them, little pink flowers in the hanging planters, palms with a pink hue to them

  • A loud airplane passes by overhead and is completely visible because of the large side windows

  • The sound of a bus screeching to a halt comes closer and closer to the building, giving me a moment of realization that I’m still in the city, despite the peacefulness and quiet of the atmosphere

  • Outside, there stands a regal metal statue of a religious figure and an incredibly beautiful koi pond with bright lily pads floating in it

  • The entrance to the Jewel Box is very grand and extravagant, there is a concrete path to the front door that walks by the statue and the koi pond, then exposes you to the giant glory of the glass building in front of you

  • There doesn’t seem to be a crazy number of visitors in the middle of a random Thursday, but there is definitely more than I expected. So far, 100% of the visitors that I’ve seen have been Caucasian, middle to older aged heterosexual couples

title: Bethesda Thrift Shop
BodyText:
While the chaotic Manchester Avenue in Ballwin buzzes with rush hour traffic, a little shop in a strip mall right next to it feels like a welcoming home. Upon walking in, a little bell above the door dings and the friendly cashier greets everyone by name and asks about their family. This warm environment only continues throughout the store. The room is mostly quiet for a calm shopping atmosphere, but customers can still hear the sounds of the hangers scratching on the metal clothing racks as people look through the clothes and the sound of the 90s and early 2000s top hits playing on the speakers -- which the cashier sings along too. The customers are almost all elderly people looking for deals and most of them seem to be regulars, who chat with the workers about life updates. Since the thrift store has a Lutheran mission behind it, there are many decorative crosses, home decor with the word “faith” in it, and a lot of books and movies about Jesus. However, while there is a religious purpose that drives the store, it isn’t too overt for the customers. The only religious values that are completely obvious to Bethesda’s visitors are the kindness and welcoming nature that the store offers for its customers.

Are the visitors of Bethesda Thrift Shop mostly coming for the store itself or do they like to support its Lutheran roots?

Do the workers all follow the Lutheran denomination?

What does a typical day look like for Bethesda with its number and typical demographic of customers?

  • The loudest noises in the store that you notice as soon as you walk in is the music playing over the speakers and the sound of metal hangers scrapping the metal clothing racks while people look through the clothes

  • The music in the speakers is all 90’s and early 2000’s hits

  • A woman standing at the cash register in the middle of the store said hi and welcomed me to the store

  • There are a few groups around the store looking through the objects already

  • Every time a new person walks into the store, a bell above the door rings and the cashier greets them, she knows every person that has walked in so far and has greeted them by name

  • One worker in the back of the store is sorting through glassware, the sound of glass clinking together becomes louder every time she comes out from the back room

  • There seems to be four workers in the store -- three middle-aged females and one older male

  • The male worker is putting up a new flag outside the store while the female workers are at the register or sorting through products inside

  • Almost all of the customers are older, there’s only one middle-aged mom with her two young girls in the store that differ from that

  • Right when you walk in, you see the cashier at the counter in the middle of the room. On the left of that is the women’s clothing section and on the right is the men’s clothing section. Behind all of that are the kitchenware, glass, books, movies, furniture, toys, and pet section

  • There are four plaques on the wall scattered around the store that say the store’s mission and their background story

  • From the plaques I learned that it is a Lutheran thrift store

  • There is one man that walks in that grabs a cart and immediately begins filling it with old electronics, the cashier knows him by name and he seems to be a regular there

  • The woman at the register sings along loudly to the songs on the speaker. She seems to be very happy to work there

  • Another worker walks over to the register and talks with the cashier, they seem to be friends because they kindly ask about each other’s lives

  • As each person comes to check out, the cashier begins to have a lengthy conversation with them, asking them lots of questions about their day and what their plans are

  • As the middle-aged mom walks up to check out, the cashier tells her that she would look like Kate Middleton in the jumpsuit she’s buying, and then asks one of her daughters to look up a picture of Kate Middleton in her orange jumpsuit

  • The workers seem to be happy with their jobs and love socializing with the regular customers

  • I start to wonder if the Lutheran mission is something that is important for the workers to agree with

  • There are plenty of religious objects for sale around the store

  • A lot of home signs that say faith, books about Jesus, and even clothing that has religious sayings

  • Outside the store, Manchester is very busy and traffic is heavy

  • The store is in a strip mall with a butcher shop and is next to a strip mall with an old Hobby Lobby that is now abandoned and an Aldi’s

  • There aren’t many cars in the parking lot to any of the stores, but Bethesda’s is the busiest

  • The thrift store has two red neon signs on the front and the side of the store facing traffic that says “Bethesda Thrift Shop” in red neon letters
