title: Dashboard Guanyin Boddhisatva
BodyText: Guanyin Boddhisattva on dashboard at grocery store in St. Louis, Mo. Guanyin is the Chinese translation of the bodhisattva Avalokiteshvara. In Buddhism, Bodhisattvas are enlightened beings who defer their enlightenment to show the way for other beings. Guanyin's likeness invokes compassion and she is popularly understood to intercede on behalf of humans.
creator: 8H86gZYSFIRHGy8q39OgBAfQFeC2

title: St. Louis Art Museum
BodyText:
Walking up to the St. Louis Art Museum, the air smells like fresh-cut grass and flowers. The sun is still up over Forest Park and people look over the Museum’s balcony to see the beautiful view from Art Hill. The statue of the Apotheosis of St. Louis, or King Louis IX of France, sits on his horse regally above the people, sword drawn in the air. Pulling open the glass door to walk inside, the environment from the wide-open, bright Park outside, the ambience totally changes. The main room is much darker and has a much colder and less intimate atmosphere: people are scattered all over the giant room, conversations echo throughout the tall ceilings but are indistinguishable. Walking into one of the four hallways that connect to the main room, the environment feels much more warm and intimate. Spotlights on the artwork are the main source of lighting -- the gold, ornate frames shimmer underneath them. Each different room has a new mood to it, the paint color of the walls and the theme of the artwork playing a huge role in that. The wood floors creak all over the Museum as people slowly walk through each room, speaking with hushed voices. The type of people at the Museum is not very diverse, there are a lot of young to middle-aged couples coming for a date on a Friday night. A lot of the artwork has religious undertones to it or is overtly religious, especially with Christian messages. The Art Museum attracts people very interested in art, religious people looking for art similar to their beliefs, or people simply looking for a good time -- all groups find exactly what they are looking for at the St. Louis Art Museum.

What is the typical visitor of the St. Louis Art Museum like? What is their race? Class? Gender?

What is the typical motive to come to the museum? Because it is a St. Louis monument or for the artwork?

  • Outside the Museum, the sun was still out over Forest Park

  • The air smelled like cut grass and fresh air

  • The statue in front of the entrance seemed to tower over the entirety of the Park

  • Since the Museum is on a hill above the rest of Forest Park, your eyes tend to wander towards its extravagant entrance with huge columns

  • People gather at the statue outside, taking pictures and looking out to the Park

  • The statue is of the Apotheosis of St. Louis, or King Louis IX of France, which is the namesake of St. Louis. He sits regally on his horse, with his sword drawn up (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Apotheosis_of_St._Louis)

  • Walking up to the front doors, the steps seem intimidating and plentiful

  • Some of the stairs droop in the middle from all the people that have walked up them

  • There’s one advertisement that is stuck on the sidewalk before walking inside, showing all the movies that SLAM is presenting this summer

  • Pulling open the glass door to walk inside, the environment from the wide-open, bright Park outside, the ambience totally changes

  • The main room is much darker, and has a much colder and less intimate atmosphere

  • People are scattered all over the giant room, conversations echo throughout the tall ceilings but are indistinguishable 

  • There’s a table in the middle of the room in front of the stairs leading down, a black tablecloth on the table reads “SLAM: Underground”, meaning that there is a slam poetry reading tonight in a seminar room of the Museum

  • People turn and smile as I walk through the door

  • There are four hallways in each corner of the room, each leading to a different area of the Museum

  • Very open, tall ceilings

  • Hushed voices

  • Lots of diverse areas

  • Slow footsteps

  • Focal point artworks that draw your eye in

  • Large and small windows scattered all over 

  • Echoing halls

  • Varied lighting all over

  • Scattered people, gathering at certain pieces and wide open parts in another

  • There is one exhibit in the main room, it is my favorite of the entire Museum. It is a giant silver bookshelf with disheveled metal sheets poking out of it from all over. The plaque next to it states that it is God’s bookshelf and he stores all of his information about the universe in it

  • I walk down the front left hallway first, everyone enters under a huge cement archway

  • The paintings and sculptures are under bright spotlights, making your eyes move from one to the next throughout the room

  • The frames are all gold and detailed, shining underneath the spotlights

  • The lighting change completely changes the atmosphere to a more intimate, warm feeling along with the lower ceiling that makes the room feel incredibly smaller

  • The wood floors creak in some areas as visitors walk through

  • The type of people at the Museum is not very diverse, there are a lot of young to middle-aged couples coming for a date on a Friday night

  • Most of the couples hold hands and look at the same pieces together, but some seem to separate more and enjoy the experience on their own

  • As I step into another area of the Museum painted forest green, there is an incredibly detailed silver cross that seems to draw all of the attention

  • A spotlight shines on it and light is reflected into the room around it

  • People stop and look at it, taking pictures, talking about it in low tones

  • In another room, eyes are immediately drawn to the tall circular ceiling with ornate, gold paintings on it

  • Below that is a vase in a glass case in front of a huge window

  • The vase stands on a white pedestal and is the only art piece in the room, drawing in people for the dramaticness of it

  • A group of teenagers stand around, taking pictures from all angles of it

  • The window shows the road in front of the museum with cars buzzing passed, it seems like a stark contrast from the antique-look of the vase

  • The Native American and Ancient Egyptian parts of the Museum on the second floor seem even more intimate because they have no windows, dark walls, and minimal lighting

  • Each room seems to have a different mood to it, in levels of intimacy with the visitors, brightness, colors of the walls

  • In the room over, the slam poetry event is in full swing, people are chattering and clapping every few minutes and the person on the stage talks over a microphone

  • As I pass by it, security guards for the event standing out front smile at me

  • As I walk to the front door to leave, my sandals create an echoing slap on the marble floors

  • I walk through the glass doors and the sun is setting on Forest Park

  • People stand at the cement wall in front of the statue and stare at the beautiful sky

  • The Art Museum attracts people very interested in art or people simply looking for a good time -- both groups find exactly what they are looking for at the St. Louis Art Museum

title: Park Avenue Coffee
BodyText:
If you blink, you’ll miss the outside of Park Avenue Coffee. While looking for the entrance, I walked right past it. I soon realized and turned around, spotting the orange front door that seems to be camouflaged in the exterior of the building and the awning with a fading “Park Avenue Coffee” written on it. But, as soon as you open that orange door, you are met with the aroma of freshly made coffee and greeted by the friendly staff behind the counter. While you barely notice this tiny coffee shop from the street of Lafayette Square, it is technically a St. Louis landmark -- Park Avenue Coffee was voted “Best Gooey Butter Cake in St. Louis” by RiverFront Times and KSDK News. 

With the rain splattering on the red brick sidewalks outside, the yellow lighting and dark walls make the interior feel so cozy. Soft music plays over the speakers and customers quietly chatter to each other in their leather seats. There is a sign sitting on the sidewalk outside that says “Welcome, Neighbor” with a Park Avenue coffee cup and blueberry muffin on it. This really exemplifies the environment of the coffee shop; making you feel like a part of the Lafayette Square neighborhood. Sitting next to the window, I look out at the cute little boutiques along the street, and it really gives me a small town feel with the small businesses  and regular customers who are greeted by name -- even though we are still in the city. There is a tradition-like aspect to coming to a small coffee shop like Park Avenue. In the same way that people go to church every Sunday and socialize with their fellow members, the regulars from around the area come to the coffee shop and socialize with the workers and customers. 

In my opinion, Park Avenue Coffee deserves the ranking of “Best Gooey Butter Cake in St. Louis” -- and “Coziest Coffee Shop in St. Louis”, if that were a thing.


What percentage of their customers come to Park Avenue because of the location, not just because they like it the best?

What is the race, gender, sex, and class of the typical Park Avenue customer?

Does the other location near Tower Grove Park have the same small-town feel to it, or is it just because it’s in Lafayette Square?

  • If you blink, you’ll miss the outside of Park Avenue Coffee

  • I walked right past it when I was looking for it, and had to turn around and walk back

  • The awning has fading letters that say “Park Avenue Coffee” on it in white letters

  • The orange door seems to be camouflaged in the exterior of the building

  • But, as soon as you open that orange door, you are met with the aroma of freshly made coffee and greeted by the friendly staff behind the counter

  • This tiny coffee shop that you barely notice was voted “Best Gooey Butter Cake in St. Louis” by RiverFront Times and KSDK News

  • As a new customer walks in, the three women behind the counter greet him by name and ask about his new apartment

  • Two people sit next to the window and type on their laptops, sipping on coffee every few minutes

  • Business men in professional clothing walk in, presumably on their lunch break, and get some coffee

  • Two women who seemingly have come to the coffee shop to talk about work sit in two of the eight leather chairs in the room

  • Three hanging banners in the room say “Good people, good coffee, good gooey butter cake.”

  • Soft alternative music plays over the store’s speakers

  • The loudest noises that the customers can hear are the conversations going on in the store that echo throughout the room, the sound of people walking on the creaky wooden floors, the heavy door slamming shut, and the clank and whir of the baristas making coffee

  • The seating arrangement varies all over the room, there are two tables in the middle of the room, two in front of the window, eight leather chairs with tables between them, and a granite bar-type seating along one of the walls. Those seem to be used only when there are no available tables

  • Upon walking in, the first thing you see is the large counter where the baristas work with glass pastry containers sitting on top of it

  • When I ordered gooey butter cake, the barista asked “What kind?” I had never heard of different kinds of gooey butter cake, so I asked what options they had. She began listing almost ten different types that she seemed to have memorized. These included cookies and cream, cookie dough, and red velvet

  • After settling with traditional gooey butter cake (since it is the one most highly rated) and a cold brew, I sat down at a table and observed the environment

  • Two girls around my age walked right past the store like I did, circling back when they realized they passed the entrance

  • The store is located right in the middle of Lafayette Square, in a storefront with apartments on top of it

  • It has a small boutique on one side and a restaurant on the other

  • There is a sign sitting on the sidewalk outside that says “Welcome, Neighbor” with a Park Avenue coffee cup and blueberry muffin on it -- this really exemplifies the environment of the coffee shop, it makes you feel like a part of the Lafayette Square neighborhood 

  • There is a sign hanging on the wall by the door that states there is a patio in the back of the cafe, which seems very surprising as this is a small space, showing how a little hole in the wall place like this can be much more substantial than what meets the eye, which is a storefront that people don’t even notice

  • Outside, rain falls and splatters on the street and the red brick sidewalks

  • It feels cozy in here with the rain outside and the warm, yellow lighting inside

  • Sitting next to the window, it really gives a small town feel with the boutique storefronts and regular customers who are greeted by name, even though we are in the city still

  • Residents of Lafayette Square walk down the streets, some taking their dogs for a walk

  • In my opinion, it deserves the ranking of Best Gooey Butter Cake in St. Louis and Coziest Coffee Shop, if that were a thing

title: Laughing Bear Bakery
BodyText:
• Upon walking inside, the air smelled like desserts being baked and a humid mildew smell like from an old building

  • Walking past the kitchen, the workers wearing white aprons seem to be bustling around

  • Kalen McAlister greets us and welcomes us to sit down, she seems to be happy to have visitors at the bakery

  • While guiding us around the Centenary Methodist Church, she seems to be proud of the location and the people she’s surrounded with. It soon becomes very obvious why, as one woman who works for the church talks about her dog treat company that hires homeless people

  • While guiding us through meditation, her voice seemed to become much calmer and softer, showing a different side to us than the very friendly and bubbly Kalen she was outside the room

  • She seems to have a very strict belief system that I admire, including the ideas that: meditation is incredibly beneficial to life, the system is not kind to prisoners, and people deserve second chances

  • When discussing the reason for spending so much of her time helping prisoners have a second chance at life, she said that she’s seen the ways in which the prison system has failed 

  • It’s interesting that many religious organizations have funded the Bakery, as well. Organizations like Sisters of St. Joseph have honored Kalen and given her funds that were desperately needed to keep the Bakery running

  • It seems like her mission ties into religious messages about Jesus granting second chances and forgiving his followers, like from the bible, there is first John 1:9 “If we confess our sins, he is faithful and just to forgive us our sins and to cleanse us from all unrighteousness.”

  • While there is a religious undertone to the mission of the Laughing Bear Bakery, it doesn’t seem like that is Kalen’s main reason for continuing her work. She has seen many people come out of prison and then immediately return back because they didn’t have the funds or resources to maintain a life outside again

  • She stated that in her nearly 30 employees that she’s hired since the bakery opened, only 2 have gone back to prison

  • While Kalen asked that we do not question the employees about their past crimes, she didn’t seem to question this either. She believes it doesn’t matter what the crimes were, her only judgement of the employees begins the moment she meets them, their history before that is unimportant to her

  • The Laughing Bear Bakery seems to be the definition of an organization that works for the community and cares for the wellbeing of an underserved group
creator: m5zMmy4slFNMTuX7a4kn6hIFumX2

title: Tower Grove Park
BodyText:
Driving into Tower Grove Park, it feels like the greenery continues forever. The entirety of its 289-acre area is covered with beautiful natural plants and old, historic structures that make it feel like an oasis from the city around it. Birds chirp overhead, cars buzz by on the streets, and people walking or sitting on benches chatter. Each colorful gazebo in the park has picnic tables in it and a sign with its historical significance on it. One reads “Old Carriage House” and another has statues of different important figures surrounding it. One area that seems to be a hub in the park is the Fountain Pond and ruins. The ruins were created as a center-piece to the Pond from fragments of the Old Lindell House, another landmark to the area’s history. They stand regally on the side of the peaceful Pond for its visitors to enjoy.

In 1866, the park was donated by 66-year-old Henry Shaw, who declared that he would donate the land if it were to be “used as a park forever”. Today, Tower Grove Park serves 2.5 million children and adults annually of many different races, genders, and socio-economic backgrounds. The majority of the attendees coming to the park are nearby residents, of which 25% in the Park’s zip code live below the poverty level (TowerGrovePark.Org). The Park provides people of all different walks of life a common area to relax and enjoy a mindful moment in the middle of the chaotic city. Whether it be religious or not, Tower Grove Park offers a beautiful and historical setting for reflection. 


How many visitors does the Park typically get in a day? When is it busiest?

What purpose do most of the visitors have for coming to the Park?

What is the race, age, class, and sex of the typical visitor?


The Fountain Pond and Ruins

 

  • “Remains [of the Pond] were collected from the Old Lindell House to form the fountain stone and rockery, an artistic arrangement of stone blocks, which are the main focus of this landscape.” -TowerGrovePark.org

  • The loudest sounds that visitors can hear is the fountain water splashing into the pond below it, the sounds of airplanes flying overhead, cars buzzing by on the street, and the people around the pond chattering

  • There are birds chirping in the trees surrounding the water and bugs make buzzing noises

  • A group of guys in their 20s sit on a bench around the lake, talking and looking at the ducks that are all around

  • They get up and explore the ruins around the fountain

  • Two men in gray polos and khaki pants take photos of the fountain and all the wildlife around it

  • Ducks are crowding the ruins on one side, all sitting around, their brown feathers looking like brown spots in the bright green grass

  • As a woman and her dog run past the group of ducks, they all flap their wings and scatter, their bright orange legs becoming visible

  • The fountain looks antique and beautiful in the middle of the pond, parts of it are turning browner than others from where the water lands

  • There are three tiers to the fountain and a large spray of water coming out of the top, it rushes down the three tiers that get larger from the top to the bottom

  • After the tiers, the water sprays down the base of the fountain, that looks like a mix of all different kinds of shapes, all mashed together in the concrete

  • Although it is an odd fountain, it looks beautiful and fits in with the environment of the area

  • A man in a golf cart who works for the park zooms past, seemingly towing lawn supplies on a trailer behind him

  • A family with three young teenage daughters walks up to the fountain area and walks around the outside of it, taking in its beauty

  • Some areas of the sky are bright blue, peeking through the dark gray storm clouds that are getting closer above me

  • When the family gets closer to the group of ducks, they all squawk at them protectively

  • A mom and her two young sons with a huge German Shepherd walk up to the pond, the two boys throwing rocks in and playing with a stick three times their size

  • The mom seems to be taking her kids to play outside while she relaxes on a bench nearby, keeping a close eye on them

  • In the distance, a leaf blower and weed whacker loudly buzz

  • The mother starts taking candid action shots of her sons playing with the fountain

  • A new group of teenage boys walk up to meet their friends across the pond

  • The young kids play on top of the ruins, unaware of the huge history behind them

  • It seems like there are a lot of visitors for a random Tuesday afternoon

  • The ruins stand regally next to the fountain, browning on the tops from all the daily wear

  • In the middle ruin, there is a doorway that the visitors seem to be taking pictures in front of

  • A man runs past with his brightly spotted Dalmatian, grabbing the German Shepherd’s attention

  • As the rain starts to pour down, all the groups around the pond take cover under a large tree

  • The young boys yell as they run from the rain, their German Shepherd running after them

  • All the people are in close proximity to each other and look around and laugh at how soaked everyone is

  • Everyone begins to disperse and walk towards their cars

  • Although the park is giant, the moment felt very intimate. The pond feels the same way

title: Goodwill Religion
BodyText: Thrift stores often sell donated and discarded items that can be classified as “religion.” Some of these items, like the Buddha below, were originally marketed as household decor in a home goods store, or the woodcarvings of indigenous people in full ceremonial dress. The Bible verse coffee mug might have had a more intentionally devotional intention among its past (and perhaps future) users. Figurines, whether for holiday or year-long display, can fall into either of these categories (and others).
creator: 8H86gZYSFIRHGy8q39OgBAfQFeC2

title: Saint Louis University Clocktower
BodyText:
The sound of the fountain streams shooting into the air and the feeling of the mist splashing onto the surrounding area are senses that come from the most iconic SLU landmark -- the Clocktower. As tour groups pass, new students and parents stare up at the monument and for the first time and see the most popular part of SLU’s campus. Even when the school year is not in session, the Clocktower remains a hub for activity on campus: families, tour and camp groups, children, professionals and blue collar workers of the University pass by the famous fountain on their way to their destination. Passerbys reach out their hand into a stream of water to cool down in the hot day. Some students sit on the concrete steps and bask in the sunlight or do homework, others find a shady spot in the grass behind it. Wherever they find most comfortable, the soothing sounds of the Clocktower fountain is the sound that epitomizes SLU’s campus and culture.

How many people frequent the Clocktower steps in a day?

Besides in the winter, do the fountains ever get turned off?

Does the fountains being turned off affect the amount of people that come? Or is the location and the actual Clocktower the most appealing part to visitors?


  • Water from the fountain crashes down onto the pavement and splashes all the way over to the cement amphitheatre steps

  • The sun beats down from the sky, making the pavement incredibly hot

  • The fountains are the loudest noise within the nearby and surrounding area

  • Some of the fountain streams reach nearly 20 feet in the air, whereas others only reach around 3 feet

  • Sounds of nearby golf carts rumble closer, then grow distant again

  • A huge group of children in soccer uniforms walk by, the sounds of high pitched voices having conversations drowns out the fountain for a moment

  • An airplane cuts through the sky above

  • Tour groups for new students pass by, all admiring the monument that is the Clocktower as they pass by

  • Flags on top of Des Peres hall clap in the wind

  • The smaller fountain next to the cement steps constantly flows water into a pool at the bottom, the water being an odd shade of green

  • All different groups of people pass by: families, tour groups, camp groups, moms with toddler-age children, moms with college-age children, individuals in professional clothes that work for the University, individuals in t-shirts and shorts that work for the University

  • The air smells like flowers and chlorine

  • Bugs fly around constantly

  • Passerbys reach into the fountain as they walk past, touching the cool water as the sun beats down on them

  • Many sweaty people jog past

  • Students with study supplies walk past, possibly heading to the library or other peaceful spots on campus to get some work done

  • As a cool wind comes in, it seems like the people walking past breathe a sigh of relief with it

  • Young people on rentable scooters whiz by the fountain

  • It seems as if the Clocktower is a hub, everybody walks past it to get to their destination on campus

  • While students usually find the cement steps to be a good study/work/relaxation spot on campus, it seems that the 82 degree, sunshiney weather is confining them to the shady spots on the lawn in front of Chaifetz Business School

  • Another airplane zooms by, flying just above the Coronado to head to the St. Louis Airport

  • Some people sit in the benches nearby the Clocktower, still trying to be close to the central hub, but in the cool shade that surrounds it

  • Water from the fountain beside the cement steps reflects the sunlight off of it onto the blue walls that surround it, creating lines of light that wiggle and move on it, like the reflection off of a pool

  • The Clocktower is a rectangular structure with a round clock near the top of it, with a green triangular point at the very top

  • Surrounding its base is a cement circle that holds colorful flowers inside of it

  • Around that is a circle of fountains that shoot lines of water into the air, that eventually fall back down into the grates below it

  • There are four sidewalks that lead into the Clocktower area from other areas of campus

  • On one side of the Clocktower is cement amphitheater-type steps where students usually sit

  • In the middle of those steps is a blue fountain where water falls down a series of steps into the pool at the bottom

  • There are two sculptures of people sitting on the surrounding cement area

title: All Star Tattoo
BodyText:
Tattoos are deeply personal, deeply meaningful rituals. Or not. They can also be vanity impulses that we regret as soon as the sun rises. Walking into the All Star Tattoo shop in Maplewood, Mo., on a gray Saturday afternoon in February 2024, I would probably split the difference in my own decision-making process. This is not my first tattoo. In fact, it is one I've been saving to mark a milestone in my life. But I wasn't expecting to be here today. Sometimes you can see milestones from, well, miles away. Other times they mark their own time. 


Alyssa Maldonado-Estrada writes about tattooing among Catholic men in the Bronx as a kind of pageantry of masculinity. The sample artworks covering nearly every inch of wall space when you walk into All Star, like many commercial tattoo parlors in the US, display predominately female forms among the figurative designs. Bare breasts and flappers in the American traditional style. Kimono clad "Japanese" and indigenous American women in painted faces look out as you wait for your artist from the bar stools and leather couch arranged inside the garage door that would be open to the streetscape on a warmer day. But of the dozen or so people waiting for their turn to take a chair, only 3 seem to present as male. Women's bodies are on display both as artworks and as canvases. 


 /





Looking over the souls waiting for their turn with the needle and ink is the Infant Jesus of Prague, holding the world in one hand and blessing humanity with the other.
creator: 8H86gZYSFIRHGy8q39OgBAfQFeC2

title: My notes
BodyText:
And I can modify text, too.

I can type notes directly into this field. 

I can underline for emphasis by toggling the button above or by using keyboard commands. Same with italics.

When I want to quote a source, I can emphasize it by using the quote button above:

Here is my quote!
I can use the tab function on my keyboard or I can use the functions above to change the paragraph positions.


 

I can add a camera shot directly into the text flow (note that the picture will load above my current text position.)

Or I can add photos from my device library:


 


Thanks for looking at my camera roll, lol. 

I can add video:


But it looks like right now the video isn't loading into the note flow! We'll change that ASAP.

And if I want to list items or make notes for myself, I can use the bullet point function.
  • think about time and place
  • think about what I am feeling at this site
  • consider the five senses, not just my own
  • xyzzy
And then I can go back and edit here or on the desktop app. 


If l have a stylus and want to handwrite notes, I can do that, too. 

And when I want to add multimedia, I can do that in different ways.

Time and Place

I add time and place using the functions on the main tool bar at the top of the screen. I can also adjust time and place if I'm updating notes later from a different location. 

Tags

Right now, tags are entered at the full discretion of the researcher/user. This is to allow the broadest latitutde to researchers to classify and position their research. But we encourage users to use a combination of specific and general tags so your entries can connect with others that are published to the global map.

Publishing

When I'm ready to publish my note, I just click the arrow at the top of the screen. Before I do that, though, I'm going to check my own notes and posts.

title: Test Case/Demo
BodyText:
Here is a quick(ish) tutorial for how to use the Where's Religion? mobile app.

I'm using a tablet for this demo but it is also very similar on your phone or other mobile devices. The desktop app has additional functionality and we will demo that later!

For starters, you've noticed that I can type directly into the Field Note using my device's keyboard. If I was on my phone, you'd see the on-screen keyboard. Like this: See. I can type here using the touch pad. But since my tablet has a Bluetooth keyboard, I'm using that for this entry.


I can also use my stylus if I want to write into this field. But my handwriting is pretty terrible so I will spare you this method. (Oh, I can also drop in emojis if I wanted, but the verdict is out on how to use those in academic prose :) 🤗.


Here are some functions you will find useful.


For starters, I can just type as I need to in order to process my environment. But when I'm ready, there are a number of text editing functions that can come in handy.


Text Functions


For instance, I've just used both the bold and the underline functions. You can add these with the toggles above or by using standard keyboard commands.


Same with italic. 


When I want to quote a source directly, I can make that text stand apart using the quote function:


Here is my quote! (make sure to cite sources lol)

And if I want to list observations, citations, ideas for interpretation, or other elements of ethnographic writing, I can create a bulleted list using that function:


  • think about sound and smell as well as what I see

  • what is my mood right now and is it affecting my observations?

  • what do i know about the history of this place and where can I find more reliable information to better contextualize my note?

Multimedia Functions


What sets Where's Religion? apart from other broadly available tools is that it prioritizes multi-sensory descriptions and analyses of religion in place. We have a crackerjack team of research computing specialists, developers, programmers, and coders who have built this customized interface and brilliant API frame to collect not just words--our words as researchers--but multimedia as well.


Photos


When I want to add photos, I click the image icon above. Notice how the photo entered the Field Note where my cursor was located instead of just loading to the image bar at the top of the page. This is designed so we can keep images in the flow of our notes and analyses. Images aren't fluff they are data!


 


I can also load images from my mobile device if needed:


 


This photo is from a tattoo parlor where there was a lot of religious iconography on display. The image is added directly into the note flow here, too.


Video


k

Video files can also be captured with your device's camera or loaded from your device's library. Sorry about that. Lol. But you'll notice that the video option is embedded in the camera function. You may also have noticed that, at this time, video isn't inserted into the text flow. 


Audio


The audio function is located to the right of the image/video function on the tool bar. This material loads to the Note but isn't inserted into the text flow. So, as with video, it is important to reference, comment, cite, and unpack in the Note.

Audio file: Test audio for demo. 



Metadata


You may have noticed that this app is called Where's Religion? (If you hadn't, now you know! Ha.) This is in big part because we want to set aside the question of "what is religion" so we can focus attention on the time and place of the materials we encounter in our daily lives. Of course there is still some of the necessary interpretive work of classification that occurs in the act of recognition, but "where's religion" asks a different kind of interaction with material and sources than "what's religion." To achieve this, we have built the app to automatically collect geocoordinates and time stamps. But you can activate and edit them as needed. (For instance, you might NOT want to have a precise geocoordinate (also called a lat/long), especially if you are studying/identifying potentially sensitive or restricted or protected material, like people's front lawns or vulnerable populations). 


Location


Location information is gathered by clicking the pin drop icon above. If you do nothing, the app will record where you are when you enter your note the first time. You can enter in a manual lat/long or adjust the pin drop on the desktop application. A good rule of thumb, especially when you don't want to have precise geocoordinates attached to your note, is to wait on publishing until you've had a chance to review and edit in the desktop app.


Time


Time stamps are also automatically collected. But you can adjust them if needed. Say, for instance, you begin your note in the field but you update it or add multimedia files later on. You, as the researcher, determine how the time is recorded. Click the clock icon on the toolbar to open the time function. We strongly encourage every researcher to take good notes about time and to reflect that in your Note and analysis. Religion is never static.


Finishing up and Publishing!


Once I've created (see what I did there?! ethnography isn't just entering data, it's creating knowledge!) my Note and am satisfied with the materials, I have two options. Oops! I just realized I haven't titled my Note yet! Now that I'm done creating my Note (at least for now), I can exit back to my list of entries or I can publish to the global Where's Religion? map. If I don't publish, the Note automatically saves, so I don't have to worry about losing my work.


I can also create tags to connect my work with other Notes and to help other researchers and users find my own Notes. Click or tap the Tag icon on the tool bar. At this time, we encourage researchers/users to create tags that gesture to broad contexts as well as more specific iterations of religion that their Notes convey. The geocoordinates and time are already collected, so we encourage users to create tags that go beyond the purely descriptive. 


Now that my Note is finished and I've created tags, I'm ready to publish! I can alway edit again if needed, or if I want to add to the note at a later time.
creator: 8H86gZYSFIRHGy8q39OgBAfQFeC2

title: I cut my goatee
BodyText:
This mornig I cut my goatee. i have been wrestling with wether or not to do this. In the Nation of Islam, men are not allowed to have facial hair beyond a mustache. As i prepare to immerse myself in the world of the Nation over the next few days at their Saviour's Day, i decided to cut the goatee so as to not appear as an outsider, as much as possible at least. In shaving my facial hair I hope to blend in among men in the NOI, creating a more at ease process of immersion. We shall see how this goes.

A larger question for me emerges: What in fact does participant observation feel like? I wonder is there will in fact be a qualitative difference in the conversations that happen through the halls of the convention center. More here later.

title: Borromeo Log Church - Saint Charles
BodyText:
At first glance, this church just blended in with the rest of the vintage buildings on main street. It had the same brown hue and was located behind another cookie shop. Its size didn’t give away its identity either-the church was probably the size of an average master bedroom. Thick and choppy wood made up the exterior of the church and a rusty, boarded metal door was at the front alongside an old white, washed away wooden postbox that read “Information”. The right and left walls of the church had boarded up windows that resembled the metal gate and were locked as well. The rear end of the church had a rusty teal and reddish wheelbarrow that lay against the church wall. It faced bushes of dry, wheat-like weeds in the soil patches that encased the church. The air was crisp and clear and allowed for the bells of nearby churches to accent the appearance of this one, for no other indications besides a metal cross on the roof and a metal plaque on the front appeared to give this structure a church-like appearance. Moreover, the presence of people at this church was not to worship inside of it (they could not), but to treat it as a tourist site and simply document it through pictures.

  1. Does the interior space play a really important role in the religious significance of a church?
creator: h5IM6ZhPGxVEAdSpwywH4C1OZLB2

title: Dar ul Islam Mosque
BodyText:
The Dar ul Islam Mosque is considered the most popular in St. Louis for a reason. In its large and spacious glory, it sits in the heart of St. Louis and welcomes people of all ages (there is a day school for children here) and backgrounds. One can see fountains as they walk to the entrance and upon entering, one is met with a host of stalls for different community events. There is a great hustle and bustle of people both inside and outside. Everyone is following the basic rules for modest prayer dressing, but people still have their own style to it. The call for prayer can be heard from far away as the imam speaks into a small microphone in the men’s area. The sound echoes and people quickly begin to rush into their respective sides of the mosque-women and children upstairs, men downstairs. The women’s prayer area isn’t much different from that of the men. It is covered in a patterned green carpet with horizontal lines running parallel to each other for the purposes of providing an outline for how people should stand in prayer-side by side and in rows altogether. The second call for prayer comes about and this time, people stand up and arrange themselves tightly into these lines and silence ensues. Only the imam can be heard and as soon as the prayer is over, the same chatter commences almost immediately.

The mosque blended in with its surroundings because of how unconventionally “normal” it looked. It didn’t look like a mosque- it was a one and a half story house on the street. Situated right across vintage gun shops, this mosque was inconspicuous in its rock and tree-clad space. Construction cones lined the rocky and hilly entrance and were the only indicator of a new addition to this otherwise old street. Upon entering the mosque through a wooden “front door”, I was met with a sudden surge of chatter. A lot of people had congregated for the Friday sermon already and were waiting for the imam to begin. Makeshift prayer areas and the use of regular house space for religious activity showed that practice doesn’t require special spaces and objects for Muslims. Whether it was the scent of mud and grass, the constant pitter patter of feet against the foam floor covering, or even the sight of “Home Depot” logos on the floor as they sat in congregation, the Muslims’ practice continued just as it would in a large intricate mosque elsewhere.

  1. Although people of many backgrounds come here, most seem to be of South-Asian and Arabic origin. Does this change how people from other backgrounds feel when it comes to a feeling of communion? (does your background matter when you come together to pray?)

  2. Some mosques have strictly separate prayer areas for women that don’t allow them to see the men’s area. Does the view of the imam from the women’s area at Dar ul-Islam have any effect on the feelings of inclusion amongst women?

  3. Do Muslims feel different when they practice in a house as opposed to a mosque? Do they feel more relaxed as a result?

  4. What impact does the size of a community have? Friday prayers are usually performed in large groups. Does a smaller group size of people make this prayer feel less elaborate?

Date founded, and who, what, when, where, and why of the founding, including growth, challenges, and accomplishments (feel free to cut and paste from the website).


Welcome to Calvary Tabernacle, a community of Christian believers whom the Lord has blessed and multiplied tremendously over the years. Our journey started on October 19th 1991, when we had our first service in the Golden Room at the Coliseum Motor Inn in East Meadow. One year later, with only thirteen members, we purchased our first building at 78 N. Franklin.

Today, the Lord has added to the church people of 23 different nationalities and diverse educational background, He has enlarged our territories beyond our borders into an international realm, and blessed us with a spirit of excellence second to none. Our properties now include a Youth Center, A Kids Center, and a Worship Center.  We invite all to worship and fellowship with us in Hempstead where God will certainly enrich your lives.

title: Greek Orthodox Cathedral of St. Paul
BodyText:

Leaders

Reverend Elias Pappas

Nicole Rousakis

Mary Marcella

  • Office Staff

History

“The establishment of a community on Long Island was first nurtured on April 21, 1944 when sixteen people attended a meeting in Mineola, New York and formed an interim committee. On June 13, 1945, The Orthodox Greek Catholic Community of Nassau and Suffolk Counties, New York, Inc. was founded. Father George Papadeas was sent here by the Archdiocese to serve as its priest in 1950. A parcel of land was purchased on Greenwich Street in Hempstead, New York and the first Saint Paul's Church was erected. On December 23, 1950 services were conducted even though the building was not yet completed. On April 15, 1951, Archbishop Michael blessed the cornerstone of the new edifice and that evening the name of Saint Paul was voted upon to become the Patron Saint of the Church.


An influx of Greek Orthodox Christians to Long Island made it necessary to build a larger Church and Complex in order to meet the growing needs of the faithful. In 1955, the Cathedral property was purchased for $60,000. The ground breaking ceremony took place in the summer of 1957. His Eminence Archbishop Iakovos officiated in the laying of the cornerstone in 1959. On March 16, 1960, the icon of the "Lamenting Mother of God" was seen to tear in the home of Peter and Pagona Catsounis in Island Park. The Phenomenon attracted world wide attention and thousands from near and far came to witness and to venerate the icon. The Ecumenical Patriarchate proclaimed it to be a "Sign of Divine Providence". The icon is permanently enshrined in our Cathedral.

On May 1, 1960, Father Nicholas J. Magoulias (see "In Memory of Fr. Magoulis") was ordained to the priesthood in the new church. He served three years as an assistant. In 1963, he assumed the pastoral helm of the Community and officially retired in January 2006 after 46 years of dedicated service. On October 17, 1971, His Eminence, Archbishop Iakovos, consecrated the Church. The holy relics of the Christian Martyrs and Saints George, Tryfon, and Parthenios were interred in the Holy Alter Table. Father Joakim Valasiadis was assigned to the parish on this day and faithfully served our Community for 35 years.

In 1974, the mortgage of the Church was burned. In the same year a vast parcel of land was purchased contiguous to the parking lot which gives access to Hilton Avenue. Later, the corner house on Cathedral Avenue was bought and is presently being used as an educational building named in honor of Constantine and Carol Cassis. His Eminence officially proclaimed Saint Paul's Church as the Cathedral of Long Island on Palm Sunday, April 3, 1988. At this time Father Nicholas J. Magoulias was appointed Dean of the Cathedral and Father Joakim Valasiadis Ecclesiarch of the Archdiocese. The Parishioners were deeply honored and blessed with the historic visit of His All Holiness Dimitrios, Ecumenical Patriarch of Constantinople, and the Holy Synod on July 17, 1990. Evening Services were conducted and a reception and dinner was hosted by the Community.

Fr. Luke Melackrinos was assigned in 2003 to the Cathedral of St. Paul and elevated to proistamenos (pastor) in 2006. Fr. John Vlahos was assigned as assistant from 2006-2008. Fr. Andreas Vithoulkas served as assistant from 2008-2011. Fr. Panagiotis Zougras served as assistant from December 2011 though 2014.

In September 2017, Father Christopher Constantinides joined the Cathedral of St. Paul as its new proistamenos. He is assisted by Father Constantin Ursache, who has been with the Cathedral of St. Paul since 2015.”

Hofstra Religious Mapping Fieldwork Notes

Dr. Burlein

The most notable aspect of our visit was the physical space itself. Every inch of the temple (they reserve the word ‘church’ for the people) is covered in mosaics: on one side, Mary and her life story, on the other side that of St. Paul; behind the altar is the resurrection and in the dome is Jesus as sustainer of the world. There is a side altar for venerating three icons (two of Mary and one of St. Nicholas) which wept myrrh; the icons are removed and processed on special days. To the side there is a small chapel of St. Anastasia, who is associated with healing through potions and elixirs. This chapel also houses a number of relics, including two of its patron St. Paul.

 

There are two priests, for 750 families. Divine liturgy is said predominantly in English (about 80%), with the remainder in Greek. Roughly 500-600 people attend the Divine Liturgy on any given Sunday, after which there is a coffee hour. There are approximately 150 sacraments or life cycle events (births, marriages, and deaths) celebrated each year. 

 

Each Greek Orthodox community develops its own unique expression of service. At St. Paul’s, this takes the following forms: 1) a special liturgy for people with disabilities or illness; 2) Love Delivered, formed by the young adults who get together maybe four times a year to cook and freeze food, which is then delivered to people who are ill; 3) Midnight Run; and 4) volunteering with Mary Brennan INN soup kitchen.  While the website still lists a Cancer Support group and Homebound Ministries, those are currently inactive. 


During covid, there was some controversy around communion. In Orthodoxy, Communion the bread and wine are believed to become the Body and Blood of Christ; as the purest substance that there is, the belief was that the practice of receiving Communion would not transmit contagion. 


Andrew

Father Elias was very welcoming and was eager to engage in dialogue with the community about Orthodoxy. He encouraged us to ask questions. His explanations of the traditions of Greek Orthodox (such as the importance of the icons as windows to the divine) were very engaging and easy to understand. Father Elias expressed interest in reaching out to the surrounding community to engage in dialogue whether it is in an interfaith context, or any other.


Dr. Julie Byrne

Fr. Elias gave us a tour of the nave and side chapel of St. Anastasia, and then we sat in the nave for more conversation.  Memorable topics throughout the 1.5-hour convo included: 

  • the sanctuary is off-limits to all but priests and those assisting priests, the latter of whom can be lay women or men, who receive a blessing in order to enter; 

  • communion is limited to those baptized and chrismated in Orthodoxy, but there is a taking of unblessed elements at the end of the service for anyone who is a baptized Christian; 

  • miraculous icons and relics are a somewhat “normal” phenomenon in the Orthodox community, meaning quite common; the formerly weeping icons in a shrine to the right of the sanctuary attract people on a daily basis to come and sit quietly and pray, and the cathedral accommodates this by inviting people to ring the bell and they will be let in during business hours; 

  • the St. Paul community began in Astoria, then Hempstead, and has since then “seeded” about eight other Orthodox locations in the tristate area since its move to Cathedral Street; 

  • the organization of Orthodoxy worldwide, with the center of the US jurisdictions in Istanbul with Europe, North America and South America considered “foreign lands” per the ancient ecumenical councils; attempted continued modern fidelity to the ancient ecumenical councils; 

  • Orthodoxy is growing in the US but exhibits the usual “gap” in age participation of college-age people (for which Fr. Elias faulted “us priests” when they emphasize rules and regulations over a personal relationship with Christ); 

  • the spread of Orthodoxy worldwide, including in sub-Saharan Africa and New Zealand; evangelization takes the form of setting up missions in places where there is none nearby with a priest who just “does [their] thing” and slowly gathers a community; 

  • the story of Fr. Elias’s own path to the priesthood; discussion of the options for marriage for Orthodox priests and celibacy for bishops.

“The establishment of a community on Long Island was first nurtured on April 21, 1944 when sixteen people attended a meeting in Mineola, New York and formed an interim committee. On June 13, 1945, The Orthodox Greek Catholic Community of Nassau and Suffolk Counties, New York, Inc. was founded. Father George Papadeas was sent here by the Archdiocese to serve as its priest in 1950. A parcel of land was purchased on Greenwich Street in Hempstead, New York and the first Saint Paul's Church was erected. On December 23, 1950 services were conducted even though the building was not yet completed. On April 15, 1951, Archbishop Michael blessed the cornerstone of the new edifice and that evening the name of Saint Paul was voted upon to become the Patron Saint of the Church.


An influx of Greek Orthodox Christians to Long Island made it necessary to build a larger Church and Complex in order to meet the growing needs of the faithful. In 1955, the Cathedral property was purchased for $60,000. The ground breaking ceremony took place in the summer of 1957. His Eminence Archbishop Iakovos officiated in the laying of the cornerstone in 1959. On March 16, 1960, the icon of the "Lamenting Mother of God" was seen to tear in the home of Peter and Pagona Catsounis in Island Park. The Phenomenon attracted world wide attention and thousands from near and far came to witness and to venerate the icon. The Ecumenical Patriarchate proclaimed it to be a "Sign of Divine Providence". The icon is permanently enshrined in our Cathedral.

On May 1, 1960, Father Nicholas J. Magoulias (see "In Memory of Fr. Magoulis") was ordained to the priesthood in the new church. He served three years as an assistant. In 1963, he assumed the pastoral helm of the Community and officially retired in January 2006 after 46 years of dedicated service. On October 17, 1971, His Eminence, Archbishop Iakovos, consecrated the Church. The holy relics of the Christian Martyrs and Saints George, Tryfon, and Parthenios were interred in the Holy Alter Table. Father Joakim Valasiadis was assigned to the parish on this day and faithfully served our Community for 35 years.

In 1974, the mortgage of the Church was burned. In the same year a vast parcel of land was purchased contiguous to the parking lot which gives access to Hilton Avenue. Later, the corner house on Cathedral Avenue was bought and is presently being used as an educational building named in honor of Constantine and Carol Cassis. His Eminence officially proclaimed Saint Paul's Church as the Cathedral of Long Island on Palm Sunday, April 3, 1988. At this time Father Nicholas J. Magoulias was appointed Dean of the Cathedral and Father Joakim Valasiadis Ecclesiarch of the Archdiocese. The Parishioners were deeply honored and blessed with the historic visit of His All Holiness Dimitrios, Ecumenical Patriarch of Constantinople, and the Holy Synod on July 17, 1990. Evening Services were conducted and a reception and dinner was hosted by the Community.

Fr. Luke Melackrinos was assigned in 2003 to the Cathedral of St. Paul and elevated to proistamenos (pastor) in 2006. Fr. John Vlahos was assigned as assistant from 2006-2008. Fr. Andreas Vithoulkas served as assistant from 2008-2011. Fr. Panagiotis Zougras served as assistant from December 2011 though 2014.

In September 2017, Father Christopher Constantinides joined the Cathedral of St. Paul as its new proistamenos. He is assisted by Father Constantin Ursache, who has been with the Cathedral of St. Paul since 2015.”

Hofstra Religious Mapping Fieldwork Notes

Dr. Burlein

The most notable aspect of our visit was the physical space itself. Every inch of the temple (they reserve the word ‘church’ for the people) is covered in mosaics: on one side, Mary and her life story, on the other side that of St. Paul; behind the altar is the resurrection and in the dome is Jesus as sustainer of the world. There is a side altar for venerating three icons (two of Mary and one of St. Nicholas) which wept myrrh; the icons are removed and processed on special days. To the side there is a small chapel of St. Anastasia, who is associated with healing through potions and elixirs. This chapel also houses a number of relics, including two of its patron St. Paul.

 

There are two priests, for 750 families. Divine liturgy is said predominantly in English (about 80%), with the remainder in Greek. Roughly 500-600 people attend the Divine Liturgy on any given Sunday, after which there is a coffee hour. There are approximately 150 sacraments or life cycle events (births, marriages, and deaths) celebrated each year. 

 

Each Greek Orthodox community develops its own unique expression of service. At St. Paul’s, this takes the following forms: 1) a special liturgy for people with disabilities or illness; 2) Love Delivered, formed by the young adults who get together maybe four times a year to cook and freeze food, which is then delivered to people who are ill; 3) Midnight Run; and 4) volunteering with Mary Brennan INN soup kitchen.  While the website still lists a Cancer Support group and Homebound Ministries, those are currently inactive. 


During covid, there was some controversy around communion. In Orthodoxy, Communion the bread and wine are believed to become the Body and Blood of Christ; as the purest substance that there is, the belief was that the practice of receiving Communion would not transmit contagion. 


Andrew

Father Elias was very welcoming and was eager to engage in dialogue with the community about Orthodoxy. He encouraged us to ask questions. His explanations of the traditions of Greek Orthodox (such as the importance of the icons as windows to the divine) were very engaging and easy to understand. Father Elias expressed interest in reaching out to the surrounding community to engage in dialogue whether it is in an interfaith context, or any other.


Dr. Julie Byrne

Fr. Elias gave us a tour of the nave and side chapel of St. Anastasia, and then we sat in the nave for more conversation.  Memorable topics throughout the 1.5-hour convo included: 

  • the sanctuary is off-limits to all but priests and those assisting priests, the latter of whom can be lay women or men, who receive a blessing in order to enter; 

  • communion is limited to those baptized and chrismated in Orthodoxy, but there is a taking of unblessed elements at the end of the service for anyone who is a baptized Christian; 

  • miraculous icons and relics are a somewhat “normal” phenomenon in the Orthodox community, meaning quite common; the formerly weeping icons in a shrine to the right of the sanctuary attract people on a daily basis to come and sit quietly and pray, and the cathedral accommodates this by inviting people to ring the bell and they will be let in during business hours; 

  • the St. Paul community began in Astoria, then Hempstead, and has since then “seeded” about eight other Orthodox locations in the tristate area since its move to Cathedral Street; 

  • the organization of Orthodoxy worldwide, with the center of the US jurisdictions in Istanbul with Europe, North America and South America considered “foreign lands” per the ancient ecumenical councils; attempted continued modern fidelity to the ancient ecumenical councils; 

  • Orthodoxy is growing in the US but exhibits the usual “gap” in age participation of college-age people (for which Fr. Elias faulted “us priests” when they emphasize rules and regulations over a personal relationship with Christ); 

  • the spread of Orthodoxy worldwide, including in sub-Saharan Africa and New Zealand; evangelization takes the form of setting up missions in places where there is none nearby with a priest who just “does [their] thing” and slowly gathers a community; 

  • the story of Fr. Elias’s own path to the priesthood; discussion of the options for marriage for Orthodox priests and celibacy for bishops.

BodyText:

Events, Programs, Specialties

classes and one-on-ones based on spiritual health (intuition, spiritual power, healing, etc.)



Additional Notes 

This religious center is a business. They sell a variety of items for a variety of metaphysical needs. This includes: tarot and oracle cards, crystals, incense, figures of gods from pagan and asian religions, and more. 



Mapping Project Researcher Name: Andrew Sine, Abigail Anderson


Date submitted: 2/13/24




Hofstra Religious Mapping Team Field Work Notes



Andrew:

The shop on the outside looked cute. It reminded me of the typical East Coast downtown shop that people frequent. The class took place after their store closed so the shop was empty except for the teacher, cashier, and “students.” I was given a punch card and my first punch for coming to the class on time. The punch card works so that with every $20 purchase you get a stamp. With enough stamps you get $20 off your purchase.


There were two other people besides us in the class. They set up 8 chairs in the back of the store with Rev. Maria D’Andrea in front of them. We were the youngest people there.

Rev. D’Andrea was very welcoming and charismatic. She had a big sense of humor, and could explain things in very clear terms. She encouraged all of us to ask questions (even to interrupt her class to do so!). She gave us her business card and told us that if we had any more questions after the class to give her a call. 


The class was about ghosts and spirits. We learned about the field of ghostology. We did an exercise to feel our spirits which was very cool. Rev. D’Andrea told us some stories about her contact with ghosts. We learned that sometimes spirits get grounded to Earth and cannot pass on if they have unfinished business. The ghost of a speakeasy gangster killed in a shootout did not want to pass on because he thought he would go to hell! Rev. D’Andrea did make a point that if people do not believe in spirituality, ghosts, crystals, etc. then they should be left alone. Everyone is where they should be on their spiritual journeys.


Rev. Andrea will be coming back to A Time For Karma on March 7th for a workshop on Mystical Incense. Here is her website: https://www.mariadandrea.com/home


 I am usually more skeptical than not, but I decided to buy a Tiger’s Eye stone after the class. Rev. D’Andrea said that Tiger’s Eye repels bad energy back to the inflictor. While I’m not necessarily a believer, the crystal will not hurt. I also picked up a rose quartz bracelet for my girlfriend. When I went to check out the order came out to around $15. They gave me another stamp on my because they “round up” in regards to those. I was also given a free pumpkin spice incense stick. The shop was incredibly hospitable overall and I plan to come back on my own time.


Abigail:

The physical space is a small, maximalist boutique (even with hanging decorations resting just above customers’ heads at every turn). They sell a wide variety of religious/spiritual products including Christian, Buddhist, Hindu, various forms of pagan, crystals, totems, jewelry, herbs, candles, cards, and so on.


The class was very small–with only eight chairs in the back left corner– and it created a very personal atmosphere. There were two other people there attending the class, Rev. Maria D’Andrea, and a cashier present to supervise/sit-it. Our team of researchers were the youngest people present, and the other attendees seemed to know each other already. Despite this, everyone was very welcoming and excited for us to be there. 


The class was called Hauntings, Spirits, and Ghosts, and Rev. D’Andrea started by introducing herself and giving us her business card and an ‘about me’ form. Her whole life, she has always been very spiritually aware or psychic, and she has been sharing her experiences, teaching, and reading for people as her full-time job since she was sixteen. She was extremely charismatic, funny, and just a ray of sunshine; she created a very comforting atmosphere in which everyone seemed comfortable asking questions and having a conversation (not just a lecture).


The class itself, primarily an introduction to ghostology, was about an hour long, and then we had time to walk around the store and make purchases. The most notable part for me was when we were asked to stand and participate in an energy sensing exercise in which we learned how to sense the size of our personal energy field.


Dylan:

We attended a metaphysical/spiritual workshop at A Time for Karma. This is a store that caters towards its consumers' needs in both spiritual and interfaith approaches. They are open every day of the week from 11 am to 7 pm from Sunday to Thursday and until 8 pm on Friday and Saturday. Walking in, I noticed that the store was an amalgamation of items from different cultures that spanned across various time periods and regions. The owner of the store was very welcoming and directed us to the back of the store where the class would be taught. 


Aside from the four of us attending the class, there were only two other attendees. Reverend Maria D’Andrea, an interfaith, psychic medium, was teaching this class that was named Hauntings, Sprits, and Ghosts. She has worked in this field since she was 16 years old. During the course of the class, she explained that everyone has an intuition where they can connect with the metaphysical realm. We feel the presence of these beings, whether ghosts, spirits, or ancestors, through a feeling, temperature, sudden idea, etc. There are both positive and negative ghosts. She also explained that people can shackle their loved ones to earthly realm by prolonged grieving which prevents them from moving on. Reverend D’Andrea spoke against using the metaphysical for money making and her transparency when dealing with clients. For instance, she described that if a house has no negative energy present, she would tell her clients that a house cleansing is not necessary. I did appreciate her interfaith approach and appeal to people from all walks of life. 


This was my first exposure to spirituality in this way. I found the ideas presented interesting; however, I felt that the concept of psychic abilities, rituals, and contact with metaphysical beings were tools that helped people improve their quality of life. I was drawn to the back of the store because there were a lot of Hindu and Buddhist objects present there. I saw a lot of deities that I was familiar with that came from my own tradition. I was curious how people in that store interacted with them and incorporated them into their practices. There was an extensive variety of crystals and their purposes were labeled. Hanging above our heads were dream catchers, which Native Americans use as a form of protection. I also observed Norse deities. At the entrance were different types of incense and sage, which are also used in Native American practices. It made me think about the extent of cultural appropriation that may be present and if there was an awareness of where these items and practices stemmed from.


Liz:

Environment:

A Time for Karma is a spiritual one floor store that stores things like crystals and incense of all kinds. For someone who is spiritual and practices this is a great place to go. There was so much to look at in that store that it would be hard to get bored.


Greetings:

When we walked in, we went to the cashier and the woman at the cashier was very nice and she gave us loyalty cards, the kind that if you get enough punched out, you get a discount afterwards. But for the class we were all going to, the cost was $20 dollars per person. You got the sense that everyone was happy to be there. When we met Maria, she was very welcoming and smiley. There were only two other people there that day. They were two women who did not know each other, one was older and one was middle aged and they seemed like they were

interested in learning the content of the class. 


Class content:

The class was about Hauntings, Spirits and Ghosts. She started off by telling us about herself, she said she has done psychic readings and been a shaman since she was 16. She held her own show and she is still aired on a radio show. A crazy story she told us was about how detectives hired her to help in a case, and she was able to tell them where the criminals were and how many were involved because of her abilities. She knew a lot and the way she explained it in a logical way with some scientific elements to it so that a person like me who had no real prior knowledge could understand. We learned about energies, positive and negative energies. We learned about our souls and how they are always in and around us but can expand and contract, shown through a physical exercise where she had us stand up and to figure out where our souls are. She told us that our souls never disappear because energy never gets destroyed, the soul might leave our body but the soul will go elsewhere. We learned that some spirits are grounded on earth because they are unaware that they are dead or they have unfinished business they have to take care of on earth. These spirits also have some kind parameter on earth that they cannot leave. Some of these spirits she had contact with in her own house. However she did say that if a ghost does not want to leave earth, it cannot be forced to go, it has to decide on its own. She believed that what you put out into the world is what you will get back. A thing she especially emphasized was if someone is not a believer in spirits or ghosts or karma, it is best to leave them alone and let them believe what they want to believe because everyone is where they are supposed to be in life.


Conclusion:

This was a very educational experience, for someone who knows nothing about this I feel like I understand more now. Not only was there a lot of information but she presented in a way that we could remember by giving real life examples and using humor to keep our attention.

title: Hobbit's Hole Antiques
BodyText:
Video 1

The antique store popped out unlike other spots on Main Street. A large wooden sign, bags of mulch on a high mound of grass and dirt, an old green carriage with rose and the fuzzy sound of old tunes caught the attention of any passerby. Upon entering, I was met with clutter. Not the slightest bit unsightly, but all packed and tucked away into every nook and cranny of the small three-story house. The antiques were all old, though they weren’t all ancient. Some pieces such as Star Wars collectibles added a modern touch to what seemed to be an otherwise historic site. The creaky Maplewood flooring, the scent of mulch and stone, and the dust that covered most of these antiques made the place seem old, but a sudden change in the music added some life. 70s tunes turned into 21st century Bruno Mars’ jams after I heard a muffled male in the rooms at the back. Upon going closer, I noticed that it was just the radio playing. This spot clearly integrated the old with the new and showcased a passion for holding on the past and merging it with the present instead of failing to let go of old traditions.

  1. Are people regular shoppers at this house and have they religiously sought out to maintain collections of their own?

  2. What types of items sell the most?

title: Hindu Temple - Saint Louis
BodyText:
Intricate floor markings line every step from the grey rubber stairs at the entrance to the shiny black marble ones leading up to the glamorous deities at their pedestals. The air smelled crisp and clean owing to the wide-open build of the space. Sure, the space was all indoors, but the plethora of windows and the continuous off-white carpet gave it an air of vastness. “No cameras, videos, or phones” read a sign that led up to this main prayer hall. It was apparent why- halfway up the steps I heard continuous and rhythmic chanting that got louder as I made my way up. Men, women and little children all sang the same hymn in a South Indian Language. The arrhythmic clinging of bells here and there was the only thing that broke the consistency in the atmosphere. The feeling of the soft carpet under my bare feet reminded me of what a prayer space would feel like at home, and perhaps this is what the temple’s intent was. 

  • Does the presence of a largely South Indian crowd make the space and practice more different than that of the average temple? Would you extend this effect to the identities of your religious priests and staff as well?

  • Does the restriction on phone usage actually force people to concentrate on prayer or have you noticed that they seem to practice just fine without it?
