title: Saint Joseph Radio
BodyText:
Video 1

When we think of religion, we think of rituals, sacred spaces, holy persons, and even gatherings amongst religious communities. We essentially construct a vivid picture of a community. Often, we also look attribute the lack of communion to perhaps a lack of bonds between individuals. Of course, rushing to conclusions such as these skews and narrows down our view of community and religion. Religion need not be limited to traditional rituals and practices- this would make it unable to adapt to our progressing society. The use of radio is one such method that has made its way to the realm of religion in our present-day and age. Radio not only brings people together in the way traditional rituals do, but it also helps reach people farther away from a traditional grasp.

St. Joseph’s Radio in St Peter’s Missouri is one such organization that makes use of radio to spread the word of Catholicism. Upon entering, what you will find may seem like an ordinary gift shop, with neat stacks of books, CDs, artwork and other articles in one corner, along with a comfy wooden seating area with coffee in the main space. However, you simply cannot miss the rest of the space which contains radio recording rooms, microphones and other apparatus, beautiful photo walls clad with collages of visitors ranging from Hollywood stars to ordinary folk, and so on. Clearly, St. Joeseph’s radio brings out its identity as a radio broadcaster for the people of the Christian faith.

As modern as it may seem, however, St. Joseph's Radio has a long and rich history that began with the need to provide correct information about Catholicism and by using means accessible to most people at that time. Hence, the main source of media was, of course, the radio, and their mission was simple- provide the truth about Catholicism. This served as all the more important of a goal given that Catholicism was and still is misunderstood by many people, as is any religion for a matter of fact. 


Transcription of Interview:

Safa: Why a radio station?

Ann: we’re better described as a production company. We produce materials to put on radio and tv. We have our own tv channel with catholic media, Christian radio rather. You get it on the internet, with roku on your tv, and for the radio programs, we do live on Saturdays at 1200 with Covenant Radio. Covenant radio is the local catholic radio station and they have over 35 stations in the area, and we produce a program that goes on air on Saturdays at about 12 o clock. Sometimes we have prerecorded programs something that was probably applicable to the season or whatever in the past and that’s , when u see our work, our intention is to provide truthful commentary about our faith to the general public. In doing so ,we sometimes record local speakers to share that with the general public. And Lou Cortese, the director, is very good about analyzing which program would go good along with different areas. We have a studio in California , orange county, and we produce programs there as well as here. Sometimes we’re called upon to record programs from different areas like, we went to Pittsburgh last year, and this year, we’re going to New Orleans to record the international leaders conference for Magnifica Organization. So that’s kind of, that’s our intention, to help people understand what is true and about our faith, more about our faith so that they  can have hope in their life.

Safa: and Is there anything that made u choose radio over other means to communicate with people?

Ann: uhm, no its just we started 35 years ago, so that was, at that time, the best source of communication. It was before a lot of current things we use now. We use internet media and we now have grown to be able to do all of that actually, you can see with our website, and we have 247 livestreaming on the website. We also have with STAN tv, over 100 programs that are being watched in over 45 countries across the world. We got a response from somebody in Pakistan not too long ago saying that they really enjoyed the program and things like that. So, its encouraging, and rly we just want to make use of the things  that god provides for us, and we know a person that has a a great source of thinking and about this or that subject, and we’d like to share that with the world.

Safa: how has current media helped you further your message?

Ann: well, only because its current and popular. And a lot of people spend their eyes and ears glues either to the iphone or ipad, or a tv, and so we have all of that available.  We have our programming available on all of that media that we possibly can. We’re looking at a twitter page right now.

Safa: that’d be a good idea.

Ann: you think so?

Safa: yeah, because youngsters and most people are comfortable with messages that are shorter and to-the-point. 

Ann: yeah sure. I can relate to that. Because I get emails from people with these lengthy podcasts and I don’t have time to listen to all of that. But there is so much out there that is twisting the truth around s that people may be confused about many different things. So we’re grateful that we have the opportunity to put out the truth and anyone who knows our station knows that they’re gonna get the right information, so we’re grateful to be able to do that, and the current media helps, but its uh, we try to jump in wherever we can.

Safa: what would u say your focal audience is, with your programming?

Ann: the audience, we expect, well, we have children’s programs as well as ageless programs, you know for any age. For ex, we have a program on death and dying produced by this priest who experienced that in his life. he was given 3 months to live and he lived for 10 years after that, and he has the most remarkable way of describing death and dying in little stories. He tells little stories about experience he had, like if you stopped at an automobile accident and he tells the story of how that interaction went and ,uh, he tells a story of a gentlemen who learned how to pray to the Lord and he was at his bedside when he was bout to die, and he describes all of the interactions between he and the gentleman uh so, with these little stories, you get a better idea of death and dying , you know. He also speaks about the God that I love and the particular circumstances of children when they’re dying. And his name was Father Arkfeld. And he passed away because of his cancer but he left us all his wonderful material. Cant say I’ve heard anyone speak about a sensitive subject as well as he. So we have the truth about certain areas of life and death that a lot of people don’t hear, yet you hear a lot of twisted truth or personal opinions or people have a way of dismissing kind of the tough things of life and we don’t , we just rather stay with the truth. We feel that that is going to bring you the most peace in your life, and the fact that faith is a tremendous part of everyone’s life. We fell that everyone is created for the experience of faith and the” god that I love”, that’s one of father Arkfeld’s talks. He describes our relationship with god, so we have people that were converted to the faith. Like Roselyn moss, who is now sister Miriam, she converted from Hebrew to Catholicism. And the way she describes it is, you can’t help but be impressed, especially when she describes the Holy Eucharist. We believe as Catholics that the Eucharist is the body and blood of Christ as it is said in the Scripture, and yet a lot of people are apprehensive about believing that truth. So we are grateful to share the truth with anybody that’s listening. You know sometimes people will just be switching channels on the radio and they’ll back to us and say “oh I was skimming through the radio and I heard your talk” and they’re very grateful. So we don’t need to make it a point to talk down anybody else’s’ religion or thoughts because that’s besides the point. Everything is between you and God, so we do want to take the opportunity to go ahead and tell what we understand the truth is through the voices of whoever the Lord puts in our path.so that’s kind of a big issue with us and we’re grateful to be able to serve the world in that capacity.

Safa: when it comes to your interactions with people, what are popular things/topics that people like to know/talk about?

Ann: much of the conversations have to do with family crisis, you know, people that have gone astray or have gone into a pattern of not attending church anymore and do we have any ideas or suggestions, that’s one big issue. We have grandparents that are worried about their grandchildren, or husbands and wives with their marriage situation, um and so we’re, we have so many resources that can really help people understand what’s going on. Like today, I guess there’s always been a battle, I know we have bishop Herman, who speaks about spiritual warfare, and that’s a very common issue although a lot of people don’t realize that. I know that one time I personally had an opportunity to invite a seminarian to teach in a school, at junior high, and my wish that I gave him, I wanted him to describe to the junior high students the issue of spiritual warfare. There’s a battle out there., there’s people that want to drag you down and make you think there’s no god and there’s no hope and you just do what everyone else does without any consideration of its moral value. So this young man was very good at approaching that subject. I think he used this classes books, I think of Chesterton maybe, or cs Lewis, one classic book that referred to that, and so he did a very wonderful job. I feel like those kids, when they graduated form 8th grade, would have an idea of how to approach life, how to make choices with friends, and everything else. So once you realize there’s a battle going on, a lot of times people don’t understand it that there’s any battle going on, you know, “why would anyone want to convince me of anything”, and yet these same young people are open to hearing what the popular thing is to do and follow it, so we hope to interfere with that in a way by saying there are choices you can make, and there are good choices, better choices, and let them understand that life is about choosing. The lord welcomes everyone with his heart to live a life of faith and eventually upon death to be with him in heaven, but we do have to make choices to make that happen.

Safa: is it easier to talk to the youth rather than to an adult who can’t have his/her mind changed?

Ann: that’s a good point because there are adults that think they know everything, well there are also some young people that think they know everything , so you do have to approach it in a common sense pattern you have to demonstrate by examples and by real life interviews to show the difficulties that real life people ran into and how they overcame. So many instances, I was reading  about a child who was very sick , perhaps given few months to live  and the family was tremendously upset as you can imagine, but when they learned to turn themselves to the Lord and surrender their feelings and their thoughts to the faith that we have, then they turned to prayer, and prayer gave them peace. And in some instances the child can be heled or cured, and in some instances, he won’t be, so what the faith dimension gives you and answer that you can be peaceful with, and the answer would be perhaps the Lord understands that this life so far has been as productive as is going to be and/or that the child would be healed because there’s a lot more to be dine with his life or her life. And the Lord gives us every opportunity no matter what our circumstance is, but families often question why these things are allowed, “why is god not intervening “. They portray god as something that takes away all evil, not that he couldn’t , but he’s given us a free will, and a  free will is the one thing that demonstrates to god that we really love him, because we’ve made a choice there o the right thing, to do the best thing. In our ignorance sometimes, we do make the wrong choices, and we feel god is ready to forgive us if we ask for it, and so we ask him for his grace to lead us in the right direction. So a lot of the questions that we get are related to family issues or relationship issues with people.

Safa: how does coming here facilitate this conversation? How do the radio station and coffee shop come together?

Ann: well we have the coffee shop because different groups like to come in and we may have a speaker for them, like we have prayer groups come and they have their prayer group meetings here, and the environment, because we have the chapel , is a good environment for them. Its centrally located for many areas, they might have a prayer group or other kinds of meetings and its something that will hep them persevere. The prayer could meet at different location s, at church or be it somebody’s home, but this is kind of a neutral area and besides, we have so man sources of information and help that they might want to use with our tv, so that’s a good opening. We also like to have volunteers come in and offer their help with different projects. It could be related to the coffee ship or the gift shop, putting things together. We currently have a young man who is totally blind and disabled. He comes with his caregiver and they’re looking for work… and we have little jobs for them to do like count cards into packages of 50 or something, he could do that even if he’s blind. Different people come in and volunteer, whatever their talent or ability is, we need their help.

Safa: there’s always something for everyone.

Ann: yes, it's a very broad place of talent that can used.
creator: h5IM6ZhPGxVEAdSpwywH4C1OZLB2

title: St. Charles Antique Mall
BodyText:
The antique mall was really large. It had three main galleries, all on one level. As soon as you entered, you were met with a continuous and monotonous arrangement, row after row of old antiques. I tried to figure out if the arrangement had some sort of pattern to it. Maybe a certain aisle of rows was dedicated to artwork, the next one to radio, etc., but I couldn’t figure it out. Everything about the types of antiques and how they were displayed was quite random. For obvious reasons, I tried to look for hints of religion here. Perhaps old “Mary and Jesus” statues would catch my eye at some point. I eventually asked the staff at the front if and where I could find such pieces and they immediately directed me to three distinct gallery and aisle numbers- it was interesting to see how they did this so quickly all by memory; finding two to three articles in a space that contained thousands really shows that the people who work there are well-versed in knowledge of these objects. Not a lot of people were present at the time and they all looked around and left. No one bought anything and it seemed to me that the purpose of visiting was just recreational. Maybe there’s something about viewing rich history through objects that you can touch and feel that connects people to different parts of the past, perhaps even their own. At least that’s how I felt when I came across old action figures in the rear gallery.

  1. Is the purpose of visiting an antique mall more to look at things or do visitors often make purchases as well?

  2. Although St Louis has a variety of religions that it caters to, it is majority Protestant. How come most pieces here are more culturally instead of religiously inclined?

title: United Hebrew Congregation
BodyText:
Two large doors made way for what looked like a regular office setting- oak walls, sleek minimalist architecture, and the same soft white light that most fancy hotels make use of in their lobbies. Upon entering I heard absolutely nothing. The only way I knew where I needed to go was through a muffled voice at the foot of the door-the intercom buzzed and asked me for my name and why I visited. I then made my way to the main visitor’s office and met the owner of the gift shop, Ms. Iris. Jewish faith has a rich history, as she explained to me while giving me a tour of the empty synagogue. Most people only really visited on the day of Shabbat, which is something she wanted me to come to and experience. That is what I did three days later on a Friday evening (typical for Jewish Shabbat timing). Unlike the atmosphere during my initial walkthrough, the air this time was full of all kinds of sensory triggers. Besides the freezing cold air conditioning that the humid weather mandated that day, a warm and ambiguous scent wafted through the long hallway as I walked towards the open meeting hall. Furthermore, the loud and uneven sounds of chatter bounced back and forth through the big hall and became even clearer as I reached the hall. Around five to six officials stood at the foot of the hall, and the hall itself was full of food, people, and laughter.

 

Not too soon after I introduced myself to a group of people at the only table that wasn’t full, I headed into the main service room and witnessed a traditional Jewish service. The service was very custom and rule based in how the crowd responded to certain command words by the Rabbi at the end of certain verses or hymns, but that’s about where the formalities ended. The topics of sermons, the attitude and language of the Rabbi and Assistant Rabbi all had a casual vibe. At one point, the Rabbi was joking about Amazon.com. Needless to say, people at this Hebrew Congregation were much more of cultural relativists than those of their other sects, and this isn’t just an assumption but something they insisted on letting me know as soon as I walked in.

title: Laughing Bear Bakery
BodyText:
The entrance to this hidden bakery was the same one for the old Methodist Church that housed it-ridden with trespasser warnings and accessible only to those whom the church staff let in. The hot air summer air remained unchanged as we entered the aged building-the air conditioning had apparently stopped working weeks ago. That explained the loud, creaky, and rhythmic whirring sound that came from a space in front and to our left. As we got closer, the soft scent of baked goods wafted and sliced through the otherwise muddy and concrete-like stench. Two open doors served as the starting point of what was a large and empty hall. A podium all the way in the back once again reminded me that this wasn’t a stand-alone bakery and was indeed now a part of the church and its attendees. Nonetheless, no one was actually present on the space or amongst the three to four empty round tables and chairs except for the owner, Ms. Kalen, and two of her kitchen staff. From the surfaces of the tables to the old wood polishing across the room, everything had an air of ancient owing to the visible dust, sound of creaks, and simply an aged scent. 

We were shown around the meditation room, the old sanctuary of the church and finally, the bakery’s main kitchen. Compared to the church’s environment, the kitchen was very clean. The two employees, who were former inmates, were extremely focused, diligent, and so very enthusiastic about their work. The way they timed their baking, organized utensils, washed up surfaces, and cooked their goods to perfection showcased the passion these men had for what they were creating. As Ms. Kalen said, baking gave the bakers a place to exhibit their pride and creativity. The bakery as a whole also gave them a place to find others just like themselves along with an environment that, instead of putting them down, lifted them up and promised them a second chance.

Questions:

1.What makes Laughing Bear Bakery different from other bakeries such as the one you had mentioned on Cherokee Street?

2. Do you notice any differences between male and female bakers when it comes to rehabilitation at the workplace?

title: Contemporary Art Museum - St. Louis
BodyText:
Two large glass doors served as the entrance to this vast, wide, and gray space. The architecture inside was nothing more than a monotonous arrangement of contemporary art frames against gray and white walls. Everything was so basic yet inviting in its simplicity and fine detail. Though not empty, the museum was full of echoes of even the smallest sounds including the faint buzzing and whirring of it’s café’s only coffee maker. Only three to four exhibitions were on display, each of them in the same grey and white space with a sole painted wall text offering context to otherwise banal objects and arrangements. This was a contemporary art museum, so nothing less of an empty, geometric and minimalistic space was expected. Nonetheless, it managed to tell powerful stories thorough the very little that it used to portray them. The most intriguing story was that told by Lawrence Abu Hamdan’s exhibit in what was called the “Earwitness Theatre”. Part of the exhibit was a pitch-black room was the source of the continuous echo in the museum. Abu Hamdan spoke about the Syrian refugee story and used vivid screams and cries to portray the fear and angst amongst these communities. 

Even if this space is not explicitly religious, do religious people find themselves drawn to certain works of art/exhibits?

title: St Anne Lofts
BodyText: Owned by Cron Management, St. Anne Lofts is a self-described luxury apartment complex in downtown East Lansing, offering Studio, 1-Bedroom, 2-Bedroom, and a 4-Bedroom Penthouse. The construction of the building was steeped in controversy, some concerning safety issues, but most popularly about the architectural feature on the side of the building that resembles a large cross. The inclusion of this Christian symbol sparked discourse on whether or not it should be acceptable to display religious symbols in public, high-traffic areas.

title: Planned Parenthood
BodyText: I talked with two twenty something white men who were out front of the Planned Parenthood on Forest Avenue. I introduced myself as a PhD student conducting research for Saint Louis University and asked whether they worked for Planned Parenthood or another organization. They confirmed that they worked for a different organization, and emphasized that they were handing out literature for clinics nearby that offered free resources (such as pregnancy tests and certain kinds of women’s health check ups) that Planned Parenthood charged for. As we were talking a woman drove into the Planned Parenthood parking lot and the one who was currently “on duty” had a short conversation with her about the free services available to her and handed her a pamphlet. Shortly afterwards a car drove by and shouted “Fuck you” at us. I asked if it was common for them to receive abuse from people, and they said that the women entering the clinic were usually nice, but that it was common for people driving by to give them the middle finger or shout at them. At this point they distanced themselves from other organizations that demeaned or yelled at women seeking abortions. Their approach was one that sought to treat women well, though they did seek to steer them away from abortions. They confirmed that both of them were Christian, and doing this work out of Christian convictions (they said explicitly that they believe that life begins at conception), but said that they don’t discuss religion with the women and that the organization is not explicitly Christian. They both had worked for the organization for a little less than a year. The organization that they worked for is called “Women’s Care Connect.” Neither were associated with Saint Louis University, but both attended Catholic colleges. They also said that a part of what they do is counseling for women, giving them the options that they have during pregnancy, which are keeping the baby, giving the baby up for adoption, and (said with significantly more hesitation) abortion. I confirmed that none of the clinics that they refer women to offer abortions. The pamphlet I received from them counseled women on their rights, including giving a baby up for adoption up to 45 days after birth, and encouraged women to participate in Natural Family Planning, which the brochure touts as an “organic alternative to artificial birth-control.” The brochure also advertises abortion recovery groups, and abortion pill reversal.
creator: https://devstore.rerum.io/v1/id/660c2f6d5ba5492ddce3ebf1

They confirmed that both of them were Christian, and doing this work out of Christian convictions (they said explicitly that they believe that life begins at conception), but said that they don’t discuss religion with the women and that the organization is not explicitly Christian. They both had worked for the organization for a little less than a year. The organization that they worked for is called “Women’s Care Connect.” Neither were associated with Saint Louis University, but both attended Catholic colleges. They also said that a part of what they do is counseling for women, giving them the options that they have during pregnancy, which are keeping the baby, giving the baby up for adoption, and (said with significantly more hesitation) abortion. I confirmed that none of the clinics that they refer women to offer abortions. The pamphlet I received from them counseled women on their rights, including giving a baby up for adoption up to 45 days after birth, and encouraged women to participate in Natural Family Planning, which the brochure touts as an “organic alternative to artificial birth-control.” The brochure also advertises abortion recovery groups, and abortion pill reversal.

title: Tower Grove and Grand Blvd Business District
BodyText: On this day, my goal was just to take pictures of all of the boarded up windows and doors in the grand business district, regardless of whether there was anything interesting on them. Though, in fairness, I knew that some of the plywood had interesting artwork, and that’s why I was interested in the first place. The majority of the boards had some kind of decoration or writing on them. The especially elaborate designs seemed to be on places of business associated with something considered international or ethnic, such as Jay’s International Foods or King and I Thai restaurant. The day was especially hot, so there weren’t many people that I came into contact with, other than Krishna. The businesses seemed to be mostly open, with general precautions taken regarding mask wearing and at least an attempt at social distancing. One woman asked me why I was taking pictures and I explained that I was taking them for a research project at Saint Louis University.
