title: Second Presbyterian Church
BodyText:
Each Saturday morning, starting at 10 a.m. and going until each person has been served, Second Presbyterian Church operates the Good Ground Food Pantry to provide food to those who are food insecure in the surrounding area. Second Church currently works with several local organizations, and has partnered with Bethel Lutheran Church, to make this food pantry available each week - though the food pantry has been in operation in some form for more than 50 years. Guests who are making use of the pantry are asked to come only once a month so that there will be enough for everyone, though even if people come more often they are typically not turned away. 

This monthly cycle aids in one of the goals of the pantry, which is to build relationships with the people who come to get food from the pantry. Because the guests often come on the same Saturday each month and the volunteers typically volunteer for the pantry once a month, volunteers and guests get to know one another over time. Second Church wants to humanize those people who come to get food from them each month as much as possible, so it is important that they don’t merely hand someone a bag of food and show them the door. In my experience at the pantry, the majority of the guests coming to get food seemed to know one or more of the volunteers, and there seemed to be a genuine rapport between the two parties. 

Another way that guests are humanized is through the interview that is a part of each guest’s visit to the pantry. During this time the guest need not provide information beyond their name and family size, but they have the opportunity to request help getting services provided by other organizations - for example help obtaining a GED or housing. Additionally, during this interview process each guest has the opportunity to provide prayer requests to their interviewer, and those prayer requests are then recorded and made a part of the Sunday service the following day at Second Church. In this way the congregation stays connected to the pantry in some way, regardless of whether they volunteer for the pantry. 

The set up for the pantry is fairly simple. Each guest is only required to have a photo ID at the door, and they are then given a number - first come first served. While guests are waiting there is coffee and some kind of snack provided for them. Once their number is called they are given access to fresh greens if they are available from local gardens, and they then head into the interview. During the interview they can make a limited number of special requests - items that are generally available but not included in every bag - and after the interview they come by the kitchen to pick up their bag. At the kitchen they receive the standard food items, any special items they requested, and any other items that happen to available to guests that week. For example, the week I volunteered each guest was offered pancake mix, cheese dip, and some other snack items that Second Church had extra that week. 

The space where the pantry is held is clearly old, though in a building completed in 1896 this is perhaps to be expected. The majority of the seating where guests wait is old church pews, which gives the pantry the feeling of a religious service. Many of the aspects of the pantry are still conducted using older methods - for example the same fraying numbers are seemingly used each week, and special food requests are made on slips of paper that are then filed away - this conveys both a sense of stability about the pantry but also perhaps a hesitance to embrace change.

It seems clear, though, that the food pantry is an integral part of the DNA of Second Church. It’s members spend many hours during the week acquiring food and preparing the food in bags to make distribution easier on Saturday, and each week’s rotation of volunteers seems to be consistent. There are budget lines feeding into the pantry, and church members donate specifically to keep the pantry operating, in food, money, and time. Thus, it is likely that as long as there is a Second Church, it will be serving those in need of food security in their community.

This interview took place Thursday, August 1st, 2019, in the office of Travis B. Winckler, who is the pastor of Second Presbyterian Church. 

David (D): Yeah I think you’re doing alright, based on those standards. 

Travis (T): Does anyone want water, coffee? 

Jesse (J): I’m fine. 

D: Yeah I’m good. 

T: Okay. 

D: Um, yeah, did either of you have any questions before we get started? Like about the project or anything?

J:  No, I just hope I can be helpful to you, that’s all. 

D: Yeah. 

J: Okay, well let’s see where you go. 

D: Okay, great. So yeah, I think you read this, but if you want anything struck from the record either right now or if later you think back and say “I’d rather have not said that,” just let me know and I’ll get rid of that. And, yeah, would either of you prefer to remain anonymous for this or would you be okay with your name being used?

J: It’s okay with me

T: I’m okay. 

D: Okay, yeah, so could both of you then just say your name and then your role, or like how you see yourself being associated with Second? 

T: So I’m Travis B. Winckler and I am the pastor at Second Presbyterian Church. 

J: I’m Jesse C. Swanigan; I’m an elder at Second Presbyterian Church. 

D: Great, thank you. And then the first question that we kinda like to start off with, pretty open-ended, but how do you identify? What words come to mind when you think of your identity? 

J: I identify as African-American. 

D: Okay, and is that kinda the main thing that comes to mind? 

J: That is me. 

D: Okay, great. And Travis? 

T: I identify as a child of God, a servant, servant-leader, teacher, a recipient of an inheritance that comes to me from Africa and Mississippi and Chicago and also Germany, Russia, and rural South Dakota. And, I’m the son of a single mother named Kim. 

D: Great, thank you. 

J: Did you want more identity? Cause he gave quite a bit. (laughter) I thought you were just asking a direct question. 

D: Oh, I mean, like I said it’s open ended, so if that’s all that comes to mind that’s fine. 

T: I’m a preacher Jesse. (laughter)

D: Yeah, if you’d like to expand feel free. 

J: Well, I’m from a small town in southern Illinois called Cairo, Illinois. I am a single parent, okay, I came up through the years of segregation, attending a segregated school system, was able to get out of Cairo, Illinois and to pursue a higher education. 

D: Where was that at? 

J: I did my first two years of undergraduate work, well the first year I did undergraduate work was at Washington University, then I did two years of undergraduate work at University of Illinois, Champaign, came back to St. Louis and got my bachelors in business administration/accounting from Wash U, and then got an MBA from Saint Louis University in finance. 

D: Okay. 

J: And, for career wise, I was with Mcdonnell Douglas Boeing company, became Boeing company, for 35 years. And I worked my way up to being a corporate auditor, being the only African-American in the corporate office. And then when Mcdonnell and Boeing merged, some say took over, whatever, was when I decided to retire. And I retired from there and then I became an adjunct professor at the University of Missouri-St. Louis, with the title of adjunct professor senior lecturer in finance. And I was there for twenty years, and I retired from there a year ago. 

D: Wow, okay, that’s quite a resume. 

J: Yes (laughter)

D: Yeah, and just kinda a follow-up, cause you mentioned growing up through segregation and getting out of Cairo, Illinois

J: Cairo, the American pronunciation is KAIR-oh

D: Okay, thank you. How did that affect and shape your identity, and how do you see that still kind of playing itself out in your identity today? 

J: Well it played quite a big role in my identity because it was something that I had to live with. And, understanding that, shall we say, we got the second hand books, understanding that, shall we say, there was, segregation was all across the city, where you were expected to go to the back door, et cetera, the majority of people there, shall we say, lived on government assistance of some type, and even after I left there and when it became - when one of my classmates took on the role of trying to move into integration, there’s quite a few books written about the situation, but it got extremely bad. Just to give you one example, you had, first of all the public library, which was owned by the city, we could not use the library. We had a small library in our high school we used, okay, and, for instance, afterwards the swimming pool, when it was decreed (chuckles) that it be integrated, what the city of Cairo did was to fill it in with concrete. And it’s there today filled in with concrete. So yes, it affected my life, and it still affects my life, because, I think in terms about what happened there, I think in terms about what happened throughout, shall we say, the South in regard to lynchings and whatnot. And there’s no way you can push that in your background. 

D: Right, right. Certainly. Yeah, thank you for sharing. Um, okay, this is a Presbyterian Church, did both of you grow up Presbyterian or how did you come to be affiliated with Presbyterianism? 

T: Please go ahead. 

J: Okay, I come from a long line of Baptist ministers and I was supposed to become a Baptist minister. But as a teenager, there are certain things going on in the Baptist Church in a small town that I didn't, did not adhere to for instance you are not supposed to go to movies et cetera and all of that. So, I did what I had to do because my mother insisted that I had to go to church on Sundays. I had to go to Sunday school. I had to sing in the choir, lead soloist. I had to go to what was called the evening service and the training service. Okay, but once I got on my own then I dropped out of the Baptist Church. Okay, and when I came to St. Louis that first year, I joined the Baptist Church here, Westside Baptist Church, and I was a member there and I got turned off by that because one of the things that happens(ed), which really turned me off. A member died and that, that member was not up with her tithes. So, they ruled they could not have the funeral there. 

D: Oh, wow, okay. 

J: So that was when I left the Baptist Church completely and what happened was there was a small Church in Labadie and Marcus Presbyterian Church that had been closed by the Presbytery because of, shall we say, urban flight. The white members had left so consequently the Presbytery just decided to close the church. So it's closed for some time. Then the Presbyter decided, okay, we're going to see if we can get some of the white people that moved out to come back to the church and we're going to bring in a young African-American Pastor. So they brought in Reverand Gillespie and he had no members, the basement was flooded, there were birds flying around in the sanctuary et cetera, and he opened the church and I lived in the neighborhood and he knocked on the door, he went around from door to door, and my landlord went around the first Sunday and she said well, I like him and so the next Sunday I went around and he came back and I kept going and so I didn’t join and so he came by one day and he said, you know, he said got a bunch of high school students that's playing basketball in the basement and I want to organize them into a Sunday school class. He said, you know, I was looking at your background and you’ve had all this training and I’d like to ask you to do this. I said, but I'm not a member of your church. He said I didn't ask you to do that. I didn’t ask you that, I asked you to put together this class. So I put together that Sunday school class and taught that class for 20 years. Out of that class came now, there are grandkids and great grandkids coming out of that class.

 

D: Wow, that's really cool. 

J: And that's how I became a Presbyterian. And I was, so in other words, the church left there. I'd been there for 55 years. So I'm considered as one of the founders of the church, and through Reverend Gillespie. He wanted me to become more involved in all the judicatories of the church. So I became involved in the judicatories and so I've served on all levels of the church and I've traveled extensively about five foreign countries for the church et cetera and held a number of positions. 

T: And remind me Jesse under Reverend Gillespie's leadership the church grew to become, is it the largest African American church? 

J: The church grew to become the largest African-American Presbyterian Church in the United States. Yeah, we had close to 700 members. The second largest church was in New York and they started running close behind. A number of years ago Newsweek did a great article, I think it was Newsweek, did a great article on Cote Brilliante Presbyterian church because it was considered, shall we say, the middle class church.

D: Okay, great.

T: This is a treat for me because I just keep learning (laughter) keep asking him questions (laughter). I did not grow up Presbyterian per se but I grew up liking order and liking faith that could also work on a committee. So, I was baptized the United Church of Christ, kind of a sister denomination of the PC USA, and had a kind of millennial sojourn I guess you call this now, sort of millennial experience, of kind of a little bit of this little bit of that had a foray with Evangelical churches for a while had some faith formational experiences with nondenominational communities that were meeting in storefronts and living rooms and very informal settings. But for me, the power of those moments was that connection a sense of a living faith a sense that God cared about me and my pain and my hopes and a sense that there could be a community of folks who also cared and so the United Church of Christ’s stance toward being an open and affirming and welcoming community initially gave my single mom and myself a place to be. We experienced a hospitable community of faith and that got burrowed in me pretty early on.

D: Had she experienced rejection previously for being a single mother or ostracization of some kind? 

T: Yeah, so growing up in rural South Dakota, she was the, is the eldest of six kids from a farm family and when she went off, you know, and met an African-American, got pregnant out of wedlock. You can imagine that first phone call was pretty hard back home to her parents and wondering about what everyone's going to think in small town South Dakota and she shared with me that there were, you know, she spent the majority of her pregnancy alone without any kind of contact, meaningful support from her church or family. Now, you know when I came on the scene and she brought me home for the first time, you know, she said my grandmother took one look at me and said, okay, you know, we love him. Like he's you know, this is a person this is our grandson and so I never felt anything but embrace, you know and acceptance 

with some distinct caveats too, there were moments of, there's there's the difference, 

but I discovered Presbyterianism and Second Presbyterian Church through going to a presbyterian seminary. I went to Princeton seminary and it's one of the flagship seminaries of the Presbyterian Church USA and through a discernment and search and call process, here in St. Louis, and attending a gathering on race and reconciliation and reformation in the city this call to ministry came up, and I pursued it and through a lot of conversation and through reminding the PNC the search committee that I went to a Presbyterian Seminary, I love the book of order. I may be ordained in the United Church of Christ. But I like this polity and I am up for stewarding this legacy and learning, you know, as I go along as well. That's how I discovered this Presbyterian church and serving as its pastor. 

D: Great. 

J: Just for your information, the United Church of Christ and the Presbyterian Church. We have an agreement where pastors can move between because our polity is so similar. 

T: That's a great thing to add, the formula of agreement was the mechanism that we utilized to be able to make this work. 

D: Yeah. Yeah, that's good to know. Thank you. So moving to sort of the geography around here. What would, how do you describe the Central West End neighborhood here? And how do you think Second kind of fits into that neighborhood? Like what role does it play in that neighborhood? 

J: How much time (laughter) Well, I can start off by saying that Second is sort of strategically situated in regard to the westward movement of the population of St. Louis. Now, let me just back up just a little. Years ago we had what was called The Mill Creek Valley, have heard about that? Read about it. Mill Creek Valley. It was torn down in 1959... 1954. It was made up of the African-American community. Within the Mill Creek Valley there was our theaters, our hotels, our nightclubs, our restaurants etc. This was the African-American community and what the fathers of St. Louis society (decided) was that this was a blighted area here, and they felt, that they said it needed to be re-developed. Okay. So the whole thing was blighted and it was torn down in 1959. It cost about, lets see what it was, 110 million dollar bond issue and it cost ten million dollars to clear. So that's how much was put into, now to focus, to help you focus, to give you some parameters. On the east side if you’re looking East it'll be 20th Street. If you going north it would be Olive Street, if you're going west it would be Grand. If you are going south it would be the railroad track. This is the area where now you have 40/64, all that was torn out and redeveloped. Okay. Now Second Presbyterian was located, shall we say, in downtown St. Louis back in those days. Okay, then as we had what I call the westward movement and Second Presbyterian Church started moving West. Okay as the city of St. Louis, shall we say, continued, shall we say, being a segregated city it kept moving West. For instance when I first came to St. Louis in 1951 after, with the Mill Creek Valley being torn down these people had to go someplace. So what they did with the poor people were to build projects and they built, shall we say, Cochran for, Cochran Gardens in 1952. That was for the white people. They built Pruitt-Igoe. You probably heard of that 1954. They built Dorth Webb (?) up in 1956 and 1957. So with this, with these projects now, that's where they wanted the poor people to go. But the other people that were in Mill Creek Valley, they had to have some place to go also, so that's when we had this westward movement coming. So then of course in Second Church came, became part of the West End, which was a flourishing church made up of, shall we say, the millionaire crux/crooks (?) of St. Louis. In fact downstairs, there's a room where the chauffeurs would sit and wait while the service was going on and whatnot. The little thing out front I could can never remember the name of what they call that, that was where the carriages came up in there...


D: Oh the little drive-through space area? 

J: Yeah that's where the carriages came up and drop the people off because there were steps and everything that would lead you right into the sanctuary. 

D: I had wondered.

J: Yeah so this was this was really a, it was a prosperous area okay, but as the western, and this is my term, the westward movement happened as the poor people, the African-Americans start moving West when I came to St. Louis in 1951, Taylor Avenue, beyond, by that time you were considered, shall we say, a middle-class African-American if you were living up to Taylor Avenue in 1951, then it moved to Kingshighway, then it moved to Union, then it moved to Good Fellow and then it kept moving West and what has happened, the westward movement now with the white people is almost gotten to Kansas City. Okay, so then what happened, Second is sitting here in the middle of this, okay, and that was when in 1961 when they had to vote, to whether to stay or to move, and they voted to stay, so that meant that now that sitting here, you have a church here, a white prosperous church with millionaires that’s left in the middle of a changing community. So what are you going to do? So one of the things that Second started doing was to look at, shall we say, the community in which they were located and, what happened was, there were gay people in this area. Okay, and on Mcpherson 4562. I think it is Mcpherson, right at McPherson and Walter, a gay couple decided they were going to purchase that house and redo it. Now what had happened to all these houses round here, they'd been split up into rooming houses and kitchenettes 

D: Oh, for people to rent?

J: Yeah, because that's what black people had to have someplace to go. So they couldn't afford to have a big whole house. So a person would rent them a room or rent them a kitchenette, so all these big buildings is places around here now they were, that's what they were, so you could buy one real cheap because they had shows to start deteriorating. So this gay couple decides they're going to buy this building and they got a bank to show him a loan. And that's how the Central West End got turned around because of the gay people coming in and buying up these buildings and refurbishing these buildings and calling them their homes. 

D: Really? Okay. 

J: So that's what, that's how the Central West End became what's called the Central West End.

T: And was Second at that time, you know, would it be considered an open and affirming congregation in that time?

J: At that time it was an open and affirming congregation because they had to get some members from someplace. I'm being honest.

T: They’re right here. 

J: So they had, so they start appearing, moving out. And asking, trying to become more involved in the in the gay community because the gays were buying property in this area. Okay, 

and then they also saw try to try to say to try (?), to move into some other areas. For instance, Mary Jean Boteler was the pastor then and she went to Cote Brilliante, and it was the largest African-American Presbyterian Church, and there were a lot of things going on there, and she wanted to know what was going on there and she wanted to try to to to have some programs between Second and Cote Brilliante. There were a couple of members on our session who were pushing the idea but the Pastor said no, he said no, she's not stealing my members. So we're not gonna have any anything, any programs between us. Okay, but she wanted, her point was she still wanted to try to keep positioning Second and to move and get other Church, other members. Now of course when we had the split at Cote Brilliante and members left Cote Brilliante, that was when Mary Jean made her next move and started getting some of those members who had left Cote Brilliante and opening up to come to Second. 

T: In our mission statement, the back of the bulletin you will see that we identify ourselves as being intentionally tethered to the Central West End and that for me in the interview process was an important phrase because it signalled to me that Second is trying to be a congregation of place and a congregation that is reflective on its history and this particular place and is also humble enough to confess being complicit in power imbalances and racism and all the rest, while at the same time, really employing that decision in 1961 to be a place where people from across lines that usually divide us racially, in terms of sexual orientation, otherwise, can be part of a community of faith. And so I was really drawn to that and it's been interesting to me as a new minister to go around in the neighborhood and to hear from folks who might not come on a Sunday morning to Second but they see it as an institution of credibility because it made that decision to continue to be a part of the tapestry of this part of the city and to be a kind of anchoring institution through a lot of sea change and a lot of, you know, transition.

J: In the, he mentioned the mission study just to sort of capitalize what I said, between 2006 and 2015, under Mary Jean, she began what was called the Second Jeans, which is a fellowship group for students and young professionals. She started working with students at Washington University and had a program there for them. She participated in pride parade and (?) parade. She grew each year bucking the trend of the denomination and we were recognized each year at the Presbyter each year as a growing congregation. She became more diverse, and relating to the African-American and the LGBTQ community. She embraced the Black lives movement and she began a community garden. This was again how Mary Jean was positioning Second Church in regard to where it was and in regard to the movement that it continued. The split from Second produced Ladue Chapel. Which is a very ex-, very rich church. The other half that's where they went, to Ladue Chapel. 

T: Now our prior interim is the interim there. So I'm excited. (laughter) I’m excited to see how might continue. And that’s where it's interesting to me to think about the neighborhood center and also the regional impact, because we've got folks, I was just having a conversation with someone about this, who will come in from Ferguson or Florissant, or come in from the county to be part of this kind of a congregation located in the city. And so, you know, I am forever grateful for for Susan and for Mary Jean and for that adaptive leadership and those movements toward connecting more deeply with students, African Americans, neighbors, the diversity that makes up the Central West End, and I think there's also room for us to create some sense of partnership even across that city/county line and doing things like dismantling racism and privilege in the Presbytery that incorporates churches built in the county and that would be considered more affluent white churches and, you know, churches like ours in the city. So 

there's space for those coalitions, I think, around common concerns, you know, to bridge that divide. 

J: I guess my thinking is just a little different. The westward movement has ended. Okay, and there's a reverse, what I call them. Those families who move way west now, the kids are grown and they are empty nesters. So they're moving back. What's happening now, those factories and those buildings in downtown St. Louis have become lofts, etc., condominiums. So there is a movement now back toward the city, it’s like it’s starting all over again. 

T: Yeah. 

J: Okay. Now what is happening in their movement back towards the city? That means that, what?, the African Americans cannot afford to live in those condominiums etc. So what has happened to them, now they are, we got nowhere to go and they are the ones that’s moving West. So where I see Second is administering (ministering?) to the community around it, which is a growing community because of the people, diverse people, that’s making up this community as well as stretching back toward East because of what's happening in downtown St. Louis. So that's where I see our growth, not, shall we say, going west. That's what I see. 

T: Yeah. Yeah, I hear that and especially with that kind of rediscovery of downtown stuff, you know, I've heard from folks too that, you know, it is a difference between having earned the credibility because you've been in a place for decades, you know, and kind of coming in on the wave of some new development and, now there's a time and a place for different kinds of churches to do different kinds of ministry, but I think in terms of being in touch with Saint Louis’ complex and often divisive and painful history, credibility and trust mean everything and so yeah, I want to second with Jesse is saying about that whole East, in that kind of attention to downtown as well. Credibility is a big part of that. 

J: Now Presbytery, in the midst of this, did something interesting, I don't know whether you’re aware of this or not, but real (?) Presbyterian Church. It's on Olive Avenue. What happened was they built a whole apartment complex in that area, it’s called a Laclede (?) town. And so what the Prebyter decided to do was to establish a different type of industry at Berea. They brought an African-American pastor and a white pastor to minister. And it did something different, was to ask Elders from other congregations to become members of Berea for a certain period of time to help this church grow in a diverse neighborhood. So that was a unique experience.

T: This was Paul Smith? 

J: Yeah. That was, that was, a unique, well he was later on. 

T: Okay. 

J: That was a unique experience, there for that.  That was what they called Laclede town (?). And that was in 1963, see, so that was in the midst of this movement. That was a unique experience. Now I feel also now that, getting off subje-, that our Presbytery here can take into consideration, see what’s going, it's time for them to be creative and, shall we say, in doing ministry. Because we are closing so many churches right now. So many Presbyterian churches are closing. Yeah. 

D: Okay, so it sounds like geographically Second has often found itself kind of in the middle of these migrations East and West…

J: That's the reason that painted that picture. (chuckles)

D: Yeah, yeah, and that it kind of both by necessity, but also has kind of seemingly taken into its identity, this community of diversity and embracing that and trying, trying to embrace that at least. Would you say that that’s accurate?

J: Now the thing about this, Second would not have been able to exist without, shall we say, endowments and those individuals who, shall we say, left money here to carry on because if Second had to throughout out those years pay, per se, all their expenses, it would’ve gone down. So without those endowments we would not be here.

T:  This building wouldn’t be functional either and the building is a big part of that mission, you know, because we have stuff that happens here that's not particularly tied to the church per se but it's nonprofit work or its work for the community or it's a gathering place for folks to be and to talk, you know, and to do work that the church deems is in line with some of its core mission and vision and values, but might not translate into Sunday morning, you know, in a direct way. You need a space to do that. So that's what the building’s for. 

J: And I think Second church is moving toward now becoming, shall we say, more able to take care of its expenses is moving in that direction, hadn’t gotten there yet. Okay, Second under Mary Jean was quite fortunate that if there was a shortfall she always had to go to one individual and that individual would write a check but now we don't go to that individual anymore, we're moving towards, shall we say, becoming more self-sustaining. 

T: Yeah. 

D: Okay. Now that we've covered, I feel like the East-West fairly well, but could one or both of you reflect some, because this is right on the Delmar divide, clearly, and like the relationship with some of those, because I've noticed that there's a number of predominantly African-American like Baptist and AME churches just to the north of here, and what you see Second’s relationship with them and sort of how you would like that relationship to be, 

if you want it to be different than it is right now 

T: Good question. How do you see that Jesse? I have some thoughts but what’s your perspective? 

J: Well moving toward the theme last year, bridging the divide, and I've talked to you about this before, I don't think we moved out as fast as I would have wanted us to see, in connecting, shall we say, with other congregations. For instance, there's a little church right down Olive here that I worked with briefly in regard to a dialogue situation between Central Reform Congregation, which is Jewish, and Cote Brilliante, and I had a short relationship with this, it was a small church, but I think it's a dynamic group. I would hope that Second would be the church that would reach out to get to know the other churches around us, and to work together. Not, shall we say, maybe creating new programs, but in working with the programs that have already been established in some of these other churches. To me, that would be very Christian and that’d be very helpful. So I don't think that we have worked, have moved out far enough within, shall we say, the last year. But, I'm hoping that we will look at it and say, okay, this is our future, let's - we can't do it all alone, because we don't have enough members to do it all alone, but we can work with these other congregations and work with these other congregations we can do some things, for the community. 

T: Yeah, it's interesting that there are these collectives that I'm learning more about and getting to know like the Holy Ground Collaborative as a group of congregations in this area. I was invited to the CRC, Cote Brilliante gathering in August now, by Karlene, so I'll be at that conversation and I also have walked this neighborhood and I've seen these AME Churches and Missionary Baptist Churches and, and reflecting on, number one, just making that extension, you know coffee - I mean a lot of what I do in the course of the week is just calling people up and having coffee, you know, and getting to know people. Some of my colleagues in this area have been, it's been harder to make that connect or to just find that tangible way to sit down and build relationship, though a few of them I’ve been able to touch base with. You know, I think for us part of the challenge with this question is, how do we reckon with being this kind of big established - at least we look like we're this kind of big tall steeple church. And I think there still is some perception that we are a predominantly white church. I hope that that's changing. I hope that there's a sense, like when we have a memorial service where I have a lot of my colleagues, African American colleagues, basically preaching, leading the service, I'm just kind of hosting, and it's primarily African Americans, almost exclusively, in the sanctuary experiencing the space as their spiritual home for this memorial or funeral service, as we had last year. I hope that that does a lot of work to build that trust and to give our neighbors, especially African-American neighbors, whether already have a church home or are north of Delmar, give them examples and opportunities where they can see this place as their church, and as a place that is part of the tapestry of the neighborhood and as a place where they can feel comfortable. And I think we have a lot of work there to continue to create those access points and not to be just kind of a big imposing church on the corner. 

D: Okay. Yeah, and you brought up there kind of the physical building here and how that plays into things. So I guess could both of you maybe reflect a little bit more on how the building kind of shapes the congregation and shapes perceptions as you were talking about a little bit and then maybe if you have something like a favorite part of the building and/or a least favorite part, or, if that makes sense, it's kind of a lot to throw at you.

T: You a favorite part of this building? 

J: Not necessarily. I think the uh, what’s the lounge down there? 

T: Nichols, Compton or Nichols Hall... 

J: Nichols hall…

T: The portrait lounge…

J: The portrait lounge, I think the portrait lounge is very unique and what I've noticed a lot of times with persons who have never been here before, when they come in and they see the lounge, it gives him a (?) sort of a warmer feeling, that it, it moves them away from this huge building to something that is more closer. More comfortable, I guess. I’ve seen that. It was interesting what you were saying about funerals and whatnot, people coming in. The, uh, not Mary Jean, with Susan, Susan had never preached an African American funeral service, and for Alva Vawn (?), who had been a long term African-American member here, she said later that she was completely lost. Okay, and what-, and also another member was saying that he has learned so much, a white member, in being here for African-American funerals and seeing how they conducted, that he didn't know, and that's given him a completely different picture. As to what’s there. So I think it’s still a learning process and whatnot. 

T: What I like about that as an example is, it shows me as the minister of the church that we realize the things we don't know, we are comfortable with acknowledging them and saying, look we have to go on a learning process and we have to be humble and at times we have to confess and be able to look at ourselves and say, here's where we are realistically, here's where God's calling us, in terms of that diversity and inclusion and we need to go on an intentional journey and take intentional steps to get there. And I'd much rather serve that kind of a community, that is aware of what it doesn't know and is curious to learn, than, look at how much we have it all together, you know, our look at how sophisticated we are. That to me is not authentic, and it doesn't signal that. We realize that for church and for Second to utilize this building and to be a viable place in this neighborhood for hopefully decades to come it's got to be it's got to be a place where folks who aren't currently in the building and see their own lives, and see their own faith, see their own relationships and families living and connecting and experiencing God and experiencing service. And so I, you know, I'm looking at the church in terms of the next three decades, not just the next three years and trying to continue that trajectory that Mary Jean has set us on, so that folks who live in this part of the city see their own lives interwoven with what happens in the building. And you know, I think part of a gift and challenge for us is that we've got these Tiffany stained glass windows. And they're beautiful and they are a draw, aesthetically, to a lot of folks, even around the nation who want to see examples of this art form, but, as we've talked about David, there is a racial component to them that is complex. And then I'm going to be exploring with session and also, you know, if you get so tied to an edifice, as beautiful as the edifice is, you have to be very careful it doesn't become a means unto itself or a kind of, a kind of…

J: God. 

T: I'm trying not to go that strong - golden calf, idol, that's one way to put it but, you know, the focus then becomes like how do we keep the building going, and we don't want that. We want to make sure, how do we keep the mission strong, and the building is a vehicle for the mission. So, you know, one of our core values is this beauty notion, and so, if we are about beauty as creating community through the arts, then the building serves that mission whether it's this building forever, which that's great, or if in a hundred years it’s a different space, you know, we, I want to make sure that the church is spiritually attuned to the value and making sure the building is serving the values. 

D: Yeah, so we've mentioned a few different values here about diversity, community, you mentioned beauty there. Are there any other values that you would want to mention and then sort of how are they taught to people? How are they, sort of, broadcast either to the congregation or to the broader community. And then in your in your experiences here, are there any kind of unspoken beliefs that become sort of more explicit as you spend time here either positive or negative? 

T: Yeah, that’s a good question. Remember our four core values? 

J: Go ahead.

T: We talk about beauty. We talk about justice, justice as being in right relationship with neighbor, obviously in St. Louis that has a racial component to it for sure an economic component, but it's also for an earth care congregation about being in relationship with the Earth in a way that’s sustainable. So we're trying to make that connection with social justice and Earth care and ecological Justice. One of our core values also is compassion. And so what you see on Saturday with our pantry ministry for instance is you see folks who come not just to hand out food to hungry people and say here you go have a good day, but to build a relationship and to be in proximity to see, you know as Jesus taught in the gospels, the widow and her mite. And to highlight that moment as a, this person's got it, and to break down divisions along wealth and disparity in this way and build mutuality, you know. So, I'm really thankful for that culture in the pantry as expressed through that exam-, that value of compassion. And then we have a heady group of people here. I mean Second is a very cerebral church, I would say, and that we like ideas and we like putting things on paper and we like thinking and learning and a lot of folks are ordained or have served the church for many years in the Presbytery or are scholars, you know, so we like to think about our faith and have a critical faith and invite folks in, outside speakers, you know, to engage us in timely topics. So we have a vouch (?) lecture series that in the past has meant we've brought up folks in from around the country to speak about injustice or to speak about, what it, the relationship between religion and politics for instance. And one idea I’ll be rolling out with the session this year is we've started this thing called an artist in residence, and I'd be curious to see what it would look like for us to have a scholar in residence as well. And a kind of ongoing relationship with a teacher in the community that can enhance some of our adult education, some of our education hopefully for children, and have some of those public lectures, but be a kind of presence of constant education and enrichment. So those are kind of official four core values. Is there anything that implicitly you think we believe that we don't necessarily put on our paperwork (laughs) but that looks like it's ingrained in us for better or worse?

J: No, I can’t think of anything offhand. One of the things that I'm seeing some movement, is in music, different types of music. It's not moving as fast as I like to see it but it's moving. Second has always been engrossed in shall we say, what term can I use, more (laughs) high cultured music. 

T: Yeah. We like us some Bach. (laughs)

J: Okay, but in order to become a church that is fitting into the community and being more diverse. You have to look at other types of music and I don't mean going from one extreme to the other extreme, but there's so much that’s in the middle that you can work toward and whatnot, and that's what I like to see us working more toward the middle… section, in regard to that type of music. Okay, and I think the congregation is acceptable, open to that, but you gotta find the right person because that's very very difficult. Just to give you an idea at Cote Brilliante, when Cote Brilliante first started, a lady who was very accomplished pianist and organist, she asked the Rev. if she could become the organist and she became the organist for the church, and it was in those veins (?) that the music was based, and we got to a certain point where we realized that, okay, we getting, the congregation at Cote Brilliante was made up of Methodist, Episcopal, Church of God and quite (?), with very few Presbyterians. Okay, so we said, okay now we, for us to grow, we’ve got to think in terms of how can, what can we do with this music situation? So we decided to move toward the middle, and by that I mean we decided to establish a different type of choir, not that, not a choir that was going to sing, um, hard gospel, if that's a way to put it, but a choir that was going to sing in the middle, and we had to do it very carefully, Reverend did a number of sermons on, okay, in regard to saying, okay you like one thing, I like something else, but let's meet in the middle, let's get together and accept, one accept the other. So that was what, the way we moved into them, to looking at different types of music. And it was very interesting, because (chuckles) when we first started having some gospel music, those individuals who do not care for it, they would not come. Okay, so uh-

T: But they had a heads up right? That it was going to be gospel Sunday?. 

J: They would not come, and especially when we got the choir that was singing more hard gospel. Okay, so what we decided to do was, okay, first of all, there was a change, some of the young people brought in their own people, from all around the community, their classmates and whatnot, and they became a club, like they had their own activities and whatnot, so when they would sing they’d bring in all these people from outside. So some of the people who decided not to come to church on Sunday said, wait, what's going on over there? (laughing) You know, so they started coming. 

T: Yes. 

J: Okay, and so that was the movement and then what we decided to do to help it out, we would always say next Sunday the gospel choir will sing, we to schedule. So if you didn't want to come you didn't have come, but eventually it was those who were outside started coming back, it was a gradual process. 

T: Yeah, you know, I think wha-, I had an interesting and kind of revealing moment with someone a few weeks ago, and this might tap into that unsaid assumption, or that unsaid belief. You know we're proudly about and, uh, a proud progressive congregation in the sense of open-minded, open and affirming to people, we are conscientious about things like critical race theory and, know that our faith needs to be in touch with these, these aspects, and yet at the same time, especially in this partisan environment, someone said to me, you know, I’d really like to come to a service but I'm a Republican and I don't know if you’d welcome me, and that was a moment for me in this role as the minister to kind of pause and go, wait a second. How do we in this moment say things that we believe need to be said, that might align ourselves more with the political left in this country, and to say them out of the scriptures and say them out of theological conviction and to say them out of a sincere desire to hold up the best of the civil rights movement and to continue to press us into that tradition both theologically and in terms of civil rights, while at the same time saying, this is not partisan community. Jesus, remember had Joseph of Arimathea, who was a rich man, also as a disciple. And so, you know, I'm really reflecting on that as a kind of thing that I think is sort of in the air that that's a, that's a, liberal church and I really want to make sure, I want to agitate that, and talk about preaching, you know, I preached sermon a few weeks ago about making sure, about basically turning our expectations and assumptions, sometimes on its head, just to make sure that we're thinking about what we're saying and why we're saying it, and who we are being in this moment, even across that partisan divide. So and this was informed, you know, for me when I was serving a church where there, you know, was a moment on that Sunday after the 2016 election where I had to get in the pulpit, and I had half the congregation was totally distressed and nervous about the election of Donald Trump, and the other half the congregation was overjoyed. And I still had to preach a sermon in a way that touched on the diverse feelings in the room, while holding up The Sermon on the Mount, and reminding us all of, here's what the  president-elect hs said, here's what Jesus says, now however are you voted you need to be thinking very hard about how people who are immigrants, people who are on the outside, people, uh, women, the disabled, all those Jesus calls us to make sure we are attentive and serving, how are they feeling right now? And from that deep sense of theological conviction, speak of that place, which some might call progressive or whatnot, but I hope it still applies-, it’s still a message that if you are on the other side politically can hear not as just a partisan message, but as a grounded 

scriptural and theological message, that has public import. So that just comes to my mind, especially, and I think sometimes, you know, churches get caught up in these polarized right left divides, in an unhelpful way. You should be a space that's, that's mending, even that divide too. 

D: Yeah.

J: I think that's interesting coming from you because, I'm surprised at that person. 

T: Yeah.

J: Because, first of all, before Susan, well, before Mary Jean, and then really when Susan came, Susan was very upfront with her, and she preached a number of sermons that were not, shall we say, (inaudible), and one person one time did get up and walk out. But, Second has, was (chuckles), shall we say, if you want to use term was very, uh, Republican. 

D: Hmm, okay.

T: How long ago would you say that was sort of the ethos? 

J: At the start of Mary Jean, her ministry, and then it started moving, and then it was moving slow but then Susan (makes whooshing sound), Susan. Cause Susan didn’t, she spoke how she felt and she didn’t care where the chips fell. 

T: She went to school with Hillary Clinton, you know, just full disclosure (laughter). So I think there was, there's a lot of personal investment. 

J: Yeah, so there wa-, I saw movement with Susan more toward, shall we say, the middle, if you want to put it that way. 

T: The middle more so than the turn toward the left? 

J: Okay, when you said left, what do you mean? I mean, let’s make sure. 

T: Well, let me say this, so my understanding is that, and I say this in the context of how does a preacher preach after national elections? And what's a preacher in a public role saying in that moment? And I know that there, so I've heard, that there were a number of times when Susan, whom I adore, love, and we’re great colleagues, she was very public on Facebook about her particular stance toward a particular candidate over another candidate, and I think was quite vocal in the pulpit about a particular candidate over another candidate. And so, you know, I look at that and I go, um, well, how do I, how is that being framed? What's undergirding that? And as a community of faith, with our first faithfulness and our first call to fidelity to be toward the gospel Jesus Christ, you know, how are we attending that witness publicly in this moment, so that we don't, so not susceptible to having people dismiss us as just being part of the partisan noise. I want to break through partisan noise and get at the heart of the matter in a way that hopefully can speak across, across and through polarization. 

J: Okay, to me what Susan was being (?) liberal, and when she talked about individuals, it was more in terms of what those individuals were doing, their actions, etc. That was where she approached it from.

T: Sure.

J: But doing that, if you have, shall we say, if this is Democrats and this is Republican here, Republicans over here, I have seen more movement, shall we say, towards back this way. (gesturing that the congregation have moved back in the direction of the Republican party)

T: Interesting, okay. 

J: Because after the election I knew, pretty firmly, that the vote here in Second was for Trump.

T: Really?

J: Yes. No, we're not going to talk about it, we’re not going to say so, but what I've seen with sermons they were coming down from Susan and whatnot, people start thinking about, based upon what was happening. 

T: Yeah. Yeah, interesting.

J: And I think right now those individuals who would not speak out, now would speak out, where before they wouldn't. Okay, does that make sense?

T: Yeah, it does. 

J: Okay, okay.

T: Sorry, we're just, is this helpful for you? We’re just chatting now. 

D: No this is very, very interesting. 

J: Okay, okay, okay, very good.  

D: Okay, yeah, thank you. Yeah and I just, I have a, I mean this has been great, and I have a few more questions, I just wanted to check in on time, how you’re both doing. 

J: Okay, go ahead.

T: I have a, I’ve got someone at 1:30, but I’ve got 15-20 more minutes. 

J: That’d be good

D: Okay. 

J: If he don’t talk so much (laughs)

T: I know (laughs)

D: So one thing that we're looking at is, sort of, religion outside of explicitly religious spaces. So how do you think, in your experience, in St. Louis, religion matters to those people that don't consider themselves a part of faith communities? And I guess you can contextualize that in the whole city or just within the Central West End neighborhood - how do you see your relationship with those people that, that are what nones, or whatever you call it now

T: Spiritual but not religious, what have you. 

D: Yeah, Mhm. 

T: Well, I mean a couple things come to my mind just briefly. I just had a conversation with someone who's not religious, but is really on fire for health and well-being and wellness education for folks in the city who historically have not had access to those sorts of resources and that's sort of a community. And so again, the building can be a space for folks who have a mission, whether it's religious or not, that's making a difference and helping to move that compassion value forward. So, for me, having those conversations are really key because it can create a coalition across belief spectrums to get something accomplished or to serve a population. You know I think there is something right now, especially five years after Michael Brown's death and Ferguson, to continuing to have a moral conversation about things like policing, disparities in education and health, that is a public concern that involves the whole polis, and I'm committed to being a pastor that is trying to build a faithful community of faith that is also stewarding and tending a polis of citizens, and being responsible, in that citizenry. So those are a few initial thoughts. 

J: Well, I don't think St. Louis is no different than any other city across the country right now. More and more Millennials or young people are not associated with the church and basically because they do not want to, they’re not interested, shall we say, in the way churches operate in the past, where the church would have this program, this program, this program. They want you to come in and become a part of this program, this program. What I'm seeing right now is that the Millennials or young people here, if they're, if you have something, first of all, they can tell you what they need. Okay. I think we need to listen to what their needs are and then to help them with their needs and help create those programs that serve them and then they will become a part but also on the other side of that, what I'm saying is Millennials are not tied down any particular denomination. Okay. It's what ser-, what suits their needs, what servestheir needs etc. etc. So I think in this, in this community, we've got to start thinking about what’s, what it, what, of the, in this community, what are some of the concerns of the people, that they have surfaced, that we can tie into and to help them? Okay, shall we say, in serving their needs and then becoming a part of church, but not dictating to them. 

T: Yep. 

D: Okay.

J: And that's what I've seen in the past, we dictate too much as to what’s what. 

T: Our, it's interesting our evangelism team, which in some contexts would be like going out and converting people, you know, is much more about coming alongside people, like Jesse is saying, and we're unfolding a new kind of culture about coming alongside people in the community means that we are trying to build those relationships of listening, and know that church happens or our faith community can happen outside the walls of the church. If you're exercising that Spirit of coming alongside people in need. 

J: There's a caution here though. And the caution is, we have to accept the fact that Second is an aging congregation and you’re not going to get, shall we say, members of the congregation to exert too much energy, okay, they want to but the body will say no. (laughs) So you’ve got to think in terms of utilizing that, those persons for the energy level that they have, that they can work within. But at the same time to co-op, that’s a good term, maybe individuals from within the community to do the legwork and to carry on, shall we say, what has been proposed to move ahead, if make sense of it. But, since you’re an aging congregation, you’re not going to get individuals to do certain things, okay. We’ll offer suggestions or finances and whatnot, but you got to think in terms of bringing in other individuals and I don't think necessarily you, when you go out, that you're asking them to do, to become a become a member of the church, but you’re asking them to become part of an ongoing ministry. That's my thinking. 

T: Yeah, yeah.

J: Okay.

D: Great, thank you. And, yeah, my last question is just, what, what should I have asked that I didn't ask, or what would you like to add that I haven't given you the chance to give voice to? 

J: Well one thing that you didn't approach was the political administration of the city, the political administration of the whole community, when I say a whole community, I'm taking to concern the city of St. Louis, the county, and the east side. We are split. And we’re not helping each other. Until we can start, and this was planned, and that's another story. This was planned (chuckles). But until we can come together in some fashion and utilize all of our resources to the best of the region, we are not doing the best that we can for the people that we serve. So some kind of way we have got to, shall we say, move toward uniting, and that's becoming more and more difficult in this area because of the national administration with policy that they've chosen, and that's affecting, shall we say, the locals because now you have people in, the locals, who are now seeing things that they would not say, would’ve not said before, but now they feel comfortable in saying it or doing it. So we moving what I called in an opposite direction. 

D: Okay.

J: But some kind of way, and I don't know how that’s, going to happen, we've got to get a hold of this whole situation and this region and start moving, shall we say, toward more cohesion and more coming together for the betterment of each, because when it comes to growth and when it comes to, shall we say, prosper, we got to work together. One thing that, years ago, that the city of Atlanta did, was to think in terms of okay, we have black over here, we have white over here. Everybody loves green. So let's think in terms of green and that's movement (?). Let’s  bring some green in here and let's work together, I don’t have to love you, I don’t have to like you, but let's work together and bring green in, and that's how Atlanta took off. For instance, if you've been to Atlanta airport, you know how extensive it is and it's growing, I can remember when Atla-, when the airport in Atlanta was no bigger than our sanctuary here.

T: Really, wow?

J: Yes.

D: Wow, okay. Interesting.

J: That’s something, you didn’t hone in on the current political situation, region or national, because they are tied together. 

D: That’s right, yeah. 

T: Well, I just want a second. I'll thank you David for letting us sit down and have this conversation with you and, you know, if there’s one kind of last thought I'd like to leave you with it’s that, as a young pastor serving a church with a deep history, I feel compelled to be part of an entrepreneurial, cultivate an entrepreneurial environment. That's also steeped in history and that attention to marginalized voices, that attention to histories of racism, injustice, disparity, I don't think we can grow, faithfully, without deep and profound continued reflection and repair of the, of those wounds. And so being in this place, being an institution or religious institution in the landscape of the city, located in this part of the city, with history and with future at the table at the same time. I'm really keen on stewarding both aspects of that, of that scope and of this ministry. So thank you again. It's been an honor sit down with you. 

D: Yeah, thank you. Yes, it's been really, really interesting and enlightening for me, thank you.

J: One thing I'd like to say is that I think that our two major universities can do more toward uniting the region…

D:  That’d be SLU and Wash U?

J: Yes, if you note what is happening. You have Wash U here and you have St. Louis U here and they are constantly buying up. Pretty soon, they will control, shall we say, right now they control quite a bit, of each, of St. Louis and of University City and whatnot. So I think that they can do more to step out and to promote more toward helping to unite the region, because they have the resources. 

D: Yeah. Yeah. 

J: Okay. 

T: What can we do next to be helpful? What do you need?

title: Religious Studies Poster
BodyText: This is an advertisement poster for the Religious Studies department of Michigan State University. It is hanging up on a wall inside the Religious Studies reception office in the 7th floor of Wells Hall, visible to anyone who walks by. Symbols of various religious traditions are included in the poster, such as: a Torah scroll, the face of Buddha, Hindu temple exterior, a Christian cross, and the exterior of the Dome of the Rock.
creator: 6ZqvcIG3sLQzpuExn7UsB1QWDQh2

title: The Church of Baseball
BodyText:
Each week on Sunday mornings, Little Leaguers in Southern California pray to the gods of baseball as they recite the Little League Pledge: "I trust in God, I love my country, and will defend its laws. I will play fair, and strive to win. But win or lose, I will always play my best. PLAY BALL!"

The ritual begins about five minutes before the game is scheduled to start. The players come out on the field as the coaches yell "don't step on the lines!" Home team lines up along the third base line, and the visiting team lines up along the first place line. Then the manager from the home team invites one of his players to help led the two teams in the Pledge of Allegiance. A second player helps lead the Little League pledge. Between these two recitations, these Southern California seekers have recognized God two times before the game can begin. Play Ball!

Video 1
creator: to6gNGICQ1X1EHBDN6KQVeykKas2

title: Atheists United Interview

It's been multiple years. I can say.

title: Atheists United Interview
BodyText:
This is an interview transcript created by a CSUN undergraduate as part of her research project for the RS capstone class. The student is identified as Int (interviewer) and the respondents are identified as R1 and R2.

the my question as far as community and that how how are you guys getting together in a

first place.

And so how does that make you feel apart? Like in society and like, how, how do you connect

with people? How, so I find it.

coworker, right? We work, you know, collectively, we all work about 40 to 50 hours, depending

we work until like 930 at night sometimes, and he gets to get out at 530.

that may not be in a divine sense, but it is still important, just as important to me as it is to him to

go do whatever he has to do for his own, uh, theistic community.

title: Atheists United Interview
BodyText:
This is an interview transcript created by a CSUN undergraduate as part of her research project for the RS capstone class. The student is identified as Int (interviewer) and the respondents are identified as R1 and R2.

go do whatever he has to do for his own, uh, theistic community.

title: Telenovelas in the Park
BodyText: During Climate Justice Education Week, the grassroots organization Mujeres de la Tierra (Women of the Earth) perform their signature program, Telenovelas in the Park, at CSUN. The goal of the performances is to create an entertaining, culturally relevant way to introduce environmental concerns into diverse communities. The performance includes opportunities for audience members to brainstorm proactive ways to live sustainably with the earth.

title: Stone towers at Bulguksa Temple
BodyText: I saw these little stone towers on the grounds of the Bulguksa Temple complex in Gyeongju, South Korea during an internship experience I had. These towers were constructed by practitioners of Mahayana Buddhism, common to Korea as a region. They are said to represent stability and balance, concepts that are heavily emphasized in this strain of Korean Buddhism.
creator: wQuX42m58oM65OP2GTRSmsNiP6B2
