title: Melrose Abbey
BodyText: The monastery is partly ruined, yet still serene. The surrounding area is scattered with tombstones, some eligible and clean, and others sunken and barely visible. It is said that Alexander II and the heart of Robert the Bruce are among those buried here. There is greenery throughout the ruins that flows with the walkways of the abbey. The size of the monastery is large, even without its full architecture present. I’m 5’5’’ and my head didn’t meet the bottom of some of the window openings.  The stone used is configured into many archways, sculptures, and crosses, reflecting the trends in medieval architecture. The people are quiet and observant, taking time to look at and touch the remaining stone. I was with my family members, some of whom are Christian and felt moved being in this space. I found myself intrigued with how the monks lived in the monastery at its peak, imagining the walkways and water-wells being used. I wonder what it must have been like to live here with the monks. There is a visiting center and museum about the history of Melrose Abbey. The monastery was the first of its kind (Cistercian) in Scotland, founded in 1136 but was involved in many conflicts with England, leading to reconstruction and eventually ruin.
creator: F9PYL1B1L8VwDllARwcSTpBDCkY2

title: Divided We Fall Protest
BodyText:
• Cori Bush opened this march like she does many marches loudly proclaiming “This is not a peaceful protest… if you want to attend a peaceful protest go and figure out what that is. Protest is disruptive. This is, though, a nonviolent protest, so if you didn’t come here for that please go back to your cars.” 

  • During the march, about half-way through, a woman got overheated and needed water and medical attention. Several people stopped to help her, including some street medics who were a part of the protest.

  • There were several stopping points during the march where speeches were made to educate the protestors. The first was near the end of the trolley tracks on Delmar, and the speaker emphasized the money frivolously spent on the Delmar trolley, and how it was used to divide people. That money could have gone to support communities in need, or to connect the city, but it was used on a largely failed project that further divide the city. Cori Bush also noted there the necessity of protests being strategically organized. She made it clear that the route had been picked on purpose, and that we had just entered into St. Louis County, a line that changed the racial make-up of what surrounded us. Her goal was to educate protestors on the complex dynamics surrounding city and county politics. The second stop was at Debaliviere Ave. and Forest Park. There we took an intersection outside of the Missouri History Museum. The main speaker there was Rev. Darryl Gray, who spoke to the need for unity in organizing and the need for disruption. During his speech someone either from the crowd or who had gotten out of their car threw a water bottle at him. He told the protestors not to worry about it, that it was just water and that he was nonviolent, but also admonished people to be looking around because not everyone there was friendly to the movement. From there the march proceeded down Forest Park Parkway towards Skinker Blvd and paused at the intersection with Skinker Blvd. Here there was a moment of silence for a local activist leader Debra Kennedy who had recently died and there was a brief discussion of recent lynchings/suicides in the news. From here the march went up Skinker back towards Delmar. This path put us alongside several neighborhoods that seemed rather well off, and there were some chants of “Out of your homes and into the streets!” There were a fair amount of people standing on the sidewalks or looking over fences/brick walls at us, and it wasn’t clear to me whether these onlookers were supporting the protests, engaging in them in a kind of voyeuristic fashion, or looking to guard their property/neighborhood from us. Once we reached Delmar we headed back in the direction of the beginning of the protest which was the now closed Cicero’s, which is located at 6691 Delmar. Walking down Delmar at this time we encountered many people, both Black and white, who were eating at restaurants outdoors, or picking up takeout food. Most seemed supportive or ambivalent, though there was an older white man and woman eating outside that seemed clearly disgusted with the protest. Many people were also taking pictures or filming the protest, though it was not clear why they did this. The final stop of the protest was on Delmar only 2-3 blocks away from Cicero’s, where the main emphasis was on the long struggle of the movement, emphasizing that this struggle began in Ferguson, and would need to continue into the future. Rev. Gray noted that the Black Panthers fought for 10+ years, and they had only been fighting 6 years, so they had at least 4 more years to go. A local city councilwoman also spoke to the need for strong local leadership, and for people running for local office if there was no one there who was really supporting the community. Finally, the formal ending to the march was the now famous Assata Shakur quote “It is our duty to fight for our freedom. It is our duty to win. We must love each other and support each other. We have nothing to lose but our chains,” which has been the motto of the movement beginning with Ferguson. From there the march disbanded, with admonitions from the march leaders that people should travel back to their cars in groups because it was certainly possible for protestors to be harassed by police or onlookers. Keep everyone safe was the ending admonition. 

  • During the march there was some dancing and music, especially during stops, but Rev. Gray was quick to point out that “this is a war dance.”

  • One protestor, I’m not sure if he was doing this with the permission of the organizers, was spray painting white fists at the intersections where we took intersections. 

  • Especially on Forest Park there seemed to be angry motorists who were unhappy at being inconvenienced. 

  • Police officers did not engage with the protestors, but drove ahead and behind them, sometimes blocking side streets. The march organizers were clear that individuals should not interact with the police during the march.
creator: https://devstore.rerum.io/v1/id/660c2f6d5ba5492ddce3ebf1

title: Love the Lou
BodyText:
At around 10 a.m. on August 17th, 2019 I met Lucas Rouggly at one of the community gardens his organization, Love the Lou, started in the Vandeventer neighborhood in 2012. We walked around the neighborhood that he lives in and that is one of the focuses of Love the Lou’s ministry while we talked. During that time Lucas encountered several people that he seemed to know, including one kid on a bike who gave him a high five. He also stopped to chat with the foreman of a crew that was demolishing a previously abandoned house that we walked by and exchanged business cards, as they were both interested in revitalizing the area and making it possible for local people to buy homes. Throughout the course of our walk we passed by two other community gardens started by Love the Lou, and inspected a house on Lucas’ block that was previously abandoned, but now is being completely rehabbed by Love the Lou and will soon be sold to a community member at a greatly reduced price, in a deal where the community member will hopefully own the house in 10 years.  

When I asked Lucas why he chose to start the gardens, he responded that starting the was “low-hanging fruit” because there are many vacant lots in the neighborhood. The gardens also serve as places of employment for local kids who are involved with Love the Lou. Lucas explained that employment in the gardens is a part of a tiered system that kids progress through, starting with work in the gardens like weeding and watering, and moving up by the time they are 17 or 18 to getting internships at companies like Southwest or working with local entrepreneurs. 

This tiered system of employment is part of the holistic approach at the Love the Lou, that seeks to address not only the spiritual, but also emotional, economic, etc. needs of those kids that are involved in the organization. “I’m not against street preachers… well actually I am,” said Lucas, and explained that he is opposed to any Christian ministry that merely states the Christian message without helping someone in their concrete situation. For Lucas and Love the Lou, the gospel can’t be preached merely with words - you need to enter into relationship with someone and tend to their physical and social, as well as spiritual, needs if you want to claim to be preaching the gospel. 

Really this understanding of the gospel comes down to love, and specifically love as it is understood by Love the Lou. Though love can sound innocuous, Lucas means something far more radical when he calls people to love one another and to love the city. He explained, using the Greek words for love, that he is talking about agape rather than something like philia. The love that Lucas is interested in is self-giving, and puts the needs of the other before your own. Lucas tries to model this both in his interactions with the people that he serves in the community, and within his own family. 

As Lucas was engaging one of the kids from Love the Lou in conversation, he mentioned that his greatest fear is being a failure as a father, and another Love the Lou staff member said that she had heard Lucas mention this on more than one occasion. This is perhaps a common fear among fathers, but in Lucas’ case there is extra weight placed upon his performance as a father, due to the fact that so many fathers in his neighborhood are either absent or incarcerated. So, for many of the kids, Lucas is the only model of what a father and husband look like, and he serves as a kind of surrogate father figure for many of them. For example, one of the kids recently bought him a mug that says “don’t touch dad’s coffee.” 

The brokenness of many of the families in the neighborhood is just one thing that nearly all of the kids associated with Love the Lou have to deal with. Additionally, many of them have had friends and/or family members violently killed. Gun violence is relatively common. Lucas’ wife has held a dying child on the street right outside their home, their home has been targeted by drive by shootings, and Lucas has personally broken up violent altercations in the neighborhood. Lucas told me that not long before my interview with him one of the young men associated with Love the Lou had their brother shot and killed, and that this set off a cycle of violence where that young man’s house had been repeatedly targeted by drive by shootings. This is on top of the fact that many of the Love the Lou kids have had to deal with food or home insecurity, and other issues related to poverty. 

Lucas’ blanket term for these hardships is trauma. He explained to me as we were walking that if there was a bang behind us, he and the kids from the neighborhood would react - perhaps looking for cover - whereas I would likely ignore the sound or merely turn around to try and find the source of it. I agreed, since gun violence is not a part of my normal reality. This trauma in turn means that the majority of the kids in the neighborhood - as well as people more generally - exist in a survival mindset. Lucas explained that many of these kids can’t imagine surviving past their late teens or early twenties; they just assume that by then they will be dead or incarcerated by then. Similarly, older members of the community generally can’t plan long term because they are trying to figure out how to survive the next few days or weeks. This trauma, and the resulting survival mindset, greatly hinder possible outcomes for the kids and the community. 

A large part of Lucas’ goal, then, is to try and get the kids and community members he works with to be able to see the possibility of a better future. For the kids, this involves the tiered employment system I mentioned previously where they graduate to bigger and better things, and the assistance that Love the Lou gives kids to stay in high school and move on to college or technical school. Lucas shared with me that one of the Love the Lou kids recently got to college and posted a picture of his new dorm on social media. The first comment was from another Love the Lou kid saying “I’m next.” This is the kind of mindset they are trying to promote. Love the Lou gives each of its “graduates” a $5,000 scholarship to help them as they transition to their next phase in life - regardless of whether they choose to attend college. Efforts to beautify the neighborhood - for example the community gardens and remodeling houses - also help people to picture a better future. Finally, Lucas is working to get community members to own homes so that they can benefit from increasing property values and feel connected to the long term health of the community. 

What Lucas has found during his time working with these kids is that they want to succeed just like anyone else their age. The problem they face is not a lack of motivation, but a lack of opportunity. When Lucas is able to give them a leg up and a vision of what their future could look like “95%” of them take the opportunity and build a better life for themselves. An additional aspect of creating opportunity for these kids is helping them work through their trauma. Lucas mentioned that he has been meeting with a psychiatrist and is planning to focus on getting kids to discuss their trauma together in the coming months. Love the Lou also can help kids get connected with counseling services. 

All of this care given to the kids social and economic needs is tied to caring for their spiritual growth. Once a week - Tuesday nights - Lucas and the kids, as well as community members who want to care for the kids, “break bread” and then proceed to read a chapter from the Bible and discuss it. Lucas said that this discussion will often last an hour or more. He indicated that the kids don’t think much of the “Christian” label - which he believes they associate more with white Trump supporters - but that they do love Jesus. For Lucas this is the important part. Jesus models the kind of love he endeavors to live out, and he wants the kids to recognize that as well. Lucas endeavors to have Jesus’ love shape each aspect of his life, and he wants to bring others along with him on that journey.

(transcribed from contemporaneous notes)

  • Employ kids.

    • Tiered system

  • “Love the Lou” basically it’s in the name, they want to take people who love the city and bring them together. 

  • By “love” though, they mean something radical and self-giving. Agape rather than philia. No cheap grace. 

  • They have at least three community gardens, a woodshop, small engine repair shop, art gallery

  • Pay kids at a tiered system to move towards an internship.

    • Give $5,000 scholarship to kids for next stage in life.

  • Giving away $150,000 house they remodeled - with strings attached.

  • Lots of volunteer folks, people retiring and wanting to do good things.

  • Lots of disappointment and hardship, but there is always good happening with the bad. “I can only handle one rejection a day.” 

  • Recently one of the kids brothers (?) was shot, and this set off a cycle of violence.

  • Kids are dealing with trauma that they don’t know how to address.

  • Trying to give them a vision of a better future.

  • Move away from a survival mindset, only thinking day to day or week to week.

  • One of the kids got to college recently, and the first comment on their Facebook post was “I’m next.” 

  • Lucas is providing a model of what a father and husband looks like

  • Most of the neighborhood is held together by women.

  • When the kids have the opportunity, 95% of them go on to lead productive lives. The problem is a lack of opportunity. 

  • Tuesday night Bible study. Break bread, read a chapter of the Bible, discuss. 

    • Kids see Christian as a problematic label, possibly tied to whiteness and Trump, but they love Jesus.

  • Not a church, kind of like a youth group

  • Lucas’ whole family contributes.

  • His biggest fear is to be a failure as a father.

  • He wants people to own property so that they reap the rewards of price increases, and so they’re invested.

  • Lucas gave a random kid on a bike a high five - he is really a part of the community.

  • “I’m not against street preachers, well actually I am.” 

  • The point is that you can’t just minister to someone’s spiritual needs, you need to minister to them holistically.

  • even when Denise turned him down, he said that she didn't want to do it because when she does something she does it right, and she didn't think she could do it right.

  • Lucas has a real way of being present despite the fact that he has a lot of things going on at any given time.

  • one of the girls got him a "don't touch dad's coffee" mug as a present after he threw a party for her friend.

  • the idea is that they're trying to uplift the community through relationships. They need long term commitment from people who want to help, not just someone who wants to take an Instagram picture with a black kid and move on.

title: Street Preaching on Grand
BodyText: Members of different churches gathering on Grand Boulevard to preach the Bible. This is a common sight for students who cross this street on Thursdays, something I'm sure has made them feel a mix of emotions. I spoke with the organizer and he was a really kind individual who said he just wants people to come to know and love Jesus. Heavy emphasis on sin and salvation.
creator: wQuX42m58oM65OP2GTRSmsNiP6B2

title: University Lutheran Church
BodyText: A Lutheran Church in East Lansing, near MSU's campus. It is associated with the Evangelical Lutheran Church in America (ELCA) which is known to be progressive on social issues. Their website also states that they are a "Reconciling in Christ" congregation, a partner of ReconcilingWorks: Lutherans for Full Participation, which promotes LGBTQIA+ inclusion and racial equity efforts.
creator: 6ZqvcIG3sLQzpuExn7UsB1QWDQh2

title: University United Methodist Church
BodyText: A United Methodist church in East Lansing, very close to MSU's campus. According to their website, the church "stands as a beacon of inclusivity and acceptance, truly embodying the belief that EVERYONE is welcome" and "endeavors to spread love and do good in the world."
creator: 6ZqvcIG3sLQzpuExn7UsB1QWDQh2

title: Islamic Center of East Lansing
BodyText: The Islamic Center of East Lansing is "a non-profit association that represents Muslims in the Greater Lansing area." It self-describes as being nondenominational and "open to all" with a goal to "promote unity among Muslims." It provides congregational prayers, teaching circles, educational programs, and social activities.
creator: 6ZqvcIG3sLQzpuExn7UsB1QWDQh2

title: Little League Opening Day
BodyText:
US Senator Alex Padilla, a regular Little League dad here in Southern California, was a featured speaker during Northridge City Little League's opening ceremony. This annual ritual builds collective effervescence as young players suit up and parade through the facilities to gather in the outfield of Field 5. Sacred leaders from bygone eras, such as former league champions now in high school and heading for college baseball careers, visit the young neophytes to offer inspirational words of guidance. Community elders, such as parents whose children are all grown up, advise current families to cherish their time on the fields, as it will all be over before we know it.

Play ball!
creator: to6gNGICQ1X1EHBDN6KQVeykKas2

title: Christmas in Hollywood
BodyText: Visitors and residents in Southern California celebrate Christmas near the Hollywood Stars Walk of Fame. Christmas music and decorations surround the larger-than-life Christmas tree that marks the festive season. Young visitors celebrate some stars while sharing their true feelings of others.
creator: to6gNGICQ1X1EHBDN6KQVeykKas2

title: Sustainability in Nature Films
BodyText: Producer Roy Conli visits CSUN to screen the film Penguins and discuss his expertise in creating powerful environmental stories through Disney Nature productions.
creator: to6gNGICQ1X1EHBDN6KQVeykKas2

title: CSUN Freight Farm
BodyText: Students, faculty, and staff visit CSUN's freight farm during a Sustainability tour for Climate Justice Education Week. The freight farm serves as a living lab for student and faculty research at CSUN. It provides fresh produce for students and community members to access through CSUN's Food Pantry.
creator: to6gNGICQ1X1EHBDN6KQVeykKas2

title: Christmakah in Southern California
BodyText: This Southern California family takes a break from the Church of Baseball to honor their family traditions through Christmakah. They eat potato latkes dressed in a manner common among the Levey clan of south Texas - an applesauce base is topped with cherry preserves and sour cream. They light the Hanukkah candles and dance around the coffee table as they play the Barenaked Ladies' version of "Hanukkah o' Hanukkah." The glow of lights from the Christmas tree complement the candles to bathe the room in the light of the season.
creator: to6gNGICQ1X1EHBDN6KQVeykKas2

title: Runners in the Hands of an Angry God
BodyText: Runners in the Hands of an Angry God is a highly selective running club whose participants all share two character traits: they are both distance runners AND scholars/historians of American religion. With twelve members hailing from at least seven states, RitHofAG showed their athletic and academic prowess as they ran through the winding roads of the Blue Ridge Mountains in October 2023. They collectively covered more than 200 miles of road in the course of approximately 30 hours, making friends and kicking butt along the way.
creator: to6gNGICQ1X1EHBDN6KQVeykKas2

title: Agia Triada Monastery
BodyText: The Holy Trinity monastery is an active Greek Orthodox monastery and is a museum for a multitude of religious objects. The courtyard is filled with plotted plants and trees surrounding benches. There are also cats that roam the monastery. The architecture has Venetian and Byzantine influence, and the monastery was built in the 17th century. (https://www.rental-center-crete.com/blog/agia-triada-tzagaroli/) The architecture includes multiple archways, but they are more rounded than the pointed archways seen at the Melrose Abbey. The monastery also has a lot of domes on the roofs, with small crosses extending through the top. This dome style is similar to that of Islamic mosques, which showcases the influence of Arabic culture in Greece. Inside the center building with the tallest dome, there is a mural of Jesus with a halo formed around His head. The room is adorned with various gold artifacts and crosses, further decorated with more images of religious Christian figures. There is a dress code, and it is to cover the shoulders and areas above the knees for both men and women. The people are mostly quiet, talking amongst the others in their group. Many visitors have their phones out and are photographing the main room. The museum contains objects ranging from important outfits and fittings to small coins and buttons. There is also a gift shop, which sells food, artifact copies, lotions, and oils among other things. The monastery is also a winery, which does wine tastings and tours.
creator: F9PYL1B1L8VwDllARwcSTpBDCkY2

title: "Where's Religion"
BodyText:
The following images you will see are pictures of various items around my family’s pooja room. This room is commonly found in many Hindu households and holds a very big importance in the practice of our religion. Its organization can differ between practitioners; in this sense, it has a very personal touch and is organized to address the thoughts, beliefs, and feelings of the home that it is in. From the various images shown around the room to the individual figures of gods and goddesses, each item, color, and shape that you see is symbolic and represents a detailed examination of Hinduism through my family’s understanding and intention.

Figure 1.1: Pooja Room + Picture of Hanuman

The frame of Hanuman Ji serves as a reminder to us that as followers of Hinduism, we must practice service and humility in everything we do. This is because in the Ramayana epic, Hanuman was a servant to Lord Ram and he was the first person to travel to Lanka and attempt to find Sita in order to save her. Next, you will see a small sculpture that appears like a small temple and a silver plate in front of it. This small temple is the abode that we pray under to focus our attention. While it can serve as a container of many different items used in prayer services and festivals, its main function is to give followers a concrete place to direct their attention to while praying and respecting God. Additionally, one of the major themes of Hinduism is the triumph of good over evil; as such, it is commonly believed that the presence of a room in the house dedicated to pooja ensures that in the day-to-day activities, no darkness or evil can hurt your home as the presence of God offsets any harm. The silver plate is held during a prayer service and normally holds a small flame; the flame dispels darkness, while the smoke purifies the air around us. On the right side of the image is a yellow bottle of ghee or Indian purified butter. This is the purest form of cow’s milk and is one of the many things we offer to God to show our thanks.

 

Figure 1.2: Picture of Ganesh

In this image, is a frame of another God, Ganesh Ji. Ganesh is one of the first Hindu deities I was taught about as a child and he is the first God that is worshiped during any sacred ritual. It is believed that Goddess Parvati made Ganesh from clay and instructed him to guard her chamber while she bathed. One day when God Shiva tried to enter her chamber, Ganesh did not let him pass which infuriated him. In retaliation, he cut off Ganesh’s head. As Ganesh screamed out in pain, Parvati came running and, out of intense anger, promised to destroy the world if Ganesh was not brought back to life. To appease his wife, Shiva placed the head of an elephant on Ganesh and brought him back to life. In addition, he promised Ganesh that any pooja or ritual will begin with the worship of Ganesh and that without this worship, no service is complete. As such, many pooja rooms have pictures or figures of Ganesh to follow this ritual implemented by Lord Shiva. From the picture, you will notice there is a red trident at the forehead of Ganesh and a lotus flower in one of his hands. The red trident is symbolic of the red  tilak that Hindus apply which indicates protection from evil energy and fellowship with other Hindus who apply it. The lotus flower is symbolic towards Lord Vishnu who is the operator, and is meant to bestow followers with prosperity in their day-to-day activities. 

Figure 1.3: Figure of Goddess Lakshmi and Lord Ganesh

In this red figure is Lakshmi, the goddess of wealth, and Ganesh, the god of prosperity. They are commonly put side-by-side when we celebrate Diwali, the festival of lights. In the social context,  Diwali is a time of fellowship with others and is when we celebrate the new harvest by praying and giving many offerings to Lakshmi and Ganesh. In practice, this takes the shape of inviting family and friends over for dinner, distributing sweets, and going to the temple to pray and sing together. In a religious context, this celebration marks the return of Lord Rama when he rescued Sita and defeated Ravana and commemorates the theme of good over evil. Upon Lord Rama’s return from Lanka, the whole city was lit up; as such, we commonly light diya’s(lamps) when celebrating Diwali to banish away darkness and commemorate the city being lit upon Lord Rama’s return.
creator: https://store.rerum.io/v1/id/662fba34b8e3a22a8b1c1c70

title: Temple No 1- Bando Station
BodyText: Bando Station is the closest local train station to the designated Temple 1 of the Shikoku pilgrimage, Ryozen-ji. Today the train is busy with students, locals, and other henro and visitors heading to the temple, judging by the white vests and jackets. A group of tourists from Italy is on the train as part of a guided tour group and looks to number about 20 people. There are dressed in comfortable outdoor clothing, so likely just visiting the first one or temples before heading to another destination.
creator: KHAHfSWMJ6SshJHmk81TXGOPUzI3

title: Shinto shrine - Walk to Temple 2
BodyText: Walking henro can encounter many instances of lived religion along the routes between temples, such as this small Shinto shrine on a quiet residential street between Temple 1 and Temple 2. These shrines are generally well-kept, and often have recent offerings.
creator: KHAHfSWMJ6SshJHmk81TXGOPUzI3

title: Journey to Daiichi Temple - Shrine
BodyText: Shinto shrine on the pathway to Temple 4
creator: KHAHfSWMJ6SshJHmk81TXGOPUzI3

title: Shikoku Pilgrimage number of temples
BodyText: The Shikoku Pilgrimage consists of 88 main temples, which give the pilgrimage it's name Hachi jū hachi-kasho. There are an additional 20 temples around Shikoku that are associated with the pilgrimage but outside the main 88, making the total number 108. These are called bekkaku (別格, different class) and bangai reijou （番外霊場, spiritual place outside those numbered). 108 is the sacred number in Buddhism and some of the other Indian traditions.
creator: https://store.rerum.io/v1/id/66426cd326cb9a5f89eead28

title: Green Line Start - Bando Station
BodyText: This small train station is the main starting point for the "Green Line," a green painted line on the pavement guiding henro (pilgrims) from the station to the main gate of Ryozen-ji, Temple No. 1 on the Shikoku Pilgrimage. Henro in their white gear are a common sight on the local trains coming from Tokushima Station, especially during the spring pilgrimage season.
creator: KHAHfSWMJ6SshJHmk81TXGOPUzI3

title: Green Line - Approach to Temple 1 (Ryozenji)
BodyText: This is the approach to Temple 1's main gate along the Green Line. As new pilgrims approach, they can go directly through the main gate, or turn right along the temple wall and enter the parking lot to access the Henro store and buy their gear, stamp books, and other items before returning the gate for a formal entry into the temple.
creator: KHAHfSWMJ6SshJHmk81TXGOPUzI3

title: Green Line - Street
BodyText: In this semi-rural area, there is a fairly small, but dense mostly residential area between Bando Station and the main gate to Temple 1. The Green Line follows the edge of several streets, with very little room between the street and building fronts.
creator: KHAHfSWMJ6SshJHmk81TXGOPUzI3

title: Temple 1 Bell
BodyText:
This is the bell tower (Bonsho) at Temple 1. It is customary to announce yourself to the temple's deity. Dr. Green demonstrating how to ring the bell. In developing the VSP interaction for users, we are lookin at an animation of the bell ringing action as users stop at the bell tower.

Video 1

BodyText: This is the two-storey pagoda at Temple 1. With the foliage and tight layout of the temple, the pagoda almost blends in with the trees from some angles.

title: Temple 2 temizuya
BodyText: Gokurakuji (Temple 2) temizuya, or washing station for visitors to cleanse themselves before proceeding into further into the temple precinct.
creator: KHAHfSWMJ6SshJHmk81TXGOPUzI3

title: Temple 2 - Hondo
BodyText:
The Hondo at Temple 2 is located adjacent to the Daishido, or Kobo Daishi hall on a narrow terrace above the rest of the temple complex. The Hondo can be reached either via a set of steep stairs, made of stone and concrete, or a concrete ramp that begins along the edge of the temple space at the back of the lower area and curves more gently around up to the back of the Daishido.

The Hondo is directly at the top of the steps, with only a narrow flat space in front of the building. Directly behind the Hondo is another short set of steep steps leading to a small building that is not open to the public.
creator: KHAHfSWMJ6SshJHmk81TXGOPUzI3

title: Temple 2 - Daishido
BodyText:
The Daishido at Temple 2 is located adjacent to the Hondo, or mail hall on a narrow terrace above the rest of the temple complex. The Daishido can be reached either via a set of steep stairs, made of stone and concrete, or a concrete ramp that begins along the edge of the temple space at the back of the lower area and curves more gently around up to the back of the Daishido.

During our field visit, a tour group led by a Zen Buddhist monk was visiting the temple, and recited the sutras at the hondo and daishido before leaving fairly quickly. The monk stopped for a moment to say hello, before following after the tour group. Some members of the group had portions of the henro attire, but others were dressed in casual clothing. Groups that travel to temples on the pilgrimage via bus are common, and it is an acceptable way to participate.
creator: KHAHfSWMJ6SshJHmk81TXGOPUzI3

title: Way marker- Journey to Temple 3
BodyText:
One small, but important detail about the journey between temples for the walking henro are the way markers that are placed along the route most commonly used. These markers come in a variety of forms, with older wooden and stone markers mixed with laminated paper sheets and even painted markers on the ground or a nearby object (such as a guardrail).

With modern access to smartphone navigation, we observed many henro using their phones, but as our team traced the route between Temple 2 and Temple 3 on foot ourselves we found we often needed the way markers we encountered to verify we were on the path to the next temple.
creator: KHAHfSWMJ6SshJHmk81TXGOPUzI3

title: Waymarker - Journey to Temple 4
BodyText:
One small, but important detail about the journey between temples for the walking henro are the way markers that are placed along the routes most commonly used. These markers come in a variety of forms, with older wooden and stone markers mixed with laminated paper sheets and even painted markers on the ground or a nearby object (such as a guardrail).

With modern access to smartphone navigation, we observed many henro using their phones, but as our team traced the route between Temple 3 and Temple 4 on foot ourselves we found we often needed the way markers we encountered to verify we were on the path to the next temple. There are often multiple types of markers found along the route, as can be seen here with the carved sign with finger pointing the way and the laminated print sign on the guardrail.
creator: KHAHfSWMJ6SshJHmk81TXGOPUzI3

title: Temple 6 pagoda
BodyText: Anrakuji's two-storey pagoda is difficult to photograph in the small, enclosed space of the temple grounds, and is partially hidden by trees.
creator: KHAHfSWMJ6SshJHmk81TXGOPUzI3

title: Temple 14 - Stone slab
BodyText: The main buildings of Temple 14 (Jorakuji) are built on a large stone slab. This temple's principal deity is Miroku Bosatsu. While the temple courtyard, with the exposed stone all around, has an open feel, it is nestled against the mountainside behind it and also maintains a secluded atmosphere.
creator: KHAHfSWMJ6SshJHmk81TXGOPUzI3

title: Temple 16 - gate
BodyText: Temple 16 (Kanonji) is situated in a dense extra urban area, and walking henro coming from Temple 15 (Awa Kokubunji) must navigate along highways and then narrow streets to get to the temple gate.
creator: KHAHfSWMJ6SshJHmk81TXGOPUzI3

title: Happy Science encounter
BodyText: While returning on the train from Temple 16 to Tokushima Station, I was engaged in conversation with a small group of visitors who asked if I spoke English. When I responded yes, an Austalian man began to speak with me, telling me he was part of a religious group called Happy Science, and he and his companions were in Shikoku to attend a retreat with their organization.
creator: KHAHfSWMJ6SshJHmk81TXGOPUzI3

title: Train to Temple 23
BodyText: Many henro use public transit where possible to move between temples. A local train line runs south to Hiwasa. Several henro were on our train from Tokushima, and additional henro got on at stations along the way
creator: KHAHfSWMJ6SshJHmk81TXGOPUzI3

title: Temple 23 - seaside
BodyText: Temple 23 is situated just above the small port town of Hiwasa. Hiwasa Cadtle can be seen on a nearby hill. This area seems to have amenities for Henry and other visitors, much like a beach town.
creator: KHAHfSWMJ6SshJHmk81TXGOPUzI3

title: Temple 23
BodyText:
Temple 23, Yakuoji, is located on a hillside in Minami in Tokushima Prefecture. This the last temple in Tokushima prefecture, and the last in what is considered the first dojo, before a long distance to Temple 24 in Kochi Prefecture.

Due to its location on a hillside overlooking the sea and the seaside village of Hiwasa, Yakuoji is tiered with multiple levels. The Hondo and Daishido on 3rd level, while the temple's Pagoda is above this terrace. Near street level is the temple's stamp office and shop. With visitors also coming to the area for its other attractions, the atmosphere at this temple is a bit more relaxed.
creator: KHAHfSWMJ6SshJHmk81TXGOPUzI3

title: Temple 23 - Rail journey
BodyText:
Tokushima to Hiwasa - Trip is just under two hours by rail, passing through the city of Anan and a number of small towns.The train was quiet, but there were several other henro in their gear traveling to Temple 23 as well.


Temples 20-22, are not easily accessible by rail and can be hiked to via Temple 19 or starting from Tatsue Station on the JR Mugi Line. For this field work, the team is focusing on temples that can be accessed by public transit, with shorter walks in between, to maximize our visits.
creator: KHAHfSWMJ6SshJHmk81TXGOPUzI3

title: Thrifting religion main finding
BodyText: Angels were the most ubiquitous form of religious material culture we observed across four thrifting contexts: two Goodwill, two independent stores in SE Texas and SW Connecticut. Overall, angels represented 26% of all examples documented (77/293). Our team distinguished six types of angels (representative examples included): country homemaker, idealized feminine, modern feminine, infantile, child-like, and anthropomorphized.
creator: sTXs6aBGKlNzlk5CfhsXCbOPvoK2

title: Tokushima Note Box
BodyText: Outside the cable car entrance at the base of Bizan mountain in Tokushima City, a small park with benches has a notebook for henro to leave messages.
creator: KHAHfSWMJ6SshJHmk81TXGOPUzI3

title: Bizan Mountain park and shrine
BodyText: Bizan mountain, in the heart of Tokushima, I'd accessible via ropeway and trails. Five Shinto shrines are located within the park at the summit. The main henro path passes along the base of Bizan mountain and the park offers a panoramic view of the valley. The city of Tokushima is both a starting point for henro and also a finishing point, as many who complete the pilgrimage return to Temple 1, so it is common to see pilgrims around parts of the city, especially near the train station/bus terminal.
creator: KHAHfSWMJ6SshJHmk81TXGOPUzI3

title: Temple 17 - temple courtyard
BodyText: Temple 17 is largely open, with no surrounding wall. Instead of gravel, walking surfaces are concrete. To the right of the hondo, some section of wall remains.
creator: KHAHfSWMJ6SshJHmk81TXGOPUzI3

title: Tokushima-Wakayama Nankai Ferry
BodyText:
When henro complete their journey, or wish to visit Kukai's resting place, they will travel to Mount Koya, or Koyasan.

There are a number of ways to get from Shikoku to Koyasan. The Wakayama Nankai Ferry takes passengers back to Honshu just south of Osaka, and then travelers can take a train to the foot of Mount Koya.
creator: KHAHfSWMJ6SshJHmk81TXGOPUzI3

title: Tokushima-Wakayama Nankai Ferry
BodyText:
When henro complete their journey, or wish to visit Kūkai's resting place, they will travel to Mount Koya, or Kōyasan.

There are a number of ways to get from Shikoku to Kōyasan. The Wakayama Nankai Ferry takes passengers back to Honshu just south of Osaka, and then travelers can take a train to the foot of Mount Koya. During our team's travel to Kōyasan, we went by way of the ferry and saw several henro sharing the ride with us. The number of pilgrims taking this journey is sufficient for a special Kōyasan ticket, which covers both the ferry and the train to Kōyasan. You just need to request the ticket at the ferry port ticket office in Tokushima.
creator: KHAHfSWMJ6SshJHmk81TXGOPUzI3

title: Okunuin cemetery - Kobodaishi Mausoleum entrance
BodyText: This is the most well-known and largest cemetery in Japan, located at Mount Koya or Koyasan. The cemetery has over 200,000 graves, including emperors, samurai lords, monks, and members of many prominent Japanese families. At the heart of the cemetery, and the end of a nearly 2km long path, is the mausoleum of Kukai, posthumously given the title of Kobo Daishi.The cemetery' setting in old-growth forest, with the long central pathway shaded even during the day, gives Okunoin an otherworldly feel, and most visitors remain quiet or speak in soft tones as they move through the grounds.
creator: KHAHfSWMJ6SshJHmk81TXGOPUzI3

title: Okunuin Cemetery - Corporate monuments
BodyText:
The newer section of Okunoin includes many corporate monuments, and among the most recognizable is the rocket shaped monument of aerospace company Shin Meiwa Kogyo. Panasonic, Nissan, Honda, and Toyota are among the many other corporations represented. For centuries, Okunoin has been one of the most sacred and desired burial places in Japan, with emperors, samurai, monks, politicians and other prominent Japanese people vying for the chance to be interred here. The corporate graves are an opportunity for employees of the company and their families (who purchase plots within the larger grave) to be memorializing in this sacred space. The streaming crowds of visitors on most days walk past these corporate graves on their way to the inner sanctum of the cemetery and Kukai's mausoleum.

As they pause at the monuments lining the pathway, visitors take a few moments to take photos or read inscriptions, but rarely move into the rows behind the main path. There are fewer trees in this portion of Okunoin, giving it a brighter, more open feel than the shaded walkways and graves in the older sections of the cemetery.
creator: KHAHfSWMJ6SshJHmk81TXGOPUzI3

title: Okunoin Cemetery- Rest house
BodyText: Near the Kobodaishi mausoleum is a rest house for henro and others to sit, with tables and chairs. The rest house is not crowded, but there is a steady stream of individuals and small groups of people coming and going from the rest house. Some are resting or talking quietly and others are eating small meals or snacks as they have a temporary respite from the bustle of the heart of the temple area.
creator: KHAHfSWMJ6SshJHmk81TXGOPUzI3

title: Dango Garan - gate
BodyText: The Dango Garan is the main temple complex in Koyasan, and includes several temples and other religious structures.
creator: KHAHfSWMJ6SshJHmk81TXGOPUzI3

title: Kompon Daito
BodyText: One of the two main pagodas in Koyasan. The original building was completed about 40 years after Kobo Daishi entered his eternal meditation state
creator: KHAHfSWMJ6SshJHmk81TXGOPUzI3

title: Saigyō Zakura - Kōyasan
BodyText: Saigyō's Cherry Tree - Famous monk and poet Saigyō planted this cherry tree in commemoration of moving the Sanmaidō Hall to its current location during the 12th century. Saigyō was a Shingon esoteric priest and some of his poems reference Shingon's Moon Disk Meditation. Saigyō's Buddhist name means West-Going, a reference to the Buddhist Pure Land and Amida.
creator: KHAHfSWMJ6SshJHmk81TXGOPUzI3

title: Mikoshi in Brooklyn
BodyText:
a Mikoshi is a sacred Shinto shrine.

followers believe that it serves as the vehicle to transport a deity in Japan while moving between main shrine and temporary shrine during a festival or when moving to a new shrine. Often, the mikoshi resembles a miniature building, with pillars, walls, a roof, a veranda and a railing. (wiki)

title: Crave Coffee
BodyText:
When passing by on SLU’s Medical Campus, the Crave Coffeehouse building appears to be a traditional-looking church. Once inside, however, you are met with a blast of cool air from the ceiling fans on the vaulted ceilings and 2000’s music softly playing over the speakers. You notice the modern-looking brick covering all the walls and the tall stained glass windows that pour color into each side of the room. You see the altar at the front of the worship center, with a big wooden cross lit aglow by a warm light behind it. There is a huge curved counter where friendly workers make coffee out of machines that whir loudly. Customers of all different careers and ages drink coffee, converse, and laugh around the room. Crave Coffeehouse provides an atmosphere that defies traditional religious ideologies, starting with its exterior. Groups of all kinds gather at Crave to create a welcoming atmosphere -- whether it is with a Christian motivation or not.


Do customers typically frequent Crave because of the religious undertones, or just because of the coffee/location?

Do all the workers share Crave’s religious values?

What does Crave’s typical customer look like/what is their profession?

  • Soft 2000’s music plays over the speakers and echoes throughout the room

  • Barista laughs with customers who are placing their order

  • The air smells like coffee beans and pastries 

  • A blender whirs as a barista adds in ingredients to make a customer’s smoothie

  • The door creaks open and clicks shut as a new group of friends/students arrive

  • Three large fans are on the ceiling, making cool air flow throughout the whole shop

  • Students doing homework at a nearby table make clicking noises as they type on their laptops

  • Little snippets of each conversation is picked up from where I’m sitting every few seconds

  • Conversations of two different groups of girls blend together, drone out the music 

  • The sound of the refrigerator whirring is one of the three most prevalent sounds (fridge, music, conversation)

  • The layout of Crave is an exact replica of a church’s worship center, as they hold a Sunday mass here every week

  • Banners at the front of the shop read “loved by God, sent to the world” and “Crave Coffeehouse + Reliant Church”

  • A cross is the focal point of the room, is displayed in the middle of the altar-area with a backlight making it look like it’s glowing

  • Seven tall, pointed stained glass windows on both side walls pour blue, yellow, red, green, and pink into the room

  • Two of the female students in the room softly sing along to the music playing as they write in notebooks

  • A machine behind the coffee counter starts up with a loud electric noise

  • Silverware and a mug clink together in a woman’s hand as she begins to clear her table

  • The brick that covers all four walls seems old and imperfect, some areas of brick being more white than red

  • The room is long and narrow, with an altar at the front. The altar is a stage-like area of the front wall that contains the main lit-up cross, four candles and metal candle holders, and a wooden podium 

  • At the back right corner of the room is the coffee bar, a huge curved counter where two workers stand near the register, waiting for their next customer

  • At the very back of the room is the restrooms on either side wall, with huge wooden doors between them that lead out to the parking lot

  • Without seeing the “Crave Coffeehouse” sign out front, a passerby may believe that this building is just a traditional church

  • Once walking inside, you are met with a nice breeze from the ceiling fans on the high ceilings, friendly baristas that greet you, and a very modern-looking church with a coffee bar in the back that seems like it belongs there

  • There are stairs leading to a door on one side of the altar that leads to the backstage area

  • Above the restrooms and the back door, there is a balcony area like a typical church may have

  • The balcony area is made of dark wood, and looks like it’s the oldest and most traditional part of the building

  • All different kinds of people are inside: professionals in the middle of their work day, more casual workers with name badges, young students here to study, and groups of friends of all different ages that gather

  • Most groups in the room seem to gather in one corner of the room, the environment feels very friendly and welcomin
creator: mPpZp21UPnZSqevTcExeLXCxhfP2

title: Unity of Fort Lauderdale Spiritual Center
BodyText:
Situated in a trendy strip mall located just a few blocks from the beach rests the new home of Unity of Fort Lauderdale Spiritual Center. Unity was first founded in 1889 by Charles and Myrtle Fillmore, and it is often historically located within the lineage of New Thought and the Prosperity Gospel (see Kate Bowler, Blessed, 33-35). Headquartered near Kansas City, Missouri, today Unity boasts over 600 study groups and churches established across the globe.

Nestled between restaurants, spas, salons, and bars, Unity’s newest Fort Lauderdale location promises to offer an inclusive and tranquil space for the spiritual seeker. Peering through the glass, the interior looks like an empty office space filled with desks and chairs but peppered with affirmations printed on plain white paper and hung throughout the building, stating: “We create sacred space. We be the energetic vibration of LOVE/PEACE/APPRECIATION/ABUNDANCE/ALLOWING/BEINGNESS/DIGNITY…”

More information is available at the door for the curious passerby, including a card with the “5 Guiding Principles of Unity” and a 55-page booklet titled “WORTHY: LGBTQ Stories of Overcoming Rejection and Religion to Find Truth” (published by Unity Village in Missouri).

While remnants of the late nineteenth century New Thought movement are still clearly evident in statements such as “Thoughts held in MIND produce after their kind,” the Unity of the twenty-first century also appears to include a strong focus on a different kind of healing than that of the past – the healing of religious trauma for those deemed unacceptable and unworthy by other religious traditions.

Sources:

“About Us,” Unity, accessed June 24, 2024, https://www.unity.org/static/about-us.
Kate Bowler, Blessed: A History of the American Prosperity Gospel, New York: Oxford University Press, 2013.
creator: F619Zx0aQZQ0b6OoHm9ORy7Hmlh1

title: Mother Jones Monument
BodyText:
I found my way to the Mother Jones monument by the beckoning of a life-size image of Mary Harris Jones (1837-1930), located inside the Coalfield Rest Area on Interstate 55, just 25 miles south of Springfield, Illinois. Dressed in a sharp purple overcoat and positioned in front an image of a diverse group of coal miners, the stern stare of “Mother Jones” urged me to take a short detour on my drive home from Milwaukee to St. Louis to learn more about this intriguing woman and “her boys.”

The Mother Jones Monument is located 20 miles south of the Coalfield Rest Area in Mt. Olive, Illinois, just a few turns off Old Route 66, behind a small neighborhood speckled with political yard signs suggestive of a small town with a conservative majority. The monument is situated within the Union Miners Cemetery, which is claimed to be “the only labor union-established and union-owned cemetery in the United States.” The cemetery was purchased in an effort to secure a burial site for miners who perished in the “Battle of Virden” (a deadly struggle that took place between miners and forces of the Chicago-Virden Coal Company in 1898), and all miners thereafter.

The monument itself is located at the far edge of the cemetery, and it marks the burial place of Mother Jones, who dedicated her life to fighting for the rights of coal miners. At the same time, the monument also stands as a memorial to those miners whose lives were lost in the Battle of Virden and similar deadly conflicts over union workers’ rights.

 

While traditional religious language is often expected at cemeteries, it is prominent at this site in unexpected ways. For example, those who “have given their lives to the cause of clean unionism in America” are labeled as “martyrs” on a monument placard; Mother Jones is given the title, “The Miner’s Angel” on an engraved stone; and a Mother Jones quote at the bottom of a list of donors borrows language of Christian atonement theology, stating, “I learned in the early part of my career that labor must bear the cross for others’ sins, must be the vicarious sufferer for the wrongs that others do.”

While Mother Jones was raised in the Roman Catholic tradition, she is said to have later rejected organized religion which she believed caused workers to become complacent in this world because of its focus on the afterlife. Still, Mother Jones believed Jesus to be a revolutionary and a model for workers in their fight against wealthy “parasites,” and she befriended several clergymen with similar activist values (Rosemary Feurer, “Mother Jones: A Global History of Struggle and Remembrance, from Cork, Ireland to Illinois,” Illinois Heritage, May 2013, 30).

 

The Mother Jones Monument stands as a witness to the life of a woman who was committed to the struggle for labor rights and class justice, while at the same time revealing a background tension between an opioid religion and an activist religion, made apparent throughout the site in characteristic quotations from Mother Jones such as, “Pray for the dead and fight like hell for the living!”

 

Sources:

 

Rosemary Feurer, “Mother Jones: A Global History of Struggle and Remembrance, from Cork, Ireland to Illinois,” Illinois Heritage, May 2013, 28-33. 

“Who Was Mother Jones?” Mother Jones Museum, accessed July 29, 2024, https://www.motherjonesmuseum.org/who-was-mother-jones.
creator: F619Zx0aQZQ0b6OoHm9ORy7Hmlh1

title: Ermita de la Caridad
BodyText:
Just five miles south of Miami’s Little Havana, on the coast of Biscayne Bay, sits the conical-shaped National Shrine of Our Lady of Charity – what Thomas Tweed once described as "the sacred center of the Cuban Catholic community in exile” (Thomas Tweed, Our Lady of the Exile: Diasporic Religion at a Cuban Catholic Shrine in Miami, 1997, pg. 3).

The centerpiece of the site is located in the sanctuary, where behind the altar rests a doll-size figurine of Our Lady of Charity, wearing a fanned-out golden dress and illuminated from below. The figurine is positioned in a way that incorporates her into the stunning mural painted on the wall behind the altar, which extends from the floor of the altar to the ceiling. According to a brochure available at the shrine, the mural narrates the history of Cuban Catholicism. The mural includes 44 important figures in this history from 1492-1977, beginning with Christopher Columbus in the lower left corner, and culminating in an image of two angels carrying a Cuban flag at the top, which the brochure describes as a representation of “carrying the homeland to God.”

In 1997 Thomas Tweed published his extensive ethnographic study of the shrine to Our Lady of Charity, which offers in-depth information on the history of the shrine and its devotees in the 1990s. That being said, the shrine is not frozen in time, and messaging added to the exterior grounds of the site has been updated to include slogans from the 2021 protests in both Cuba and Miami, criticizing the Cuban socialist government. For example, the hashtag #SOSCuba, used to spread awareness of the protests on social media, is printed on a banner below the petition, Virgen de la Caridad, Salva a Cuba! (Virgin of Charity, Save Cuba!). Further, attached to the fence on the opposite side of the grounds is a phrase that can be seen on many flags hanging from balconies in Little Havana: Patria y Vida. This phrase comes from a reggaeton song which criticized the Cuban government and was adapted as the unofficial slogan of the 2021 protests. On the grounds of the shrine, this slogan has been further modified to include the word Dios, as it is written above an image of the Cuban flag and American flag, connected in the center by Our Lady of Charity: Dios: Patria y Vida (God: Homeland and Life).

Sources:

Anamaria Artemisa Sayre, “Explaining 'Patria Y Vida,' The Song That's Defined The Uprising In Cuba,” NPR, July 20, 2021, https://www.npr.org/sections/altlatino/2021/07/19/1017887993/explaining-patria-y-vida-the-cuban-song-defying-an-evil-revolution.

The Mural at the Shrine (Miami: National Shrine of Our Lady of Charity).

Thomas Tweed, Our Lady of the Exile: Diasporic Religion at a Cuban Catholic Shrine in Miami (New York: Oxford University Press), 1997.
creator: F619Zx0aQZQ0b6OoHm9ORy7Hmlh1

title: Ermita de la Caridad
BodyText:
Just five miles south of Miami’s Little Havana, on the coast of Biscayne Bay, sits the conical-shaped National Shrine of Our Lady of Charity – what Thomas Tweed once described as "the sacred center of the Cuban Catholic community in exile” (Thomas Tweed, Our Lady of the Exile: Diasporic Religion at a Cuban Catholic Shrine in Miami, 1997, pg. 3).

The centerpiece of the site is located in the sanctuary, where behind the altar rests a doll-size figurine of Our Lady of Charity, wearing a fanned-out golden dress and illuminated from below. The figurine is positioned in a way that incorporates her into the stunning mural painted on the wall behind the altar, which extends from the floor of the altar to the ceiling. According to a brochure available at the shrine, the mural narrates the history of Cuban Catholicism. The mural includes 44 important figures in this history from 1492-1977, beginning with Christopher Columbus in the lower left corner, and culminating in an image of two angels carrying a Cuban flag at the top, which the brochure describes as a representation of “carrying the homeland to God.”

In 1997 Thomas Tweed published his extensive ethnographic study of the shrine to Our Lady of Charity, which offers in-depth information on the history of the shrine and its devotees in the 1990s. That being said, the shrine is not frozen in time, and messaging added to the exterior grounds of the site has been updated to include slogans from the 2021 protests in both Cuba and Miami, criticizing the Cuban socialist government. For example, the hashtag #SOSCuba, used to spread awareness of the protests on social media, is printed on a banner below the petition, Virgen de la Caridad, Salva a Cuba! (Virgin of Charity, Save Cuba!). Further, attached to the fence on the opposite side of the grounds is a phrase that can be seen on many flags hanging from balconies in Little Havana: Patria y Vida. This phrase comes from a reggaeton song which criticized the Cuban government and was adapted as the unofficial slogan of the 2021 protests. On the grounds of the shrine, this slogan has been further modified to include the word Dios, as it is written above an image of the Cuban flag and American flag, connected in the center by Our Lady of Charity: Dios: Patria y Vida (God: Homeland and Life).

Sources:

Anamaria Artemisa Sayre, “Explaining 'Patria Y Vida,' The Song That's Defined The Uprising In Cuba,” NPR, July 20, 2021, https://www.npr.org/sections/altlatino/2021/07/19/1017887993/explaining-patria-y-vida-the-cuban-song-defying-an-evil-revolution.

The Mural at the Shrine (Miami: National Shrine of Our Lady of Charity).

Thomas Tweed, Our Lady of the Exile: Diasporic Religion at a Cuban Catholic Shrine in Miami (New York: Oxford University Press), 1997.

title: whatever
BodyText:
“Savage Saints” historiographically reconfigures “Muscular Christianity.” It studies the close and positive relations of martial arts and combat sports to Muscular Christianity, and it argues the central importance of the concept of “human nature” to Muscular Christian theology and practice.

Many have shown that the Muscular Christian movement took shape as a critical reaction against the perceived unhealthy and enfeebling ways of American culture. Decrying the physical stagnation of indoor life prompted by urban environs, the poor dietary customs of American foodways, and the general lack of play among both children and adults, the movement solidified as a large-scale Protestant “commitment to health and manliness.” My work refines this understanding of Muscular Christianity. Muscular Christianity was a response to various rumored cultural “crises”—particularly regarding health and manly vigor. More fundamentally, Muscular Christianity was (and continues to be) a rejoinder to America’s supposed divergence from Creation’s Purpose and Nature’s Laws. Muscular Christianity, then, was a natural theology that sought to correct unnatural modern ills by discerning and following a designed human plan. And the human design that Muscular Christians revealed was a violent one, wherein fighting was integral to “human nature”—an instinct placed within us that was both original and good.

Fighting was uniquely foundational for Muscular Christians. Cast as a natural act prior to and outside of an unnatural American civilization, fighting occupied a privileged place in Muscular Christian theory and praxis. Opposite the perceived “overcivilizing” trends of the nation—i.e. the culturally inflicted threats to health and manly vigor—fighting showcased “human nature” and God’s Creation in its purest form. Languid, impotent, and chronically ill Americans, so it went, had neglected the value of rough-and-tumble action. Combat sports and martial arts gave wayward Americans a rare glimpse into what was and what should be. Finding the Divine in the bellicose, Muscular Christians looked to the fighting arts as a socially curative and individually salvific countermeasure to American “overcivilization.” Filling a historiographic void, then, “Savage Saints” accounts for the Muscular Christian attraction to and use of combat sports and martial arts in the 20th-century United States. Muscular Christians readily advocated and took up Japanese jiu-jitsu at the turn of the century, boxing during and immediately after the First World War, judo, karate, and other eastern martial arts in the second half of the century, and mixed martial arts (MMA) from the 1990s to the present day. If sports and a newly emboldened physical culture defined Muscular Christianity’s restorative and revisionist program, fighting was clearly an essential component.

In the overall saga of Muscular Christianity and fighting, “human nature” was the primary protagonist and the praiseworthy hero. Pugnacious human nature was the God-given guide inside us. Physical aggression was the natural instinct created within. Employing the exemplary practices of martial arts and combat sports, Muscular Christians vested “bare life”—a life outside and before American civility—with a masculinized sense of primal bellicosity and theological meaning. As God created it—and as evident through fighting—human nature was virile and potentially savage. The Nature that American culture forgot was the Nature that Muscular Christianity sought to remember. Fisticuff knowledge was not lost to all, however. Muscular Christians often looked to culturally untainted youths, and more naturally attuned foreigners for ideas for living rightwise. Physically aggressive children and combat proficient eastern cultures were valued as those less subject to the detrimental effects of American overcivilization. Looking to children, eastern cultures, or within themselves, Muscular Christians fabricated a forceful instinct—the Word in the flesh. Americans, so it went, simply had to remember who they were—aggressive and physical—as they were made. By enabling special access to “human nature” through fighting, Muscular Christianity popularized masculinized notions of persons as originally, purposefully, and virtuously atavistic. With fighting as an instrumental practice, and with the quarrelsome Word as an inner guide, Muscular Christians constructed persons as godly barbaric selves, as savage saints.

title: 4th of July Parade, 2022
BodyText:
For nearly 40 years, breaking only for the pandemic, members of my extended family have been gathering with food and drinks at the North Avenue bridge over the Menomonee River to celebrate and watch the Fourth of July Parade in Wauwatosa, Wisconsin. “Tosa,” as it is familiarly called, is a predominately white middle-class suburb of Milwaukee (81.4% of residents are “non-Hispanic White”). As Wisconsin’s 14th largest city, Wauwatosa is relatively younger (median age of 37.9 years) and more educated (58.6% of adults hold a bachelor’s degree or higher) than both the state and national averages. Although Wisconsin is politically considered to be a “swing state,” like most of the cities in Milwaukee County, the majority of Wauwatosa residents reliably vote democrat in both local and national elections, with at least one-third still solidly republican.  

 

While the mood was jubilant and celebratory, the crowd was considerably more sparse in 2022 than those from my childhood days, when designated family members would have to camp out for hours to secure our coveted spot on the North Avenue bridge. In contrast, this year parking was ample and good parade-watching spots were plentiful, as the crowd was too thin to fill both sides of the street. Still, those in attendance were decked out in patriotic gear as many united with friends and family of all ages alongside their bloody mary bars and tables of food.

Before the parade began, a cheery gentleman was walking along the sidewalk handing something out to every person he saw. It was a fake “million dollar bill,” and on the back it said “In God We Trust,” and a paragraph that begins with, “THE MILLION DOLLAR QUESTION: Will you go to Heaven when you die?...” The paragraph ends by directing readers to visit “NeedGod.com” and “LivingWaters.com.”

The unofficial start to the parade was a group of Harley Davidson motorcycles with large American flags on the back. This was followed by a man and a woman who appeared to have jumped into a gap in the lineup carrying a sign that simply said “Jesus.” The man shouted, “Many signers of the Constitution were pastors who gave their lives and honor so that we could have our freedoms today. Trust in Jesus…” Hearing this, my aunt (a retired nurse) made a quick comment to me about how rights and freedoms were also taken away from indigenous people who had originally resided in the land; a comment that gave voice to the unexpressed tension of celebrating independence on stolen land named after its indigenous inhabitants.

The parade officially began with police motorcycles, a fire truck, and a float with Tripoli Shriner Veterans with about 10 American flags and a sign stating, “Honoring all Veterans” and another sign stating, “Please Stand For Your Flag.” Attendees pridefully stood and clapped. In full swing, the parade included high school bands, color guards, and dance teams; politicians; civic organizations; veterans’ organizations; businesses; and local media personalities.

Taking place just ten days after the overturning of Roe v. Wade in the Supreme Court Dobbs decision, there were subtle signs of patriotic protest in the parade. For example, one woman marching with the Girl Scouts wore a dress with an American flag design and peace sign earrings. She was carrying a small American flag, and written on her left arm were the words “Protect Women.” I saw this woman again later on as she was walking back from the end of the parade, and I noticed on her right arm was written, “I dissent.”

The phrase “I dissent” also appeared on a t-shirt worn by a man marching with the group that garnered the loudest applause from the crowd, called “Tosa Together.” Leading the group was a banner which stated, “Growing Equity & Diversity in Wauwatosa.” Other t-shirt statements included “Black Lives Matter - Wauwatosa” and “AntiRacist – Wauwatosa.” In addition to an American flag were rainbow flags and a Black Lives Matter flag. One person carried a sign written in English, Spanish, and Arabic which said: “No matter where you are from, we’re glad you’re our neighbor.” Another group passed by later on similarly promoting LGBT equality, led by a vehicle with a rainbow sign that read, “Free Mom Hugs.”

About halfway through the parade, two men were walking near the sidewalk, unaffiliated with the parade, handing out material to people. One of them was pushing a dolly with a box strapped to it which had a picture of the US on the front with a cross and the words, “This Great Nation was Founded on the GOSPEL of Jesus Christ.” On the side it read, “‘It is impossible to govern a nation without God and the Bible.’ - President George Washington.”

On the outside of the folder that contained the materials was written, “US Presidents Declare Christianity” with a list of alleged quotes from former presidents to defend this statement. The other side included claims that the United States was founded solely on the basis of Christianity, and the inside included a plea for America to return to its “Christian heritage.” The envelope inside the folder indicated that the church distributing the materials was Shalom Baptist Church in Brown Deer (another Milwaukee suburb). Also printed in red letters on the envelope were statements condemning homosexuality and abortion. Inside the envelope contained a slew of pamphlets, including several Chick tracts, one of which stoked fears that Islam is overtaking the United States and will bring an end to Christianity in America if not stopped.

While the representatives from Shalom Baptist Church had just inserted themselves into a gap in the parade, there were two churches that officially marched as participants in the parade. My aunt notified me early about the first group, suggesting to be on the lookout for “the Baptists” who always have the largest float in the parade. She was right. Before the arrival of the semi-truck carrying the float, were two women in their late teens wearing long skirts carrying a sign that said, “Big Dig,” which is the title of the upcoming Vacation Bible School at nearby Falls Baptist Church. The semi passed with loud and dramatic music playing, and on the semi was an archeological scene with several people on the float waving and an American flag in the center. As the float was driving past, I heard a man in the group next to us say, “Now that’s big church money.”

In comparison to the big money at Falls Baptist Church, the other church represented in the parade seemed pintsize. Wauwatosa Avenue United Methodist Church was one of the last organizations to march in the parade, carrying a sign that read, “Welcome Pastor Kate,” with children riding bikes adorned with flags. They handed out cards which provided information about the church, including that it is an inclusive “reconciling congregation” that welcomes all.

The parade ended somewhat abruptly with a car that carried two local TV news anchors. My family and I were confused about whether or not it was over, and we all were in agreement that this year’s parade was rather underwhelming compared to pre-pandemic years.

 

Despite its small size, the 2022 Wauwatosa Fourth of July parade still had some big things to say about religion, patriotism, and ideology in a midwestern swing state. While Christian nationalism was on full display by those who unofficially inserted themselves into the lineup, it appears to have been excluded by those city volunteers who organized the parade. This ultimately regulated the messaging to represent Wauwatosa as an open and inclusive community, which countered the anti-abortion, anti-LGBTQIA+, and anti-Muslim sentiments included in materials from sideline entries like Shalom Baptist Church.

 

While patriotism was everywhere, it seemed to carry different meanings for different organizations. For some it was pride in storied origins and an argument to return to better days, while for others it was pride in progress and fuel for positive change, and it was clear that Wauwatosa city leaders were driving for the latter. Still, I am left wondering about the effects of those who entered into the parade on the margins – did their messages of Christian nationalism appeal to, or even radicalize, any parade-goers who may have felt concerned about the declining attendance and rising progressive tone of this beloved annual tradition?

 

Sources 

“About Wauwatosa,” City of Wauwatosa, WI, accessed August 10, 2024, https://www.wauwatosa.net/discover-tosa/about-wauwatosa. 

“Election Results,” City of Wauwatosa, WI, accessed August 10, 2024, https://www.wauwatosa.net/government/departments/city-clerk/elections-voting/election-results. 

Allie Habeck, “Comparing How the City and Every Milwaukee County Suburb Voted in 2016 and 2020,” Milwaukee Magazine, November 4, 2020, https://www.milwaukeemag.com/comparing-how-the-city-and-every-milwaukee-county-suburb-voted-in-2016-and-2020/.
creator: F619Zx0aQZQ0b6OoHm9ORy7Hmlh1
