Trust in Jesus…” Hearing this, my aunt (a retired nurse) made a quick comment to me about how rights and freedoms were also taken away from indigenous people who had originally resided in the land; a comment that gave voice to the unexpressed tension of celebrating independence on stolen land named after its indigenous inhabitants.

The parade officially began with police motorcycles, a fire truck, and a float with Tripoli Shriner Veterans with about 10 American flags and a sign stating, “Honoring all Veterans” and another sign stating, “Please Stand For Your Flag.” Attendees pridefully stood and clapped. In full swing, the parade included high school bands, color guards, and dance teams; politicians; civic organizations; veterans’ organizations; businesses; and local media personalities.

Taking place just ten days after the overturning of Roe v. Wade in the Supreme Court Dobbs decision, there were subtle signs of patriotic protest in the parade. For example, one woman marching with the Girl Scouts wore a dress with an American flag design and peace sign earrings. She was carrying a small American flag, and written on her left arm were the words “Protect Women.” I saw this woman again later on as she was walking back from the end of the parade, and I noticed on her right arm was written, “I dissent.”

The phrase “I dissent” also appeared on a t-shirt worn by a man marching with the group that garnered the loudest applause from the crowd, called “Tosa Together.” Leading the group was a banner which stated, “Growing Equity & Diversity in Wauwatosa.” Other t-shirt statements included “Black Lives Matter - Wauwatosa” and “AntiRacist – Wauwatosa.” In addition to an American flag were rainbow flags and a Black Lives Matter flag. One person carried a sign written in English, Spanish, and Arabic which said: “No matter where you are from, we’re glad you’re our neighbor.” Another group passed by later on similarly promoting LGBT equality, led by a vehicle with a rainbow sign that read, “Free Mom Hugs.”

About halfway through the parade, two men were walking near the sidewalk, unaffiliated with the parade, handing out material to people. One of them was pushing a dolly with a box strapped to it which had a picture of the US on the front with a cross and the words, “This Great Nation was Founded on the GOSPEL of Jesus Christ.” On the side it read, “‘It is impossible to govern a nation without God and the Bible.’ - President George Washington.”

On the outside of the folder that contained the materials was written, “US Presidents Declare Christianity” with a list of alleged quotes from former presidents to defend this statement. The other side included claims that the United States was founded solely on the basis of Christianity, and the inside included a plea for America to return to its “Christian heritage.” The envelope inside the folder indicated that the church distributing the materials was Shalom Baptist Church in Brown Deer (another Milwaukee suburb). Also printed in red letters on the envelope were statements condemning homosexuality and abortion. Inside the envelope contained a slew of pamphlets, including several Chick tracts, one of which stoked fears that Islam is overtaking the United States and will bring an end to Christianity in America if not stopped.

While the representatives from Shalom Baptist Church had just inserted themselves into a gap in the parade, there were two churches that officially marched as participants in the parade. My aunt notified me early about the first group, suggesting to be on the lookout for “the Baptists” who always have the largest float in the parade. She was right. Before the arrival of the semi-truck carrying the float, were two women in their late teens wearing long skirts carrying a sign that said, “Big Dig,” which is the title of the upcoming Vacation Bible School at nearby Falls Baptist Church. The semi passed with loud and dramatic music playing, and on the semi was an archeological scene with several people on the float waving and an American flag in the center. As the float was driving past, I heard a man in the group next to us say, “Now that’s big church money.”

In comparison to the big money at Falls Baptist Church, the other church represented in the parade seemed pintsize. Wauwatosa Avenue United Methodist Church was one of the last organizations to march in the parade, carrying a sign that read, “Welcome Pastor Kate,” with children riding bikes adorned with flags. They handed out cards which provided information about the church, including that it is an inclusive “reconciling congregation” that welcomes all.

The parade ended somewhat abruptly with a car that carried two local TV news anchors. My family and I were confused about whether or not it was over, and we all were in agreement that this year’s parade was rather underwhelming compared to pre-pandemic years.

 

Despite its small size, the 2022 Wauwatosa Fourth of July parade still had some big things to say about religion, patriotism, and ideology in a midwestern swing state. While Christian nationalism was on full display by those who unofficially inserted themselves into the lineup, it appears to have been excluded by those city volunteers who organized the parade. This ultimately regulated the messaging to represent Wauwatosa as an open and inclusive community, which countered the anti-abortion, anti-LGBTQIA+, and anti-Muslim sentiments included in materials from sideline entries like Shalom Baptist Church.

 

While patriotism was everywhere, it seemed to carry different meanings for different organizations. For some it was pride in storied origins and an argument to return to better days, while for others it was pride in progress and fuel for positive change, and it was clear that Wauwatosa city leaders were driving for the latter. Still, I am left wondering about the effects of those who entered into the parade on the margins – did their messages of Christian nationalism appeal to, or even radicalize, any parade-goers who may have felt concerned about the declining attendance and rising progressive tone of this beloved annual tradition?

 

Sources 

“About Wauwatosa,” City of Wauwatosa, WI, accessed August 10, 2024, https://www.wauwatosa.net/discover-tosa/about-wauwatosa. 

“Election Results,” City of Wauwatosa, WI, accessed August 10, 2024, https://www.wauwatosa.net/government/departments/city-clerk/elections-voting/election-results. 

Allie Habeck, “Comparing How the City and Every Milwaukee County Suburb Voted in 2016 and 2020,” Milwaukee Magazine, November 4, 2020, https://www.milwaukeemag.com/comparing-how-the-city-and-every-milwaukee-county-suburb-voted-in-2016-and-2020/.

title: 4th of July Parade, 2022
BodyText:
For nearly 40 years, breaking only for the pandemic, members of my extended family have been gathering with food and drinks at the North Avenue bridge over the Menomonee River to celebrate and watch the Fourth of July Parade in Wauwatosa, Wisconsin. “Tosa,” as it is familiarly called, is a predominately white middle-class suburb of Milwaukee (81.4% of residents are “non-Hispanic White”). As Wisconsin’s 14th largest city, Wauwatosa is relatively younger (median age of 37.9 years) and more educated (58.6% of adults hold a bachelor’s degree or higher) than both the state and national averages. Although Wisconsin is politically considered to be a “swing state,” like most of the cities in Milwaukee County, the majority of Wauwatosa residents reliably vote democrat in both local and national elections, with at least one-third still solidly republican.  

 

While the mood was jubilant and celebratory, the crowd was considerably more sparse in 2022 than those from my childhood days, when designated family members would have to camp out for hours to secure our coveted spot on the North Avenue bridge. In contrast, this year parking was ample and good parade-watching spots were plentiful, as the crowd was too thin to fill both sides of the street. Still, those in attendance were decked out in patriotic gear as many united with friends and family of all ages alongside their bloody mary bars and tables of food.

About halfway through the parade, two men were walking near the sidewalk, unaffiliated with the parade, handing out material to people. One of them was pushing a dolly with a box strapped to it which had a picture of the US on the front with a cross and the words, “This Great Nation was Founded on the GOSPEL of Jesus Christ.” On the side it read, “‘It is impossible to govern a nation without God and the Bible.’ - President George Washington.”

title: Wynwood Street Art
BodyText:
Driving down I-95 in Miami, Florida, just two miles south of Little Haiti, it is nearly impossible to miss the now iconic image of three young people of color towering over the trendy Miami neighborhood of Wynwood. The mural entirely covers two adjacent walls of the Wynwood 25 building (a large apartment complex), and snakes around the corner, spilling onto a third wall. The scene is tranquil, as the two outside individuals are each pictured holding a rose with a halo-like ring of roses around their faces, and the third has his hands raised in a prayer-like position.

This mural, one of the largest permanent murals in Wynwood, gives the passerby a small taste of what they would encounter if they exited the freeway and entered into this Instagrammable art district. Walking the streets of Wynwood can quickly bring about a feeling of sensory overload. The area smells of stale beer, cigarettes, weed, and street food; there is a constant chattering among drivers through the vocalization of their car horns; Latin and hip-hop music can be heard from every direction; and every inch of building, sidewalk, and light post is covered with murals, graffiti, stickers, and stencils.

The style and subject of the art varies, with many neutral murals seemingly commissioned by local business owners to add style to their buildings.

More overt religious imagery can be seen throughout the area, including a Bible verse accompanying the commemoration of a life lost, stencils of rosaries and doves, and a transmuting image that connects the concepts of protest and prayer.

Overt cultural commentary is also often depicted, with critiques of consumerism, capitalism, and gun violence.

The artist who spraypainted the earlier-referenced iconic mural that beckons onlookers from I-95, El Mac, offers some insight into the mind of a Wynwood street artist in his blog post written about the mural. The piece is titled “A Love Supreme (Wynwood Saints),” and the young folks in the mural depict three local figures who El Mac chose as expressive of the neighborhood, portraying “monumental, everyday saints—prayerful, resilient, and representative of upliftment, beauty, and loving kindness.”

 

El Mac describes the act of art and painting as an act of prayer, and he states that he hopes his art can ultimately be a force for good. Further, El Mac states, “I strongly feel that the creation of art can be, at its best, a spiritual vocation, a means of responding to the world in service of truth, beauty, and goodness.”

El Mac stated that he wanted his mural to be “something representative of this place, its history, and its people, while conveying strength, dignity, balance, solidarity, and love.” El Mac wrote about how much Wynwood had changed since his first mural in the area back in 2007, but he stopped short of using the word that many critics have come to use to describe Wynwood – gentrification.

 

A quick glance at local news and editorial stories reveals a common narrative about Wynwood: What was once a largely Puerto Rican community known as “Little San Juan,” the area was hit by poverty and began to fall into disrepair. Taking advantage of the cheap building costs, artists began to settle in the area at the turn of the twenty-first century and galleries were assembled, forming a vibrant artistic community. Noticing the rising popularity of the area, developers swooped in, building luxury apartments and condos, and bringing in upscale restaurants and nightclubs. Rising rents have now priced out many of the area’s former inhabitants, including many artists, and Wynwood is now a popular stop on Miami bus tours, with upwards of $40 cover charges at many of its crowded bars and clubs.

There is a complex and uncomfortable relationship between street art and gentrification, particularly in the age of Instagram, which can quickly popularize sites of beauty, insight, and oddity. This brings a sort of irony to those murals critiquing capitalism, as the very existence of these murals plays a role in perpetuating gentrification, which exemplifies the capitalist impact on urban areas. The entanglement of art and capitalism, much like that of religion and capitalism, seems almost inescapable; despite occasional noble intentions, the outcomes of these intersections are often problematic and far-reaching.

 

As for El Mac, it is interesting to note that his iconic Wynwood mural was commissioned by The Related Group – a Miami development company owned by Jorge Pérez, who is often called the “luxury-condo king of Miami” and the “Donald Trump of the tropics.” Still, El Mac has stated his commitment to the Wynwood community. Although he does not use the term “gentrification” explicitly, in his blog post, he links a video which documents the neighborhood's gentrification. Further, El Mac seems to offer a veiled acknowledgement of his own discomfort with his developer alliance and the irony of his mural’s role in Wynwood’s gentrification through his choice of quote to accompany the mural’s description, taken from Leonard Cohen’s novel, Beautiful Losers:

 

"What is a saint? A saint is someone who has achieved a remote human possibility. It is impossible to say what that possibility is. I think it has something to do with the energy of love. Contact with this energy results in the exercise of a kind of balance in the chaos of existence. A saint does not dissolve the chaos; if he did the world would have changed long ago. I do not think that a saint dissolves the chaos even for himself, for there is something arrogant and warlike in the notion of a man setting the universe in order. It is a kind of balance that is his glory... Something in him so loves the world that he gives himself to the laws of gravity and chance. Far from flying with the angels, he traces with the fidelity of a seismograph needle the state of the solid bloody landscape."

Sources

Álvarez, Camila and Natalie Edgar. “Right to Wynwood.” November 10, 2013. Miami: R17 and Meraki Media. Vimeo. https://vimeo.com/110682099.

 

Drake, Carolina Ana. “Miami-Based Artists and Arts Organisations Grapple with Gentrification.” The Art Newspaper. December 8, 2023, https://www.theartnewspaper.com/2023/12/08/miami-based-artists-and-arts-organisations-grapple-with-gentrification.

 

El Mac. “New El Mac Murals in Miami: ‘A Love Supreme (Wynwood Saints).’” Blogspot. May 18, 2020, https://mac-arte.blogspot.com/2020/05/new-el-mac-murals-in-miami-love-supreme.html.

 

Pasols, Aaliyah. “Gentrification Complete: Will Wynwood's Progress Be Its Downfall?” Miami New Times. October 5, 2021, https://www.miaminewtimes.com/music/history-wynwood-miami-gentrification-13066720.

 

Patel, Shaan. “Wynwood, A Story of Instagram Gentrification.” Miami Grid. March 3, 2019, https://miami-grid.com/2019/03/03/wynwood-instagram-gentrification/.

 

Sokol, Brett. “Friends No More? Jorge Pérez and Donald Trump.” The New York Times. February 17, 2017, https://www.nytimes.com/2017/02/17/arts/design/friends-no-more-jorge-perez-and-donald-trump.html.

El Mac describes the act of art and painting as an act of prayer, and he states that he hopes his art can ultimately be a force for good. Further, El Mac states, “I strongly feel that the creation of art can be, at its best, a spiritual vocation, a means of responding to the world in service of truth, beauty, and goodness.”

El Mac stated that he wanted his mural to be “something representative of this place, its history, and its people, while conveying strength, dignity, balance, solidarity, and love.” El Mac wrote about how much Wynwood had changed since his first mural in the area back in 2007, but he stopped short of using the word that many critics have come to use to describe Wynwood – gentrification.

 

A quick glance at local news and editorial stories reveals a common narrative about Wynwood: What was once a largely Puerto Rican community known as “Little San Juan,” the area was hit by poverty and began to fall into disrepair. Taking advantage of the cheap building costs, artists began to settle in the area at the turn of the twenty-first century and galleries were assembled, forming a vibrant artistic community. Noticing the rising popularity of the area, developers swooped in, building luxury apartments and condos, and bringing in upscale restaurants and nightclubs. Rising rents have now priced out many of the area’s former inhabitants, including many artists, and Wynwood is now a popular stop on Miami bus tours, with upwards of $40 cover charges at many of its crowded bars and clubs.

There is a complex and uncomfortable relationship between street art and gentrification, particularly in the age of Instagram, which can quickly popularize sites of beauty, insight, and oddity. This brings a sort of irony to those murals critiquing capitalism, as the very existence of these murals plays a role in perpetuating gentrification, which exemplifies the capitalist impact on urban areas. The entanglement of art and capitalism, much like that of religion and capitalism, seems almost inescapable; despite occasional noble intentions, the outcomes of these intersections are often problematic and far-reaching.

 

As for El Mac, it is interesting to note that his iconic Wynwood mural was commissioned by The Related Group – a Miami development company owned by Jorge Pérez, who is often called the “luxury-condo king of Miami” and the “Donald Trump of the tropics.” Still, El Mac has stated his commitment to the Wynwood community. Although he does not use the term “gentrification” explicitly, in his blog post, he links a video which documents the neighborhood's gentrification. Further, El Mac seems to offer a veiled acknowledgement of his own discomfort with his developer alliance and the irony of his mural’s role in Wynwood’s gentrification through his choice of quote to accompany the mural’s description, taken from Leonard Cohen’s novel, Beautiful Losers:

 

"What is a saint? A saint is someone who has achieved a remote human possibility. It is impossible to say what that possibility is. I think it has something to do with the energy of love. Contact with this energy results in the exercise of a kind of balance in the chaos of existence. A saint does not dissolve the chaos; if he did the world would have changed long ago. I do not think that a saint dissolves the chaos even for himself, for there is something arrogant and warlike in the notion of a man setting the universe in order. It is a kind of balance that is his glory... Something in him so loves the world that he gives himself to the laws of gravity and chance. Far from flying with the angels, he traces with the fidelity of a seismograph needle the state of the solid bloody landscape."

Sources

Álvarez, Camila and Natalie Edgar. “Right to Wynwood.” November 10, 2013. Miami: R17 and Meraki Media. Vimeo. https://vimeo.com/110682099.

 

Drake, Carolina Ana. “Miami-Based Artists and Arts Organisations Grapple with Gentrification.” The Art Newspaper. December 8, 2023, https://www.theartnewspaper.com/2023/12/08/miami-based-artists-and-arts-organisations-grapple-with-gentrification.

 

El Mac. “New El Mac Murals in Miami: ‘A Love Supreme (Wynwood Saints).’” Blogspot. May 18, 2020, https://mac-arte.blogspot.com/2020/05/new-el-mac-murals-in-miami-love-supreme.html.

 

Pasols, Aaliyah. “Gentrification Complete: Will Wynwood's Progress Be Its Downfall?” Miami New Times. October 5, 2021, https://www.miaminewtimes.com/music/history-wynwood-miami-gentrification-13066720.

 

Patel, Shaan. “Wynwood, A Story of Instagram Gentrification.” Miami Grid. March 3, 2019, https://miami-grid.com/2019/03/03/wynwood-instagram-gentrification/.

 

Sokol, Brett. “Friends No More? Jorge Pérez and Donald Trump.” The New York Times. February 17, 2017, https://www.nytimes.com/2017/02/17/arts/design/friends-no-more-jorge-perez-and-donald-trump.html.

title: Catholic Figures Facing the Street in Williamsburg
BodyText: It's interesting that some of the windowsills in New York City have religious statues facing the street rather than, expectedly, inside the home. For some, it is done to protect the home from vandals and those who wish to harm. For some, it serves to remind the passers by of godliness.

title: Bando Station - Start of the Henro Michi
BodyText:
This is an updated note for Bando Station.

This small train station is the main starting point for the "Green Line," a green painted line on the pavement guiding henro (pilgrims) from the station to the main gate of Ryozen-ji, Temple No. 1 on the Shikoku Pilgrimage. Henro in their white gear are a common sight on the local trains coming from Tokushima Station, especially during the spring pilgrimage season. As more visitors from countries outside Japan come to Shikoku to participate in the henro michi, support in the form of signs in English and other languages is growing, but it still can be difficult to navigate comfortably without some knowledge of Japanese. Both local people and other pilgrims are generally helpful, and will try to assist with guidance to the correct pathways and temple entrances.
creator: KHAHfSWMJ6SshJHmk81TXGOPUzI3

title: Disney Animal Kingdom "Asian Religion"
BodyText:
"Asia" exhibits at Walt Disney World's Animal Kingdom theme park outside of Orlando, Florida.

There is a long and fraught history of representing religion in American exhibitions and theme parks. Late-nineteenth and early-twentieth-century worlds fairs, for instance, were hotbeds of colonialist representations of Asian and indigenous religions, often casting them as "primitive" or otherwise as inferior to "enlightened" Protestantism. Disney World has long participated in representations of religion that are built on appropriated imagery and racialized tropes. The representations of Tibetan and Nepalese religion at Disney's Animal Kingdom theme park are presented as authentic replicas of religious objects. This performative authenticity of Buddhas, stupas, and puja shrines are nevertheless situated in an environment that is created for consumerist entertainment--it is a theme park, after all--not Buddhist contemplation or religious practice. Why was it important to park designers--"imagineers"--to include religious iconography in the queues for roller coasters and water rides? What work are these objects doing to and upon patrons and employees?

Video 1
creator: 8H86gZYSFIRHGy8q39OgBAfQFeC2

import React, { useEffect, useState, useRef } from "react";import { Alert, View, TextInput, TouchableOpacity, SafeAreaView, Keyboard, Platform, KeyboardAvoidingView, Modal, Text, StyleSheet} from "react-native";import { WebViewMessageEvent } from "react-native-webview";import * as Location from 'expo-location';import ToastMessage from 'react-native-toast-message';import { Ionicons } from "@expo/vector-icons";import { Media, AudioType } from "../models/media_class";import { getThumbnail } from "../utils/S3_proxy";import { User } from "../models/user_class";import ApiService from "../utils/api_calls";import PhotoScroller from "../components/photoScroller";import AudioContainer from "../components/audio";import TagWindow from "../components/tagging";import LocationWindow from "../components/location";import TimeWindow from "../components/time";import { DEFAULT_TOOLBAR_ITEMS, RichText, Toolbar, useEditorBridge } from "@10play/tentap-editor";import NotePageStyles, { customImageCSS } from "../../styles/pages/NoteStyles";import { useTheme } from "../components/ThemeProvider";import LoadingModal from "../components/LoadingModal";import { KeyboardAwareScrollView } from 'react-native-keyboard-aware-scroll-view';import { Video } from "expo-av";import { Link } from "@react-navigation/native";const user = User.getInstance();const AddNoteScreen: React.FC<{ navigation: any, route: any }> = ({ navigation, route }) => { const [titleText, setTitleText] = useState<string>(""); const [isSaveButtonEnabled, setIsSaveButtonEnabled] = useState<boolean>(true); const [bodyText, setBodyText] = useState<string>(""); const [newMedia, setNewMedia] = useState<Media[]>([]); const [newAudio, setNewAudio] = useState<AudioType[]>([]); const [tags, setTags] = useState<string[]>([]); const [time, setTime] = useState<Date>(new Date()); const [viewMedia, setViewMedia] = useState<boolean>(false); const [viewAudio, setViewAudio] = useState<boolean>(false); const [isTagging, setIsTagging] = useState<boolean>(false); const [isLocation, setIsLocation] = useState<boolean>(false); const [isTime, setIsTime] = useState<boolean>(false); const [isPublished, setIsPublished] = useState<boolean>(false); const [location, setLocation] = useState<{ latitude: number, longitude: number } | null>(null); const [isUpdating, setIsUpdating] = useState<boolean>(false); const [isVideoModalVisible, setIsVideoModalVisible] = useState<boolean>(false); const [videoUri, setVideoUri] = useState<string | null>(null); const editor = useEditorBridge({ initialContent: bodyText || "", autofocus: true, avoidIosKeyboard: true, }); const { theme } = useTheme(); const titleTextRef = useRef<TextInput>(null); const scrollViewRef = useRef<KeyboardAwareScrollView>(null); useEffect(() => { if (editor?.focus) { const timeout = setTimeout(() => { editor.focus(); }, 500); return () => clearTimeout(timeout); } }, [editor]); useEffect(() => { if (editor) { editor.injectCSS(customImageCSS); } }, [editor]); const toggleLocationVisibility = async () => { if (isLocation) { setLocation({ latitude: 0, longitude: 0 }); setIsLocation(false); } else { try { const { status } = await Location.getForegroundPermissionsAsync(); if (status !== 'granted') { const { status: requestStatus } = await Location.requestForegroundPermissionsAsync(); if (requestStatus !== 'granted') { Alert.alert("Location permission denied", "Please enable location permissions to use this feature."); return; } } const userLocation = await Location.getCurrentPositionAsync({}); if (userLocation) { setLocation({ latitude: userLocation.coords.latitude, longitude: userLocation.coords.longitude, }); setIsLocation(true); } } catch (error) { console.error("Error fetching location:", error); Alert.alert("Error", "Failed to retrieve location. Please try again."); } } }; const insertImageToEditor = async (imageUri: string) => { if (editor && editor.setContent) { console.log("Inserting image with URI at cursor:", imageUri); try { const currentContent = await editor.getHTML(); const imageTag = <img src="${imageUri}" style="max-width: 200px; max-height: 200px; object-fit: cover;" /><br />; const newContent = currentContent + imageTag; editor.setContent(newContent); editor.focus(); } catch (error) { console.error("Error retrieving editor content:", error); } } else { console.error("Editor or setContent method is not available."); } }; const addVideoToEditor = async (videoUri: string) => { if (editor?.setContent && editor?.getHTML) { try { // Get the current content from the editor const currentContent = await editor.getHTML(); // Create the new video link with line breaks for spacing const videoLink = ${currentContent}<a href="${videoUri}">${videoUri}</a><br>; // Set the combined content back to the editor editor.setContent(videoLink); editor.focus(); } catch (error) { console.error("Error adding video link to editor:", error); } } else { console.error("Editor instance is not available."); } }; const insertAudioToEditor = async (audioUri: string) => { if (editor?.setContent && editor?.getHTML) { try { // Get the current content from the editor const currentContent = await editor.getHTML(); // Create the new audio link with line breaks for spacing const audioLink = ${currentContent}<a href="${audioUri}">${audioUri}</a><br>; // Set the combined content back to the editor editor.setContent(audioLink); editor.focus(); } catch (error) { console.error("Error adding audio link to editor:", error); } } else { console.error("Editor instance is not available."); } }; const handleShareButtonPress = async () => { setIsPublished(!isPublished);ToastMessage.show({ type: 'success', text1: isPublished ? 'Note Unpublished' : 'Note Published', visibilityTime: 3000, }); await saveNote(); }; const saveNote = async () => { console.log("Back button pressed - saveNote function invoked."); setIsUpdating(true); setIsSaveButtonEnabled(true); try { const userLocation = await Location.getCurrentPositionAsync({}); const finalLocation = userLocation ? userLocation.coords : { latitude: 0, longitude: 0 }; const textContent = await editor.getHTML(); const sanitizedContent = textContent.replace(/<\/?p>/g, ''); // removes <p> tags from content const uid = await user.getId(); const newNote = { title: titleText || "Untitled", text: sanitizedContent, media: newMedia || [], audio: newAudio || [], tags: tags || [], latitude: finalLocation.latitude.toString(), longitude: finalLocation.longitude.toString(), published: isPublished, time: new Date(time).toISOString(), creator: uid, }; const response = await ApiService.writeNewNote(newNote); await response.json(); route.params.refreshPage(); navigation.goBack(); } catch (error) { console.error("Error saving the note:", error); } finally { setIsUpdating(false); } }; return ( <SafeAreaView style={{ flex: 1 }}> <KeyboardAvoidingView behavior={Platform.OS === "ios" ? "share" : "share-outline"} size={30} color={NotePageStyles().saveText.color} /> </TouchableOpacity> </View> <View style={NotePageStyles().keyContainer}> <TouchableOpacity onPress={() => setViewMedia(!viewMedia)}> <Ionicons name="images-outline" size={30} color={NotePageStyles().saveText.color} /> </TouchableOpacity> <TouchableOpacity onPress={() => setViewAudio(!viewAudio)}> <Ionicons name="mic-outline" size={30} color={NotePageStyles().saveText.color} /> </TouchableOpacity> <TouchableOpacity onPress={toggleLocationVisibility}> <Ionicons name="location-outline" size={30} color={NotePageStyles().saveText.color} /> </TouchableOpacity> <TouchableOpacity onPress={() => setIsTime(!isTime)}> <Ionicons name="time-outline" size={30} color={NotePageStyles().saveText.color} /> </TouchableOpacity> <TouchableOpacity onPress={() => setIsTagging(!isTagging)}> <Ionicons name="pricetag-outline" size={30} color={NotePageStyles().saveText.color} /> </TouchableOpacity> </View> </View> <View style={NotePageStyles().container}> <PhotoScroller active={viewMedia} newMedia={newMedia} setNewMedia={setNewMedia} insertImageToEditor={insertImageToEditor} addVideoToEditor={addVideoToEditor} /> {viewAudio && ( <AudioContainer newAudio={newAudio} setNewAudio={setNewAudio} insertAudioToEditor={insertAudioToEditor} /> )} {isTagging && <TagWindow tags={tags} setTags={setTags} />} {isLocation && <LocationWindow location={location} setLocation={setLocation} />} {isTime && <TimeWindow time={time} setTime={setTime} />} </View> <View style={NotePageStyles().richTextContainer}> <RichText editor={editor} placeholder="Write Content Here..." style={[ NotePageStyles().editor, { backgroundColor: Platform.OS === "android" ? "white" : undefined }, ]} /> </View> <View style={NotePageStyles().toolBar}> <Toolbar editor={editor} items={DEFAULT_TOOLBAR_ITEMS} /> </View> {Platform.OS === 'ios' && ( <Toolbar editor={editor} items={DEFAULT_TOOLBAR_ITEMS} /> )} </View> </KeyboardAwareScrollView> {/* Video Player Modal */} <Modal animationType="slide" transparent={true} visible={isVideoModalVisible} onRequestClose={() => setIsVideoModalVisible(false)} > <View style={styles.modalOverlay}> <View style={styles.modalContent}> {videoUri && ( <Video source={{ uri: videoUri }} useNativeControls resizeMode="contain" style={styles.videoPlayer} /> )} <TouchableOpacity onPress={() => setIsVideoModalVisible(false)}> <Text style={styles.closeButton}>Close</Text> </TouchableOpacity> </View> </View> </Modal> <LoadingModal visible={isUpdating} /> </KeyboardAvoidingView> </SafeAreaView> );};export default AddNoteScreen;const styles = StyleSheet.create({ modalOverlay: { flex: 1, justifyContent: "center", alignItems: "center", backgroundColor: "rgba(0, 0, 0, 0.5)", }, modalContent: { width: "90%", padding: 20, backgroundColor: "white", borderRadius: 10, alignItems: "center", }, videoPlayer: { width: "100%", height: 200, }, closeButton: { color: "blue", marginTop: 20, },});

title: Tatsue Station - Walk to Temple 19
BodyText: Tatsue Station, on the JR Mugi Line, is the closest train station to Temples No. 18 (Onzan-ji) and No. 19 (Tatsue-ji). Temple 19 is quite close to the station and a short, flat walk toward the Tatsue River.The station is typical of more rural areas, as it is unmanned.

title: Sikhs of St. Louis w/ Starbucks Foodshare
BodyText:
This sticker on a Starbucks pastry display case signals Sikh participation in the charitable economy in the St. Louis metro region. Sikhi developed in the Punjab region of the Indian subcontinent in the 16th century and is now a major religion throughout the world, largely through Indian diaspora communities. Seva, often translated as service to others without regard for personal benefit, is central to Sikh devotional practice. This photograph was taken during Starbucks’ holiday marketing season, which aligns with the western Christian religious calendar, prompting reflection on the subtle forms of religious pluralism in modern life.

For an introduction on Sikhi beliefs and practices through the experiences of an American-born Sikh, see Simran Jeet Singh, The Light We Give (2022).
creator: 8H86gZYSFIRHGy8q39OgBAfQFeC2

title: Car/walking Directional Sign
BodyText:
As the number of henro participating in the Shikoku Pilgrimage has increased, signage in Japanese and English (and sometimes other languages) has been installed in many areas to try to direct pilgrims and visitors unfamiliar with the area.

This sign, on the journey between Temple 4 and Temple, directs both walking henro and those traveling by car.

title: Church mouse traffic box?
BodyText: On a busy intersection in Columbia, Missouri, an ordinary traffic box has become an installation of public art incorporating medieval architectural motifs consistent with those found throughout western Christianity. The cathedral “windows” open up to an unpeopled streetscape that includes at least one steeple. Each window has an occupant: a mouse looks “outward” from its perch while, in another window, a lounging cat faces “inward” to catch the gaze of passersby. This street corner is adjacent to the campuses of the University of Missouri and Stephens College. Aromas from nearby restaurants representing cuisines from around the world and the bustle of foot traffic along this college town street are poignant juxtapositions to the traffic box’s imagined landscape.
creator: 8H86gZYSFIRHGy8q39OgBAfQFeC2

title: Walk to Temple 16 (Kanonji)
BodyText: For walking henro, the journey between Temple 15 (Awa Kokubunji) and Temple 16 (Kanonji) requires walking along roads in a rural setting, along a highway, and through narrow extra urban streets. Along the route, various signs and waymarkers help to guide walking henro, as well as those traveling by car.

title: Temple 3 Hondo
BodyText: The main courtyard and hondo (main hall) at Temple 3 (Konsenji). This temple was fairly quiet, with only a few visitors and henro during our visit. As walking henro move away from Temple 1, the numbers tend to spread out. Henro and visitors traveling by car or tour bus also move through subsequent temples well before those who are walking between.
creator: KHAHfSWMJ6SshJHmk81TXGOPUzI3

title: Temple 4 Rules
BodyText:
As the Shikoku Pilgrimage temples have welcomed an increasing number of visitors and henro (pilgrims) from around the world, including many who do not speak Japanese, some temples have made efforts to create multilingual signage and provide clear guidance on proper behavior and etiquette within the temple grounds.

This example from Temple 4 (Dainichiji) illustrates such efforts, featuring bilingual signage in Japanese and English. The sign not only helps visitors navigate the temple facilities, such as the dedicated parking area for pilgrims, but also outlines rules and etiquette to ensure respect for the sacred space. These initiatives make the pilgrimage more accessible and create a welcoming experience for international participants.

The content of the sign provides information about the No. 4 Dainichi-ji Temple ONLY Pilgrimage Parking Lot and outlines the following policies and guidelines:

  1. Private Management:
    The temple property is privately managed, and visitors are required to follow the listed conditions.

  2. Restricted Access:

    • Only pilgrims are allowed to enter the property during the temple's official opening hours (8:00 AM to 5:00 PM).

    • The parking lot is exclusively for pilgrims.

  3. No Responsibility for Accidents:
    The temple is not responsible for any accidents, damage, or injuries occurring on the property.

  4. Prohibited Activities:

    • Parking or driving vehicles other than for pilgrimage purposes.

    • Camping or overnight stays in the parking lot.

    • Smoking on temple premises.

    • Leaving garbage.

    • Entry of pets into the temple grounds.

    • Handling plants or flowers inappropriately.

  5. Stamp Office Hours:
    The nōkyō-sho (stamp office) is open from 8:00 AM to 5:00 PM daily.

This sign demonstrates the temple’s efforts to maintain order, ensure safety, and promote respectful behavior among visitors and pilgrims,
creator: KHAHfSWMJ6SshJHmk81TXGOPUzI3

title: Temple 5 - Kukai Statue
BodyText: Each temple on the Shikoku Pilgrimage has a statue of Kukai, such as this example at Temple 5 (Jizoji)
creator: KHAHfSWMJ6SshJHmk81TXGOPUzI3

title: Temple 5 - Statue
BodyText: Each temple on the Shikoku Pilgrimage features a statue of Kūkai (Kōbō Daishi), honoring the revered founder of Shingon Buddhism and the pilgrimage itself. This particular statue, located at Temple 5 (Jizōji), exemplifies the profound respect and devotion that Kūkai inspires among pilgrims. These statues serve not only as symbols of his enduring spiritual legacy but also as focal points for reflection and prayer along the sacred journey.
creator: KHAHfSWMJ6SshJHmk81TXGOPUzI3

title: Temple 4 - Dainichi
BodyText:
Temple 4 (Dainichiji) is located at the end of the first sustained climb of the Shikoku Pilgrimage path, nestled in a tranquil upland valley. During our 2019 visit, our team spoke with the head monk, who has spearheaded efforts to make the temple more accessible to the increasing number of visitors. These updates include improved restrooms and an expanded parking area, ensuring greater comfort for pilgrims and other visitors.

While the temple warmly welcomes everyone, the monk and temple staff stress the importance of respect for the sacred site. Visitors are encouraged to read the posted signs for guidance and, whenever possible, to use Japanese when conversing, fostering an atmosphere of cultural understanding and reverence.
creator: KHAHfSWMJ6SshJHmk81TXGOPUzI3

title: Temple 4 Area - Map
BodyText:
Throughout the pilgrimage pathways in Tokushima Prefecture, henro (pilgrims) and visitors can find maps and other navigational aids designed to guide them from temple to temple and highlight additional points of interest along the route. These tools are invaluable for ensuring smooth travel and enriching the pilgrimage experience.

This particular map, written in Japanese, is located at the edge of a parking area near Temple 4 (Dainichiji). It serves as a practical resource for pilgrims, offering detailed information about the surrounding area and helping them navigate the sacred journey with confidence.
creator: KHAHfSWMJ6SshJHmk81TXGOPUzI3

title: Temple 3 to 4 path - Small temple
BodyText:
The common pathway connecting Temple 3 (Konsenji) and Temple 4 (Dainichiji) transitions from paved roads to a scenic route that winds through small fields, wooded areas, and tranquil bamboo groves. Along the way, it passes through a small, unaffiliated temple before rejoining a paved street.

At this unaffiliated temple, the resident monk often extends warm hospitality to passing henro (pilgrims), offering refreshments and engaging in friendly conversation when he is at home. This welcoming gesture adds a personal and heartwarming touch to the pilgrimage, creating a moment of connection and respite amidst the sacred journey.
creator: KHAHfSWMJ6SshJHmk81TXGOPUzI3

As more non-Japanese have participated in the pilgrimage, more of the newer, printed markers have included text in English as well as Japanese. These markers are a visible sign on the S
creator: KHAHfSWMJ6SshJHmk81TXGOPUzI3

title: Waymarker - Temple 3 to 4 Path
BodyText:
This laminated, printed waymarker is one of many that guide pilgrims along the pathways in Tokushima Prefecture, serving as a helpful navigation aid throughout the Shikoku Pilgrimage. With the growing participation of non-Japanese pilgrims, newer printed markers increasingly feature bilingual text in both English and Japanese, making the pilgrimage more accessible to international travelers.

These waymarkers are not only practical tools but also visible symbols of the pilgrimage experience, blending tradition with modern inclusivity as they guide pilgrims on their sacred journey.
creator: KHAHfSWMJ6SshJHmk81TXGOPUzI3

title: Itano Station - Henro guide
BodyText: Itano Station, on the JR Shikoku Kōtoku Line, is the closest local train station to Temple 3 (Konsenji), Temple 4 (Dainichiji), and Temple 5 (Jizoji). Here, someone has placed informational literature on the Shikoku Pilgrimage in English below the train schedule.
creator: KHAHfSWMJ6SshJHmk81TXGOPUzI3

title: Itano Station - Henro guide
BodyText:
Itano Station, located on the JR Shikoku Kōtoku Line, is the nearest local train station to Temple 3 (Konsenji), Temple 4 (Dainichiji), and Temple 5 (Jizōji) on the Shikoku Pilgrimage. This station serves as a convenient access point for pilgrims traveling by train to these temples.

Notably, someone has thoughtfully placed informational literature on the Shikoku Pilgrimage in English beneath the train schedule, offering valuable guidance to international pilgrims. This gesture reflects the welcoming spirit of the pilgrimage and provides an accessible resource for understanding the journey’s significance and practical details, even for those unfamiliar with Japanese.
creator: KHAHfSWMJ6SshJHmk81TXGOPUzI3

title: Temple 1 Henro Store
BodyText:
At Ryozenji, designated Temple 1 on the Shikoku Pilgrimage, there is a henro store that sells gear for pilgrims just starting their journey, including the white coat or vest, hat, walking stick, and stamp book or scroll that henro will need as they visit each temple.

Each temple on the pilgrimage will usually have a small selection of goods and supplies that can be purchased, but the Temple 1 henro store is one of the largest.
creator: KHAHfSWMJ6SshJHmk81TXGOPUzI3

title: Temple 1 Henro Store
BodyText:
At Ryōzenji, designated as Temple 1 on the Shikoku Pilgrimage, there is a well-stocked henro (pilgrim) store catering specifically to those beginning their spiritual journey. This store offers essential items for the pilgrimage, including the white coat or vest (hakui), a conical hat (sugegasa), the signature walking stick (kongō-zue), and a stamp book (nōkyō-chō) or scroll (kakejiku) used to collect stamps from each temple visited along the route. These items not only identify the wearer as a pilgrim but also hold symbolic and practical significance throughout the pilgrimage.

While many temples on the Shikoku Pilgrimage have small shops offering basic supplies and souvenirs, the henro store at Temple 1 stands out as one of the largest and most comprehensive. It serves as a central point for pilgrims to gather the necessary gear and receive guidance, making it an ideal starting place for their journey.
creator: KHAHfSWMJ6SshJHmk81TXGOPUzI3

title: Kickin' and a Gougin'
BodyText:
The smell of stale cigarette smoke hung low and dense as I walked through the heavily tented doors. The lighting was dim and poor. The sun stopped at the doorway. It took some effort for my eyes to adjust. Flashing neon. The unnatural greenish hue of florescent bulbs hanging overhead. Ostentatious carpets, where any stain would easily get lost in the motley of unrelated colors. A cacophony of bells, horns, whistles, and clinks from the hundreds of slot machines. Gloomy figures pumped tokens into various automated contraptions, eyes affixed, shoulders hunched. Oxygen tanks and wrist braces. An all-you-can-eat seafood buffet to the right. A panoptical tower in the middle, with double-sided glass, seeing all, seen by none. No windows. Time, day/night, was irrelevant. Outside is not welcome here. But first, a gruff security guard in an ill-fitted uniform. My ID. Fortunately, I was old enough for this. It was a beautiful Saturday. Fight night at the local casino.

I made my way to the impromptu arena. The white floor of the fight cage was encrusted with blood from untold previous encounters. Appropriate. Employees lined stackable chairs around the chain-linked hexagon. Others followed as they placed flyers advertising the forthcoming weekend’s events on each of the chairs. Midget wrestling and wet t-shirt contests. The bartender busily stocked the bar full of light domestic beers. Merchants arranged displays for their pricey wears, such that interested consumers might have the option to let anyone else know that they were once a part of this fandom. Said fandom begins to slowly enter. Affliction and Tapout shirts aplenty. Tattoos and bejeweled jeans. High heels and shorts skirts. Still plenty of time for the cash bar.

Backstage—i.e. the mobile home out back—the atmosphere was tense. Grapes, bananas, bottled water, and cheap assorted lunchmeat in the middle. The “red” and “blue” corners on opposing sides of the trailer. Combatants temporarily partitioned by inches of laminate wood paneling. Some paced nervously, exchanging apprehensive yet aggressive glances. Others sat listening to their trainers and cornermen as they got their hands taped. Others sprawled out on the black faux-leather couches, listening to ear-phoned music. Words were sparse in here. Quiet focus. The occasional laughter seemed to be born less of comedy than of a bodily need to vent, to release the overabundance of stored up energy from what was to come. Combatants in the evening’s earlier fights warmed up their kicks and punches in the back parking lot by the dumpsters. 1-2-3, 2-3-2, 1-2-10, 1-1-3-10, 2-3-2-9. Pads of various shapes and sizes absorbed the edgy strikes. Anticipation was palpable. Ring girls smoked cigarettes.

The fights went quick. Adrenaline tends not to pace its release over time. It’s not easy to train your body to curtail its natural reaction. But this made for short and exciting exchanges. Knockouts and submissions were abundant. Opponents rapidly expressed those years, months, and weeks of training and anticipation. Warm-ups became a luxury backstage, as we worked quickly to tape hands. Fighters were rushed in by the event coordinators who beckoned them by yelling last names. Each time the doors opened the sounds of the cheering audience would spill out. Sweat, blood, bruises, and hematomas visible on the exiting combatants. They did it for fun.

By the time the main fight was to commence, the bar ran dry. The audience was ready. Assigned seats were irrelevant, as most stood and hovered toward the center ring. Groups of same-shirted family and friends gathered in support of their representative. Behind thin curtains, the fighters and their respective entering entourages awaited announcement. I helped one of the fighters stay warm. Each kick, bruising my forearms behind the Thai pads. I pretended it didn’t hurt. He was ready. Less than two minutes into the first round, he took his opponent down to the ground and minced him with a flurry of punches. Blood. The referee pulled them apart, stopping the fight. The audience was rabid. They had gotten their fill of overpriced cheap beer and violent spectacles. Bloodlusty.

But not all of the casino’s bars ran dry that night. As I walked past the gruff security guard in the ill-fitted uniform to seek a more oxygen-rich environment outside, I looked back to see the two headliners sitting shoulder to shoulder, laughing over shared beers. Less than an hour after they met in the crimson-stained ring. Hallmark.
creator: OH1utgr2BKSojnHk3zaLBXxse4Z2

title: Statue of the Virgin Mary
BodyText: This picture is of a statue of the Virgin Mary that my parents put on display all year round. My parents keep this statue on our mantle because it reminds them of their values and keeps them grounded in the Catholic faith. The Virgin Mary can symbolize many things, but my parents view her as the absolute perfection and gentleness that God and mary exude. By having her on the mantle, my parents can be reminded of the beauty and grace God has to offer.
creator: JKF57656uoXXZt6S4BtEqK0y6bv1

title: Council Oak (Mvskoke)
BodyText:
The Council Oak in Tulsa, Oklahoma is a sacred site to the Mvskoke (Muscogee Creek) people. The Mvskoke were forced to relocate to what is now Oklahoma from their ancestral lands in the southeastern United States during the early 19th century through the violent tactics of the US Government remembered as the Trail of Tears. This site along the Arkansas River was established as sacred grounds by the Locv Pokv (Locapoga) tribal town of the Mvskoke in 1836. During the twentieth century, the site became incorporated into Tulsa, a city whose name derives from the Mvskoke word Tvlvhasse, meaning "old town, and was added to the Register of National Historical Places in 1976. During the November 2024 annual commemoration of Council Oak Tree Day, the City of Tulsa declared an intention to return governance of the site to the Muscogee Creek Nation.

The Council Oak Tree is now fully enmeshed in the cityscape of Tulsa, Oklahoma, a fixture in the Riverview residential neighborhood and adjacent to the downtown commercial district.

On the grounds of the Council Oak is a monument to the Mvskoke peoples who endured forced relocation and those who died from the brutal conditions en route from Alabama to Indian Territory.

The monument is entitled "Morning Prayer" and was commissioned by the Muscogee Creek Nation. "Morning Prayer" was designed by Richard Thornton, a Yuchi-Creek, and sculpted and installed by Dan Brook, also Creek. The monument features a stylized flame that symbolizes the sacred fires brought from ancestral lands to Indian Territory that were used to sacralize the site of the Council Oak and create continuity through the ritual life of survivors and their descendants. It also includes text panels that tell the story of forced migration, resettlement, and the rituals that animate this site.

Panel text: "Each year at Council Oak we celebrate the historic meeting held here after the United States Government removal to re-establish our tribal government. We remember the struggles and celebrate the successes of our Nation. We honor those tribal towns and all Mvskoke men and women who perpetuate the traditional ways and keep the ceremonial fires burning."

Panel text: "Assimilation into the dominant society, U.S. Government policies, and the loss of elders knowing the old ways contributed to the extinction of many tribal towns. Of the 44 original tribal towns removed, only a few Mvskoke and Euchee tribal grounds actively continue with ancient ceremonies. These remaining ceremonial grounds keep our sacred fires 'alive' to this day."
creator: 8H86gZYSFIRHGy8q39OgBAfQFeC2

title: Council Oak (Mvskoke)
BodyText:
Mvskoke Council Oak

The Council Oak in Tulsa, Oklahoma is a sacred site to the Mvskoke (Muscogee Creek) people. The Mvskoke were forced to relocate to what is now Oklahoma from their ancestral lands in the southeastern United States during the early 19th century through the violent tactics of the US Government remembered as the Trail of Tears. This site along the Arkansas River was established as sacred grounds by the Locv Pokv (Locapoga) tribal town of the Mvskoke in 1836. During the twentieth century, the site became incorporated into Tulsa, a city whose name derives from the Mvskoke word Tvlvhasse, meaning "old town, and was added to the Register of National Historical Places in 1976. During the November 2024 annual commemoration of Council Oak Tree Day, the City of Tulsa declared an intention to return governance of the site to the Muscogee Creek Nation.

The Council Oak Tree is now fully enmeshed in the cityscape of Tulsa, Oklahoma, a fixture in the Riverview residential neighborhood and adjacent to the downtown commercial district.

The Council Oak sits atop a hill to the east of the Arkansas River, which is just barely visible here through the development along 18th Street and Riverside Drive.

On the grounds of the Council Oak is a monument to the Mvskoke peoples who endured forced relocation and those who died from the brutal conditions en route from Alabama to Indian Territory.

"Morning Prayer" Monument

The monument is entitled "Morning Prayer" and was commissioned by the Muscogee Creek Nation and completed in 2009. "Morning Prayer" was designed by Richard Thornton, a Yuchi-Creek, and sculpted and installed by Dan Brook, also Creek. The monument features a stylized flame that symbolizes the sacred fires brought from ancestral lands to Indian Territory that were used to sacralize the site of the Council Oak and create continuity through the ritual life of survivors and their descendants. It also includes text panels that tell the story of forced migration, resettlement, and the rituals that animate this site.

Panel text: "Each year at Council Oak we celebrate the historic meeting held here after the United States Government removal to re-establish our tribal government. We remember the struggles and celebrate the successes of our Nation. We honor those tribal towns and all Mvskoke men and women who perpetuate the traditional ways and keep the ceremonial fires burning."

Panel text: "Assimilation into the dominant society, U.S. Government policies, and the loss of elders knowing the old ways contributed to the extinction of many tribal towns. Of the 44 original tribal towns removed, only a few Mvskoke and Euchee tribal grounds actively continue with ancient ceremonies. These remaining ceremonial grounds keep our sacred fires 'alive' to this day."

Panel text: "Fire is a revered element of many sacred rituals of the Mvskoke (Muscogee Creek People). The sacred fire represents the divine masculine of the 'Epofvnkv' (the Creator) to which all things are connected."

Text panel: "During the rituals, dances and prayers, the smoke rises from the sacred fires and it fades into the skies. The smoke carries the messages of the Mvskoke people to the Creator. These ceremonies are not primarily for personal benefit, but rather the benefit of the entire community or nation."

Text panel: "The sacred fires are built with logs pointing to the east, west, north and south; the four cardinal directions. This is the basis of many traditional Mvskoke concepts. The earliest Mvskoke teachings instruct that our sacred fires are to burn eternally. If extinguished, the Mvskoke will perish."

Text panel: "By 1834, our forefathers were forced to walk to the Indian Territory (Oklahoma) on what is known today as the Trail of Tears from our ancestral tribal lands in the southeastern United States. However, our Mvskoke leaders ensured that our traditional legacy was continued and protected here."

Text panel: "The sacred fires were integral to the religious, political and social systems long before the first European contact. The ashes of our ceremonial fires from each of the tribal towns were carried over the long march to be rekindled here."
creator: 8H86gZYSFIRHGy8q39OgBAfQFeC2

title: Willmore Park - St. Louis
BodyText: This park is closer to an urban area, surrounded by large fields of grass. The park itself has a large playground, with many swing sets. It’s a popular park so there are always many people around.There’s also a small hockey area, where many people come to play hockey, soccer, or even use their skateboards. There’s a dog park as well as a pond where many people fish or sit around. The people who come here are usually children or teenagers. Of course, there’s also a lot of parents and families who come here, and I have especially seen many parties (such as birthday or graduation parties) come and be hosted. People who come here seem to stay for an hour or two, and parks like this are usually the most popular mid-afternoon. Evidence of human interaction would be the run-down equipment, clearly a playground and pavement that have been used for years. There’s always people around somewhere, and all the benches are run-down as well. The grass is patchy, especially around areas where there are the frisbee nets and benches to sit on. There’s constant chatter and you can always see a grill with used coal underneath. There's a lot of human evidence at a place like this, since it’s such a popular and large area. Since it is closer to an Urban area, there are a diverse group of races and ethnicities who come to this park. There doesn’t seem to be a dominant religion/ethnicity/race, it seems very diverse with all different cultures coming to this place. I’ve seen many Bosnian and Hispanic families here—but still, it’s very diverse. It’s not an incredibly rich area, so I would say the visitors are anywhere from low to middle class. It gives a very “cozy” and welcoming vibe to the park. My own feelings and thoughts that have to do with this park is, that it holds a lot of memories from my childhood up to my teenage years. There have been many upgrades to this park, so it doesn’t look as old as it actually is. There are many places within it, such as the hockey and soccer fields, tennis, and a dog park area. There’s a pond and this has always been my favorite park to walk my dogs at. I’ve come here not only to play as a toddler, but to take homecoming and dance pictures in my teens. So, there’s so many memories that make this place special and notable to me. I’ve made new friends here, and hung out with old friends as well. There’s so much to do so I believe it to be an overall positive, notable place in my own life. I believe when it comes to this place, it’s so diverse and many families of various religions come to visit. Because of this, it is very welcoming and an overall positive vibe, with no religion feeling “dominant” over another. This makes it especially welcoming to minority religions. I remember many Islamic Bosnians coming to this park, and there are still many Bosnians who come and visit. Because of this, you will see many families with hijabs or families that speak different languages.
creator: gb9lsunG6oXMjsxmLnXgzmYcXG82

title: Stupsko Brdo - Bosnia
BodyText: The roads are kind of run-down, and there are many houses lined up one after another. There’s also clothing lines hung up behind each house, indicating families and life at each one. Each house is two houses divided in one building, so there’s always chatter going on. There are bikes along most of the front doors. The people are all Bosnians, many are related or have known each other's families for decades. It is a very small neighborhood, so everybody knows and interacts with each other. The evidence of human interaction would be the garbage cans at every house, the bikes being gone then reappearing, and the constant chatter you hear. Front doors are always open, indicating that anyone is welcome to come and visit. Everyones’ race in this neighborhood is white, since most of Bosnia are white people and not many foreigners choose to live there. I have many memories of this neighborhood as well, since it holds the house we stay at whenever we visit. Majority of the neighborhood are Muslims, which is obvious when Eid or Ramadan is happening, and there’s celebration all along the street and many religious individuals go to visit the Mosque every Sunday.
creator: gb9lsunG6oXMjsxmLnXgzmYcXG82

title: Bixby Avenue - Affton
BodyText: In this neighborhood, there were always many people on the street back then and we would always talk with one another and the younger ones would play together. There were a lot of trees lined up along the sidewalks, and a lot of greenery in general. A lot of holiday celebrations would be thrown as well, so there’d be neighborhood parties and a lot of cultural events. Fourth of July used to be a big thing here, and the whole neighborhood would gather to shoot fireworks and grill hot dogs. Religion played a part when it came to the holidays. Specifically, when it was Christmas, all the houses would be decorated and there’d be religious statues/figures all around the neighborhood. I would also always come to my best friend’s house to celebrate Christmas with her, even though I am not Christian myself.
creator: gb9lsunG6oXMjsxmLnXgzmYcXG82

title: Church of Scientology
BodyText: The Church of Scientology is a building that stands out every time you drive by with its elegant yet modern touch. Its grand stature and unique architecture make it a tough landmark to oversee. The S in the word scientology on the sign displays a resemblance of the classic Christian Cross but integrates its own twist with the triangles which is symbolic of its exclusive ideologies and belief system. Inside, the church is quiet and embodies a peaceful environment. The churches goal is to express the intention of liberation from suffering and to aide individuals in accomplishing spiritual wisdom. Initially, just looking at the building, it seems intimidating, but really I think its just a different alluring concept that a lot of people are unfamiliar with. It definitely spiked my curiosity!
creator: rdhZC6H9O1bzb92yPQMyCM8WbPO2

Initially, just looking at the building, it seems intimidating, but really I think its just a different alluring concept that a lot of people are unfamiliar with. It definitely spiked my curiosity!

title: Blessing for the Home on the Feast of Epiphany
BodyText: On Sunday, at the King of France church in St Louis, MO, after church had ended, the priest handed out these little cards with a piece of chalk. The directions are to all gather at the doorway of your home, write 20 C M B 25 to represent the current year as well as the initials of Casper, Melchior, and Balthasaar, and to say the following prayer, "May all who come to our home this year, rejoice to find Christ living among us and may we seek and see, in everyone we meet, Jesus, who is Lord for ever and ever. Amen." The marking of the doorway is a ritual used to bless the home and is linked to Epiphany, a Christian celebration. Epiphany marks the the visit of the three traditional Magi (Casper, Melchior, and Balthasaar) to baby Jesus. For the new year, it is meant to bring security and blessings into the home for all who enter.
creator: rdhZC6H9O1bzb92yPQMyCM8WbPO2

title: Cathedral, Basilica of St. Louis
BodyText:
The Cathedral Basilica of St. Louis is a remarkable structure with a complex build. From the outside you see a grand window, a castle like gothic design, arched doors, and a traditional Roman approach to style. The grass is vibrant green with trees that blow in the wind and overhang onto the building. The church bells ring loud for anyone near to hear and you listen to a soft mumble of conversations as visitors slowly make their way up the steps. Upon entering the church, you are greeted with the smell of incense and burning candles for those who have lit one in remembrance, or in prayer, of a loved one. The piano music plays at the perfect volume and encompasses the sacred area in a serene way as it echoes through the walls. The atmosphere is stunning with breathtaking meticulous mosaics filled with vibrant colors and exhibiting displays from the bible. Marble columns line the long hallways that form a path to the alter, where you see Jesus Christ hung from a cross, surrounded by exquisite and majestic architecture. As I sit in the pew I have chosen, my hands caress the cold polished wood, and I embody all of the wonderful things that are surrounding me. I look around and see fellow worshippers who have also chosen to be here in this place of worship on this beautiful Sunday. I see them gathered together, singing, kneeling in prayer, greeting those around them, and preparing for mass to begin.

Every time I step foot into this cathedral, I always feel something different. A sense of admiration, and devotion always fills my body, but the feeling on why I show up each Sunday feels a little different as I grow in my faith. To be a part of something so substantial and so connected to Jesus gives me a feeling of contentment. When I see others gathered to worship the same God and to give their selves and their prayers to Christ to take hold of, it instills a feeling of shared community and togetherness. What is happening within the walls feels harmonious and divine, like no one can disturb you in this time of worship, as if time stands still for a moment. The cathedral brings to us a place of preservation for our traditions and a place to practice our beliefs.

The Cathedral Basilica is a true representation of a framework that converges various topics into one. With its depictions of faith, history, stories, and craftsmanship, it serves as a true indication of what Catholic institutions are meant to symbolize and preserves its legacy for forthcoming communities.

Questions:

Are the mosaics meant to show specific occurrences from the bible, or are they more so meant to be open to interpretation?

How is the placement of the Cathedral Basilica important to its religious ties as a sacred house of worship? Does St. Louis signify something special for it?

When the cathedral was built, do you think that it came with the intention that the people who enter through its holy doors, may not be religious, but instead simply tourists who are interested in its history and architecture?
creator: rdhZC6H9O1bzb92yPQMyCM8WbPO2

title: home religion
BodyText:
This picture showcases my family's monthly ritual of worshiping the gods. It is an important family tradition in which all of us participate, expressing our respect and gratitude to our ancestors and deities. The ceremony is usually held at home, where we set up a table with abundant offerings, including fruits, snacks, homemade dishes, and wine. These offerings symbolize our sincerity and reverence as we pray for the blessings of our ancestors and deities to protect our family's health, happiness, and success.

At the end of the ceremony, we burn joss paper, typically in the container shown on the left side of the picture. Joss paper is a symbolic currency representing our care for our ancestors’ lives in another world. By doing so, we hope that our ancestors will have sufficient wealth in heaven. It is a way of expressing our gratitude to them.

This custom is part of the unique cultural traditions of southern coastal regions in China, deeply rooted in family values and local beliefs. We hold this ritual every month, not only to seek blessings from the deities and ancestors but also as an opportunity for family reunion.

location: shangtou city Guangdong China
creator: nE1zFFEYadXIDMeGfvyiZLoVJTs1

title: Rural folk activities
BodyText:
This photo shows the traditional You Shen （Parading of Deities) event held during the Spring Festival in Shantou, a common custom in Shantou and Fujian Minnan-speaking regions. Usually, on a specific day after the Spring Festival, villages in rural Shantou organize the event as a communal ritual. Villagers bring out statues of deities from temples for worship, and then young men from the village carry these statues around the village in a parade, praying for peace and prosperity.

The deities represented by these statues are often historical figures who made significant contributions to the village, such as teachers, doctors, or officials. The You Shen event is not only a traditional ritual but also a way to commemorate the village’s history and its influential figures, fostering a sense of identity and connection among the villagers.

location Shangtou city Gunagdon China
creator: nE1zFFEYadXIDMeGfvyiZLoVJTs1

title: Religion Yard Decor
BodyText: It is uncommon for individuals to showcase their religious beliefs through yard decor; however, this specific individual does this by propping up a sign that has a cross and says Jesus in all capitals. This signifies the individual(s) living in this home are most likely Christian since this religion believes in Jesus as the son of God and knows Jesus died on the cross. I noticed how the sign looked a little dirty, meaning it has been there for a decent amount of time. The sign is propped up against an outhouse, which is an old-fashioned bathroom. This property is located in Wildwood, MO, which is a predominately white area. Also, there is a large population of Christians within this area because of the copious amounts of Christian churches nearby. The yard also had loads of Christmas decor up, showing the individual(s) celebrate Christmas as well. I felt happy to see this sign because I am a Christian myself, and seeing others in my community believing in the same thing as me makes me happy.
creator: eNlFMkamG3dhAy0n4WcBAcZECOm2

title: Rural folk activities
BodyText:
This photo shows the most lively festival of the year for the people of Shantou, which does not yet have an official name. On a certain day after the Chinese New Year every year, the rural villages in Shantou would hold a grand festival of worship on a village-by-village basis. All the idols are moved from the temple to the square for worship. The villagers would then bring all kinds of food to the square and each family would have a table. These tables are filled with offerings such as fruits, snacks, roasted meat, chickens and ducks, as well as alcohol and paper money to symbolize respect for the gods and ancestors. The villagers offer incense and worship in turn, praying for favorable weather conditions, family health and business success in the new year. The whole scene was bustling with pious worship rituals and mutual exchanges among villagers, reflecting a strong community atmosphere and family ties.

At the end of the ceremony, the offerings are taken home to be enjoyed, which is seen as a symbol of sharing the blessings of the deity. The idol, on the other hand, will be re-carried back to the temple by the village youths to end the day's activities. Although the festival has no official name, it has become a unique cultural symbol in the Shantou area, carrying not only respect for traditional beliefs, but also an important moment for villagers to reunite and pass on their culture. This kind of worship activity demonstrates the Shantou people's emotion towards their history and homeland, and at the same time allows the younger generation to feel the charm and significance of traditional culture.

Participating in such activities gives me a deep sense of belonging and respect for traditional culture. In modern society, most villagers live in cities, but everyone returns to the village for this festival. This kind of worship ceremony allows me to pause and reflect on our roots and family bonds. Every offering table and each item on it carries respect for our ancestors and deities, as well as the hopes of each family for the future. This communal ritual, involving the entire village, makes me feel the unity and warmth between people.

location：Shangtou city ,Guangdong, China
creator: nE1zFFEYadXIDMeGfvyiZLoVJTs1

title: Hobby Lobby Religion
BodyText:
Hobby Lobby is a well-known home decor store. This store is in almost all states and has been extremely successful in their business. David Green and his family are the founders of Hobby Lobby and are devout Christians who continued their beliefs into their work. Before walking in, I noticed that this store is in a pretty busy strip mall. There is a grocery store, restaurants, and a consignment store nearby that are quite busy. The first thing I noticed when I walked in was the hours placed on the door. It states that they are open Monday-Saturday and are off on Sunday to give their workers a break to spend with family and worship. I had never read their hours before, so I was quite shocked when I saw this. I knew they were closed on Sundays but did not know they said, "Give time for employees to worship" on their doors.

After I entered the store, I noticed how friendly the workers are. They welcomed me and asked me if I needed help finding anything. I saw many individuals in the store, most being white middle-aged women. Most were shopping alone and taking their time in each aisle, slowly viewing all the items the store had. There were many workers in the store who were walking around and making sure everything was tidy, and all customers were finding what they needed. I walked around the store for a little while until I came across my first piece of Christian decor. It was a small piece of wall art, most likely for a children's bedroom, that stated, "God is within her, she will not fall." This is a commonly known Bible verse in the Christian community and is used frequently for decor, Bible covers, motivational quotes, etc. This specific verse is not quoted on the art, but as a Christian myself, I noticed it from the Bible and knew it was a verse.

The next piece of wall art I encountered was another Bible verse: "She is clothed with strength and dignity, and she laughs without fear of the future. Proverbs 31:25." This piece seemed more for adults than the first piece did since it was white and tan.

After leaving the wall art section, I came across a small shelf of crosses, all varying in color, size, and shape. Most of them had Bible verses on them, and some didn't. The ones with Bible verses were mostly stating values each believer should have, such as hope, faith, trust, and love.

Lastly, I came across a section of devotionals and Bible's. I was not expecting to see these since this was a home decor store, but they had a pretty significant collection of them. These devotionals ranged from Jesus Calling, which is an extremely common devotional book in the Christian community, to Walking with God. The books were very pretty and varied in color and size.

All in all, Hobby Lobby utilizes their religion to expand their merchandise. They have opened up many doors by using religion in their merchandise, such as selling Bible's and other religious home decor like the wall art. I talked to some employees, and they said that the corporation is devoted to serving their community and ensuring individuals have access to home decor that relates to the Christian religion. The store was not very homey, though. I was expecting a very cozy and warm environment, but the bright fluorescent lights and busy crowd did not allow that to happen; however, the workers were extremely friendly and helpful. Hobby Lobby shows how common the Christian religion is here in Saint Louis, especially in the suburbs. The store was busy and many people were viewing the religious items the store had.
creator: eNlFMkamG3dhAy0n4WcBAcZECOm2

title: Goodwill Religion
BodyText:
The Goodwill on Manchester Road is a busy store that provides second-hand items for individuals in the Saint Louis community. Before entering the store, I noticed the strip mall the store was in. There were a variety of other businesses, including a sushi restaurant, a coding place, and a nail salon. The parking lot was quite full for a Thursday afternoon around 3 pm. When walking in, I was immediately greeted by a cashier who asked me how my day was and if I needed any help. After, I made my way through the store, taking in all of the items Goodwill was selling. Most were clothes, but they had a section for home goods as well. There were many different people in the store. Some were families with young children shopping for toys. Some were veterans who were viewing the clothes. And some were middle-aged women looking at the home goods.

Once I went back into the home section, I immediately came across a nativity scene in a large box. It was priced at $10.77. All of the pieces were inside and in great condition. The nativity scene was eight pieces total and included porcelain figures. The nativity scene most likely was from a Christian individual, who either did not need the nativity scene anymore or did not want it anymore.

As I continued throughout the store, I noticed another home decor item, which was a small angel who was holding a cross. It had wings and was a woman with a long dress on that had gold detailing on the bottom. She was hugging the gold cross in her arms, holding it tightly. I did not check the price on this item, but if I had to guess, I would say it would be no more than $5.

After viewing the rest of the store, I was taking in the feeling of the store. It felt extremely comforting and homey. I am not sure if that is because the workers and fellow shoppers were extremely nice or if the second-hand items made that feeling. The lights were a soft white, and the store was playing quiet music on the speakers. When I left the store, the workers told me goodbye and wished me a happy new year.

Since this second-hand store was selling religious items, it makes me wonder why these items were there. Maybe the individual left their religion and went to another one, or maybe just left in general. Maybe the individual found another thing of the same item and liked it better. Maybe the individual was moving and did not need that item anymore. There are many possibilities as to why these items could be at the thrift store. This Goodwill shows how people incorporate their religion into most aspects of their life, whether that is in their clothing, house decor, or jewelry. I believe that this store allowed me to see the possibilities as to why some people are getting rid of these religious items and what that means in our society. Are more people leaving their churches or shopping more often? We may never find the answer; however, looking at the items and analyzing the meaning of them helps our society grow in our knowledge about this topic.
creator: eNlFMkamG3dhAy0n4WcBAcZECOm2
