title: Holy Trinity Catholic Church
BodyText: Holy Trinity is a Catholic church located in a very wealthy neighborhood in Washington DC. The church is in the heart of Georgetown surrounded by between rowhouses. The church is beautiful with pillars lining the entrance giving off a very formal feeling presence. This is further reinforced by the clothes of those who attend. Many of those who attend Sunday service are in suits and formal dresses including the kids, many of which are dressed up in khakis and semi formal attire. The congregation is made up of many families with young kids. I observed many families talking with each other before and after the Sunday service. The congregation was clearly a very tight knit group with many having connections with each other outside of the church. The community is also seen as the church is connected to a school which many of the families send their kids to. The inside of the church was very well lit with a large seating area and some balcony seating space. The church has tall ceilings with artwork carved into the wall depicting the day that Jesus was crucified. I was welcomed by ushers at the entrance handing out pan flips and welcoming me into the service. They had smiles on their face and a welcoming tone to their voice, this set the tone for my visit as from the start I was welcomed in.            While the congregation was very welcoming the congregation was made up of predominantly white families. This comes from the economic status of the surrounding area as the church is deep inside the upper class area of Washington DC. The congregation may be welcoming but due to their location they predominantly attract white families. The location of the church limits the accessibility for those outside of Georgetown and the surrounding neighborhoods. This lack of diversity within the church plays a role in the up bringing of the kids who attend the church and its Sunday school program. There is a need for the diversification within the upper class DC area.            After the conclusion of the service, I enjoyed a donut from the school cafeteria. This allowed me to further see the interactions of the community as parents were talking and kids were running around with their friends. This gave me the feeling of a very family friendly congregation that welcoming growing families. This openness to inclusion of families is important for the church as it allows for growth through the church’s congregation. The church is pivotal for the practice of Christianity because without an accessible church in the heart of Georgetown many would be left without a place to practice as traffic can become an issue. I thought the service was very respectful and there was an undertone of the conservative nature of the church within the priest’s homily. This conservative undertone plays to the location of the church as many of the upper class families are conservative leaning.
creator: b4GD3PejFOXBgLEzgOBazwi5uyg2

title: St. Camillus Parish
BodyText: St. Camillus Parish is located in Silver Spring Maryland within a very diverse neighborhood this is seen in the congregation who attend the masses. I attended the multicultural Christmas Eve mass. This mass was very powerful as many different cultures can come and enjoy mass as one congregation. This diversity allows for there to be no boundaries of entry to attend mass. St. Camillus Parish is very large with brick walls and dim lighting. There is a small entrance which has double doors where there were many greeters waiting to hand out programs. The congregation is made up of all walks of people those stems from the diverse surrounding neighborhood where many immigrants have settled. There was some talking before and after the service but mostly joyous celebration as Christmas was coming the next morning. There were different languages spoken before and after mass between families and friends.            The mass was in three different languages this entailed three different homilies all done in their respective language and music done in all three languages. This provides a sense of belonging within a diverse group all connecting by their religious beliefs. This sense of community stems from everyone respecting the other languages as they all have their moments of practice. St. Camillus Parish is also made up of a lot of families with little kids who were full of excitement for the Christmas morning to come. This was seen as after the service many kids could be seen yelling and running back to their cars in order to get home for bed.            St. Camillus Parish does a wonderful job making all feel welcome I think this stems from the congregation which is made up of many different ways of life. There is someone from all walks of life with their own life experiences, but the Parish provides a place where all can come and enjoy service as one. I talked to the older lady next to me in the middle of the service as she was trying to ask me a question about the order of the homilies. This conversation took a moment due to her only speaking French. I took French for many years through high school which helped me slowly explain the order. This gave me a sense of belonging in the church as the older lady trusted she could turn to her side and ask me a question.            Reflecting back upon my time at the church I believe that if I were looking for a regular church to attend, I would give a lot of consideration to St. Camillus Parish as the community is unmatched. The church gives off a welcoming feeling to all who step through the door no matter who they are.
creator: b4GD3PejFOXBgLEzgOBazwi5uyg2

title: President Carters Lying in State
BodyText: President Carters passing crossed many Americans news the past week. This provided an interesting opportunity to go to the Capital Building to President Carters Lying in State. This was a very mournful event, when waiting in line there was an air of respect with many talking very quietly or not talking at all. When inside the capital there was no photography allowed and no phones were out. All kept their eyes low and many said a prayer or took a knee. These prayers were all a private moment between the prayer and God wishing the best for former President Carter. The respectful mourners all kept former president Carter in their prayers in their respective religions. The prayers were all meaningful holding value within every religion. There was no visible judging for how people mourned the formers presidents passing. There was respect for all in a moment which was bigger than any singular person. After I left the hall I had a deep appreciation for the people around me as we had all gone to pay respects to a man none of us ever met and this was all done in each persons personal way.
creator: b4GD3PejFOXBgLEzgOBazwi5uyg2

title: Penn State Basketball
BodyText: The Penn State basketball games are a huge attraction for families and students of Penn State. This is a place where many come together from all walks of life to support the same team. This is a place where it does not matter who you are or where you’re from as long as you are supporting Penn State. There is a sense of belonging to the community as all are cheering in their own way for Penn State to win. Every fan is watching waiting expectantly for a big play. This event brings people together who would never cross paths. The seating force you to sit next to someone you would never get to meet anywhere else. The fan to fan interactions come from a mutual excitement over the game and a desire for the team to well. There is a supportive culture where there is a common goal of victory. After the game I reflected upon the moments I had shared with others. I had watched as people celebrated together and met new people through high fives. This support for a school team brings many different cultures together allowing for common ground to be found.
creator: b4GD3PejFOXBgLEzgOBazwi5uyg2

title: Boston Aquarium
BodyText: The Boston Aquarium is a modern building with a path to follow through all the exhibits. This allowed me to experience all different kinds of animals which I would never have been able to see. I shared this experience with those around me. There were many families with little kids running around excited by all the animals. Seeing the kids run around excited showed me that this was more than a place to see cool animals. This was a place where many become intrigued by the world around them. The kids would press their faces against the glass to get a closer look at the fish. The aquarium was a safe place for this kids, from all over the city, to come and explore the world of fish. There were kids talking with each other and pointing out different fish. After reflecting upon my time at the Boston Aquarium I have a deeper appreciation for place where people can explore the world together. This ties into religion as none of the kids were concerned about another religion, they were all intrigued by the fish and exploring what the world had to offer.
creator: b4GD3PejFOXBgLEzgOBazwi5uyg2

title: Saint Francis Xavier College Church
BodyText: Founded in 1843, St. Francis Xavier church is the religious “heart” of Saint Louis University. Standing along Grand Blvd., it is an important spot not only for students at SLU but also for citizens of St. Louis at large.
creator: vkXhcfUpNogQCZia3cvpO8pJ44G3

title: Mississippi Palisades State Park
BodyText: Located among the Mississippi River in northwestern Illinois, the Palisades State Park stands as an example of God in nature. Many religions believe that the world around us is proof that there is a God, these pictures show that. The area is quiet, fairly devoid of outside noise outside of the passing of cars on the remote highway far below the lookout point. While there you may encounter one of the many freight trains transporting items along the river. The park is also home to a great deal of wildlife that is hard to find anywhere else.
creator: vkXhcfUpNogQCZia3cvpO8pJ44G3

title: St. Francis Xavier College Church
BodyText: Founded in 1843, St. Francis Xavier College church is the religious heart of Saint Louis University. Located along Grand Blvd, the church is an important piece of architecture not only for students at SLU but also for citizens of St. Louis City. The true beauty of the church lies on the inside. When you walk in it feels like you have left the busyness of Midtown St. Louis and entered a quiet, beautiful place that is closer to heaven than it is to Earth.
creator: vkXhcfUpNogQCZia3cvpO8pJ44G3

title: Basilica of the National Shrine of Immaculate Conception
BodyText: The Basilica of the National Shrine of the Immaculate Conception is located in Washington D.C. It serves as a minor basilica in the Catholic faith and acts as a national shrine. It is also the largest church building in North America and the tallest habitable building in Washington D.C. Walking into the basilica for the first time can be intimidating. The building is huge and the ceiling is covered in a collection of artwork. The first mosaic that most people's eyes are drawn to is the Christ in Majesty Mosaic. The goal of the mosaic is to remind the people who see it that Christ reigns above all. The mosaic shows Christ with his arms raised and three tongues of flames coming from his head. There are many fine details in the image, such as his crown of jewels to show he is above all, the look on his face that shows he is in judgment, and his throne which is a symbol of pardon and reconciliation. Moving on from the mural there is a large number of other things to do. The basilica has numerous chapels and there is almost always a mass happening in one of them. There is also a cafeteria where visitors can get food. Lastly, there is a gift shop that sells different religious goods. All proceeds from the gift shop contribute back to the basilica. Moving on from things to do at the Basilica, there is a lot of feelings and emotions that happen while inside. All the times I have been there it has always been packed full of people. The lights are low in the entirety of the church and there is always quiet music playing in the background. The air smells of candle wax and incense. Even though I was there to sightsee, it was obvious that the feeling in the air was one of worship. Numerous tours are being given simultaneously, and it is difficult to find a quiet and private spot to pray. The church is a large and beautiful example of religion and architecture in the United States.
creator: vkXhcfUpNogQCZia3cvpO8pJ44G3

BodyText: On Gravois, right before highway 44 there's a lopsided cross. There's nothing detailing why it's there or if the uneven nature of it indicates anything. Modern cross or abstract art and a statement?

title: Lived Religion Example 1
BodyText: I chose this tattoo because I became acquainted with a co-worker in the fall of 2023 that had one. The backstory behind this: he is a sureno that was relocated to Illinois after his prison term through a drug rehabilitation program that places the patients into jobs with the intent of integrating them into society. What he believes, and many other surenos believe, is that the “Lady of Guadalupe” is a symbol of protection and faith. She is seen as a prominent representation of Mexico in Catholicism. The Catholic religion is so deeply engrained in many Hispanic cultures that it even bleeds over into gang life. I had to get this picture from google because though I’d seen my co-worker’s tattoo, I never got a chance to take a picture of it because he left the job and program and fled back to the west coast after about 2 months of being in Illinois.
creator: cbajE8sZRhbpsfT4wGI0bppRQra2

title: Lived Religion Example 2
BodyText: I took these pictures in a Rural King last week. These are belt buckles that I would say heavily represent the Evangelical faction of Christianity. I took note of the American flag in the background of two of them, one of them stating: “I stand for the flag and kneel for the cross”. I grew up interacting with Evangelical Christians and it is very on brand for them to treat Evangelical Christianity as being synonymous with patriotism. For them, American values and Christianity go hand-in-hand, even so much as to have these beliefs bleed over into politics.
creator: cbajE8sZRhbpsfT4wGI0bppRQra2

title: Centennial Establishment of the Society of Saint Vincent de Paul
BodyText:
The Society of Saint Vincent de Paul is a Catholic laypersons’ organization which promotes and facilitates volunteer-led efforts to address material conditions of the poor and needy. The first conference of this organization in the US met at the Cathedral of Saint Louis, King of France in 1845. Saint Vicnent de Paul is considered a Patron Saint of the City of St. Louis.

Title: Plaque Commemorating the Society of St. Vincent dePaul

title: Bishop's Chair & Kneeler; Archbishop's Coat of Arms
BodyText:
The historic chair and kneeler once belonged to Bishop Joseph Rosati and was created around the time the cathedral was consecrated in 1834. The Coat of arms above the chair belong to the archbishop of the Archdiocese of Saint Louis. The coat of arms includes the inscription “Serve the Lord With Gladness”, and a design featuring the flag of Baltimore, the Archbishop's former parish, as well as his Polish ancestry.

Title: Bishop Rosati’s Chair and Kneeler; Current Archbishop Rozanski’s Coat of Arms

Publisher: Archdiocese of Saint Louis

Contributor: Kathleen Jochman

Format: JPG Image

title: Bishop Joseph Rosati
BodyText:
The above oil painting was completed in 1887 to memorialize the first bishop of Saint Louis Diocese. Bishop Joseph Rosati was responsible for commissioning a suitable structure and landmark for the growing diocese, and in 1831 laid the cornerstone for the current building. Within 3 years, the structure would be commemorated as a cathedral, the very first west of the Mississippi.

Title: Oil Portrait of the Right Reverend Joseph Rosati, First Bishop of St. Louis

Author: Schultze, Louis 1820-1901

Publisher: Missouri Historical Society

Contributor: Kathleen Jochman

Format: JPG image 238 x 288

Rights: Copyrights Undetermined

Source: http://collections.mohistory.org/resource/374049
creator: TrWZ9PxTspOnzWwVD6UeQTxC5s12

title: Lithograph of St. Louis Cathedral, 1840
BodyText:
Pictured is a lithograph of the grounds of the Old Cathedral, to the right pictures the Bishop’s House. The Cathedral is the only remaining original structure from the time. There are buildings in the background, none of which are standing today, placed where the interstate is now carved through downtown St. Louis.

title: Vestibule Memorial to Msgr. Tannrath Is Opened to View- The Cathedral Basilica of St. Louis
BodyText:
The left-most column and top photo on this page of a newspaper discuss the memorial mosaic created for Msgr. J. J. Tannrath. The creation of a memorial mosaic showcases that these pieces of art carry weight for the community and are more than beautiful images, but a story of faith as well the specific St. Louis Catholic community. 

Title: Vestibule Memorial to Msgr. Tannrath is Opened to View

Creator: Unknown

Publisher: St. Louis Globe Democrat

Contributor: Maura Hill 

Date: June 29th, 1931

Type: Newspaper

Format: Page 3

Rights: Unknown

Source: Newspaper.com, St. Louis Globe-Democrat
creator: zHwslkIPrdaiaeuXvaSbHh0JIHt1

title: The Mosaic Beauty of the St. Louis Cathedral- The Cathedral Basilica of St. Louis
BodyText:
In this single page of a multi-page article in the St. Louis Globe Democrat, the design process and style of the mosaics are described in detail. Learning the process of this complex art form creates a greater appreciation for the craft and the description of the St. Louis' specific details create a home-like feeling. It is also important to note that there is a connection to ancient arts and societies. Creating elaborate and ancient inspired religious spaces connects the church goer to their God more closely because the house of God is meant to be elaborate for Him. 

Title: The Mosaic Beauty of the St. Louis Cathedral 

Creator: Nell Gross

Publisher: St. Louis Globe-Democrat

Contributor: Maura Hill 

Date: October 13th, 1962

Type: Newspaper

Format: Page 99

Rights: Unknown

Source: Newspaper.com, St. Louis Globe-Democrat
creator: zHwslkIPrdaiaeuXvaSbHh0JIHt1

title: Building St. Louis' Great Cathedral- The Cathedral Basilica of St. Louis
BodyText:
Two weeks after the previous article, an entire page of the Post dispatch was dedicated to the excitement surrounding the start of this amazing building. An illustration shows us an image of what the cathedral was planned to look like after its completion. From this drawing, it is clear there is art on the ceilings in some areas, but it is unclear if the copious amounts of mosaics were a part of the plan at this time. This article showcases the excitement and impact of this cathedral and also brings up the question of when the mosaic route was taken. 

Title: Building St. Louis’ Great Cathedral

Creator: Rev D. S. Phelan 

Publisher: The Post Dispatch St. Louis

Contributor: Maura Hill 

Date: November 11th, 1908

Type: Newspaper

Format: Page 49

creator: zHwslkIPrdaiaeuXvaSbHh0JIHt1

title: Legions of Catholics to March To Cathedral Site- The Cathedral Basilica of St. Louis
BodyText:
This newspaper article briefly discusses the parade that took place at the laying of the cornerstone of the cathedral. Thousands of people and over fifty musicians attended the parade. This kind of celebration is rarely seen today and indicates the impact this new church had on the community even in the early stages of construction. 

Title: Legions of Catholics to March to Cathedral Site

title: Noted German Artist Coming Here to Decorate Cathedral- The Cathedral Basilica of St. Louis
BodyText:
This newspaper column states that August Oetgen, a well known mosaic artist in Germany, will be making the trip to St. Louis to assist in the installation of the mosaics at the cathedral. The lengths the architects, artists, and Catholic officials went to making sure these mosaics were beautiful and well made shows that these mosaics were important and meant to be impactful.

BodyText:
This front page news article from 1990 discusses the creation of the mosaic museum in the basement of the cathedral. The process of installing the mosaics, examples of the mosaics scale, and other artifacts from the cathedral will be housed there. This museum opened up a new way to attract visitors.

BodyText:
This postcard showcases the cathedral in 1914, the year it opened to the public. The mosaics inside had not yet been completed, but this postcard showcases the splendor of the Romanesque exterior which factors into the artistic draw of the cathedral. Creation of a postcard immediately after opening shows this place was anticipated to be popular and well known.

title: Decorations in Mosaic Cathedral of St. Louis- Cathedral Basilica of St. Louis
BodyText:
The Lotus Magazine published this three page article about the mosaics of the main altar and baldacchino at the Cathedral in 1916. The main architect of the cathedral, George D. Barnett, is interviewed for this magazine and discusses his beliefs that mosaics should look like mosaics and not exact copies of the cartoons. Striving for this original appearance makes the mosaics feel like pieces from ancient times.

title: Umbraculum
BodyText:
The umbraculum, or “big umbrella”, located on the right side of the photo, is one of two ritualistic papal objects which denote the historic significance and honor given to the Cathedral to designate it a Holy Basilica. The Basilica honor was sanctified by Pope John XXIII in 1961.

title: Front Facade
BodyText:
The Hindu Temple of St. Louis is the largest Hindu place of worship in the St. Louis area. The temple got its start in 1988 when it was registered as a not for profit organization in the State of Missouri. In 1991 the main temple was completed. The deity sculptures were installed in 1995. There are around 14,000 Hindu practitioners living in the St. Louis area. The goal of this documentation project is to document and record the various features of the temple on separate notes on the Where’s Religion website.

"The Temple was first registered as a not for profit organization in the state of Missouri on March 7th, 1988" (Temple History). Construction was finished and services began on Nov 8, 1991. The temple is one of Seven official Hindu organizations in the St. Louis area.

Hindu Temple of St. Louis, Mark Lovelace, YouTube, Blake Koehr, Image, JPEG, Hindu Temple of St. Louis website. https://www.hindutemplestlouis.org/temple-history/
creator: oZd2tbTqLhhKlzxSGPW7ic6F1Pv2

title: Vaikasi Vikasam
BodyText:
The Hindu Temple of St. Louis is the largest Hindu place of worship in the St. Louis area. The temple got its start in 1988 when it was registered as a not for profit organization in the State of Missouri. In 1991 the main temple was completed. The deity sculptures were installed in 1995. There are around 14,000 Hindu practitioners living in the St. Louis area. The goal of this documentation project is to document and record the various features of the temple on separate notes on the Where’s Religion website.

Vaikasi Vikasam, a yearly festival in honor of the Hindu god Lord Murugan.

The Hindu Temple of St. Louis, Blake Koehr, Image, JPG, The Hindu Temple of St. Louis, https://hindutemplestlouis.smugmug.com/2019-Photos/Vaikasi-Vishakam.
creator: oZd2tbTqLhhKlzxSGPW7ic6F1Pv2

title: The Ugadi festival
BodyText:
The Ugadi festival was celebrated at the temple in April, 2013. This is the first day of the year on the Hindu calendar.

title: St. Charles 1950 Newspaper
BodyText:
In this newspaper clip, we read a short story about a woman who was able to return to her home, 554 Madison St. This is the same address as the first AME Church of St. Charles which was turned into a residential building sometime before 1950.
